page.title: 1984 Biman Bangladesh Airlines Fokker F27 crash

revision.text:
{{Infobox aircraft occurrence |occurrence_type = Accident |name = 1984 Biman Bangladesh Airlines Fokker F27 crash |image = Fokker F27-600 S2-ABJ B Biman Dum Dum 08 09 74 edited-4.jpg |caption = The accident aircraft in 1974, ten years prior to the accident. |date = 5 August 1984 |type = [[Controlled flight into terrain]]{{ASN accident|id= 19840805-1|title= S2-ABJ}} due to bad weather{{cite journal|title= Commercial flight safety: 1984 reviewed – Fatal accidents: scheduled passenger flights|journal= [[Flight International]]|date= 26 January 1985|page= 35|format= PDF|url= http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1985/1985%20-%200249.html|accessdate= {{Date|2014-8-14}} }} |site = near [[Zia International Airport]]
[[Dhaka]], [[Bangladesh]] |passengers = 45 |crew = 4 |injuries = 0 |fatalities = 49 |survivors = 0 |aircraft_type = [[Fokker F27 Friendship|Fokker F27-600]] |origin = [[Shah Amanat International Airport|Patenga Airport]] |destination = [[Zia International Airport]] |operator = [[Biman Bangladesh Airlines]] |tail_number = S2-ABJ |}} On 5 August 1984, a [[Biman Bangladesh Airlines]] [[Fokker F27 Friendship|Fokker F27-600]] crashed into a marsh near [[Zia International Airport]] (now [[Shahjalal International Airport]]) in [[Dhaka]], [[Bangladesh]] while landing in poor weather. The aircraft was performing a scheduled domestic passenger flight between [[Shah Amanat International Airport|Patenga Airport]], [[Chittagong]] and Zia International Airport, Dhaka. With a total death toll of 49 people, it is the deadliest aviation disaster to occur on Bangladeshi soil and also the airline's worst accident.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/06/world/around-the-world-49-die-in-bangladesh-as-plane-plunges.html |title=AROUND THE WORLD; 49 Die in Bangladesh As Plane Plunges |date=6 August 1984 |publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' |accessdate=14 August 2014}} ==Aircraft== The aircraft, a [[Fokker F27 Friendship|Fokker F27-600]] registered S2-ABJ, was manufactured in 1971. It first flew for [[Indian Airlines]] but it was given to Biman in 1972, as a part of all the support given to Bangladesh by the [[Government of India]] following [[History of Bangladesh after independence|Bangladesh's Independence]]. At the time of the accident, the aircraft had flown more than 24,000 cycles and more than 15,500 airframe hours. ==Passengers and crew== There were a total of 45 passengers and 4 crew members on board the flight, all of whom perished in the crash. There was one Briton and one Japanese among the passengers, and the rest of the passengers and crews were Bangladeshi. Thirty three of the passengers were traveling to Dhaka to catch connecting flights to the Middle East. The captain of the flight was Mr. Kayes Ahmed Majumdar, an experienced pilot by the time of the accident. He had logged 5000 flying hours. The co-pilot was [[Kaniz Fatema Roksana]], who was also known as the first female commercial pilot of Bangladesh.{{cite web|title=Breaking the Glass Ceiling|url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/magazine/2010/03/01/cover.htm|website=thedailystar.net|accessdate=23 June 2015}} ==Accident== The weather conditions in Dhaka were poor on the day of the accident; there was turbulence and heavy rain made visibility very poor. Amid these conditions, the crew first attempted a [[VOR/DME|VOR]] approach to [[Zia International Airport]]'s runway 32. As the runway was not spotted by either crew member, a [[missed approach]] was executed. The crew then tried an [[Instrument approach|ILS approach]] on runway 14 of the same airport, but a missed approach had to be executed again as both pilots had failed to spot the runway once again. On the crew's third approach (second on runway 14), the plane got too low while it was still several hundred meters from the runway but neither crew member realized this (due to the poor visibility) and the plane crashed into a swamp about 550 meters short of the runway.{{efn|It was also stated that the aircraft crashed beyond the runway, but considering the crash location (north west of Dhaka) and the fact that the flight was approaching runway 14 of DAC (approach is from north west of Dhaka city), it is clear that the plane crashed short of the runway and not beyond it.}} ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist|1}} {{Aviation accidents and incidents in 1984}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Biman Bangladesh Airlines Fokker F27 crash}} [[Category:Aviation accidents and incidents in Bangladesh]] [[Category:Airliner accidents and incidents caused by weather]] [[Category:Aviation accidents and incidents in 1984]] [[Category:Airliner accidents and incidents involving controlled flight into terrain]] [[Category:Accidents and incidents involving the Fokker F27]] [[Category:1984 in Bangladesh]] [[Category:Biman Bangladesh Airlines]] [[Category:Airlines of Asia accidents and incidents]] [[Category:August 1984 events]]

{{Use British English|date=March 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Other uses|Ariel (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = ARIEL | image = | image_alt = | image_caption =
| mission_type = [[Space observatory]] | operator = [[European Space Agency|ESA]]{{dot}}ARIEL Consortium | COSPAR_ID = | SATCAT = | website = {{url|http://ariel-spacemission.eu}} | mission_duration = 4 years<ref>[http://sci.esa.int/ariel/59798-summary/ ARIEL Summary]. ESA.</ref>
| manufacturer = | launch_mass = ~{{convert|1300|kg|abbr=on}}<ref>[http://sci.esa.int/ariel/59800-spacecraft/ ARIEL Spacecraft]. ESA.</ref> | dry_mass = ~{{convert|950|kg|abbr=on}} | payload_mass = ~{{convert|300|kg|abbr=on}} | dimensions = | power =
| launch_date = 2028 | launch_rocket = [[Ariane 6|Ariane 6-2]] | launch_site = {{Unbulleted list|Ariane Launch Area 4|[[Guiana Space Centre]]}} | launch_contractor = [[Arianespace]] | entered_service =
<!--Telescope parameters--> | instrument_type = [[Cassegrain reflector]]<!--converts telescope fields to suit a camera or other similar instrument--> | telescope_type = <!--type of telescope, mirror arrangement, etc--> | telescope_diameter = oval: 1.1 m × 0.7 m | telescope_focal_length= <!--focal length of telescope--> | telescope_area = 0.64 m<sup>2</sup><!--collecting area--> | telescope_wavelength = visible and near-infrared | telescope_resolution = <!--resolution of telescope--> | instruments = <!--a list of instruments on the satellite-->
| insignia = ARIEL insignia.png | insignia_size = 150 | insignia_alt = A grey opaque circle with the word "ARIEL" written in white across the circle's bottom half. A series of concentric circles close in on the black-colored dot in the "I", with the last circle colored yellow, representing an exoplanet transiting in front of a star. | insignia_caption = Official mission insignia
| programme = '''[[Cosmic Vision]]''' | previous_mission = [[PLATO (spacecraft)|PLATO]] | next_mission = [[Advanced Telescope for High Energy Astrophysics|ATHENA]] }}
The '''Atmospheric Remote-sensing Infrared Exoplanet Large-survey''' ('''ARIEL'''), is a [[space observatory]] planned for launch in 2028 as the fourth medium-class mission of the [[European Space Agency]]'s [[Cosmic Vision]] programme. The mission is aimed at observing at least 1,000 known [[exoplanets]] using the [[Methods of detecting exoplanets#Transit photometry|transit method]], studying and characterising the planets' chemical composition and thermal structures.
== Mission == ARIEL will observe 1,000 planets orbiting distant stars and make the first large-scale survey of the chemistry of [[Extraterrestrial atmosphere|exoplanet atmospheres]].<ref>[https://ariel-spacemission.eu/press-releases/ ARIEL Space Mission - A Candidate for the ESA M4 Mission]. 2018.</ref> The objective is to answer fundamental questions about how [[Nebular hypothesis|planetary systems form]] and evolve.<ref name='Tinetti PI'> [https://arielspacemission.files.wordpress.com/2018/03/ariel-selection-press-release-uk_2018_final_updated.pdf ARIEL exoplanet mission selected as ESA’s next medium-class science mission]. ''World Press''. 20 March 2018.</ref> A [[spectrometer]] will spread the light into a [[spectrum]] ('rainbow') and determine the chemical fingerprints of gases in the planets' atmospheres.<ref name='Tinetti PI'/> This will enable scientists to understand how the chemistry of a planet links to the environment in which it forms, and how its formation and evolution are affected by its parent star.<ref name='Tinetti PI'/> ARIEL will study a diverse population of exoplanets in a wide variety of environments, but it will focus on warm and hot planets in orbits close to their star.<ref name='Tinetti PI'/>
The ARIEL mission was developed by a [[consortium]] of various institutions from eleven member states of the [[European Space Agency]] (ESA),{{efn|These are the [[University of Vienna]] from Austria, the [[KU Leuven|Universities of Leuven]] and [[University of Liège|Liège]] from Belgium, the [[Technical University of Denmark]], the [[French Alternative Energies and Atomic Energy Commission|CEA]], [[CNES]], [[Institut d'astrophysique de Paris|Paris Institute of Astrophysics]], [[Marseille Observatory|Marseille]], [[Côte d'Azur Observatory|Côte d'Azur]], and [[Paris Observatory|Paris Observatories]] in France, the [[Max Planck Society]] and [[University of Hamburg]] in Germany, [[Netherlands Institute for Space Research|SRON]] and the [[University of Amsterdam|Universities of Amsterdam]], [[Delft University of Technology|Delft]], and [[Leiden University|Leiden]] in the Netherlands, the [[Space Research Centre of Polish Academy of Sciences]], the [[European Space Astronomy Centre|CAB]], [[Institut de Ciències de l'Espai|Institute of Space Sciences]] and the [[Instituto de Astrofísica de Canarias|Institute of Astrophysics of the Canary Islands]] in Spain, [[University of Bern]] in Switzerland, and the [[UK Astronomy Technology Centre|ATC]] and the [[Cardiff University|Universities of Cardiff]], [[University of Exeter|Exeter]], [[University of Hertfordshire|Hertfordshire]], [[Keele University|Keele]], [[University of Leicester|Leicester]], [[University of London|London]], and [[University of Oxford|Oxford]] in the United Kingdom.<ref name="ariel-1">{{cite web|author1=[[European Space Agency]], ARIEL Science Study Team|title=(ESA/SCI(2017)2) ARIEL – Atmospheric Remote‐sensing Infrared Exoplanet Large‐survey|url=https://arielspacemission.files.wordpress.com/2017/05/sci-2017-2-ariel.pdf|website=ARIEL Science Mission|publisher=ARIEL Consortium|accessdate=22 March 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180322214222/https://arielspacemission.files.wordpress.com/2017/05/sci-2017-2-ariel.pdf|archivedate=22 March 2018|language=en-GB|date=March 2017}}</ref>}} and international contributors from four countries.{{efn|These are the [[Université de Montréal|Universities of Montréal]] and [[University of Toronto|Toronto]] in Canada, the [[Earth-Life Science Institute|ELSI]], [[Tokyo Institute of Technology]], and [[Osaka University]] in Japan, the [[National Autonomous University of Mexico]], and [[California Institute of Technology|Caltech]], the [[Lunar and Planetary Laboratory|LPL]] and [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory|JPL]], [[Lunar and Planetary Institute]], and Universities of [[Arizona State University|Arizona State]], [[University of Chicago|Chicago]], and [[Princeton University|Princeton]] in the United States.<ref name="ariel-1"/>}} The project is led by [[principal investigator]] Professor [[Giovanna Tinetti]] of the [[University College London]],<ref name="bbc-1">{{cite web|last1=Amos|first1=Jonathan|title=Discovering the nature of planets|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/av/science-environment-43477355/discovering-the-nature-of-planets|website=[[BBC News]]|publisher=[[BBC|British Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=22 March 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180322221849/http://www.bbc.com/news/av/science-environment-43477355/discovering-the-nature-of-planets|archivedate=22 March 2018|language=en-GB|date=20 March 2018}}</ref><ref name="nature-1">{{cite web|last1=Gibney|first1=Elizabeth|title=First space mission dedicated to exoplanet atmospheres gets green light|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-018-03445-5|website=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]|publisher=[[Nature Publishing Group]] ([[Holtzbrinck Publishing Group]])|accessdate=22 March 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180322221844/https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-018-03445-5|archivedate=22 March 2018|language=en-GB|date=20 March 2018}}</ref> who had previously led the unsuccessful ''[[EChO|Exoplanet Characterisation Observatory]]'' (''EcHO'') proposal for the M3 Cosmic Vision launch slot.<ref name="nature-2">{{cite journal|last1=Gewin|first1=Virginia|title=Turning point: Giovanna Tinetti|journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]|date=14 April 2011|volume=472|issue=7342|pages=251–251|doi=10.1038/nj7342-251a|url=https://www.nature.com/naturejobs/science/articles/10.1038/nj7342-251a|accessdate=22 March 2018|publisher=[[Nature Publishing Group]] ([[Holtzbrinck Publishing Group]]|issn=1476-4687|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180322221840/https://www.nature.com/naturejobs/science/articles/10.1038/nj7342-251a|archive-date=22 March 2018}}</ref><ref name="astronomy-1">{{cite web|author1=[[European Space Agency]]|title=ESA selects planet-hunting PLATO mission|url=http://www.astronomy.com/news/2014/02/esa-selects-planet-hunting-plato-mission|website=[[Astronomy (magazine)|Astronomy]]|publisher=[[Kalmbach Publishing]]|accessdate=22 March 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180322221837/http://www.astronomy.com/news/2014/02/esa-selects-planet-hunting-plato-mission|archivedate=22 March 2018|language=en-US|date=21 February 2014}}</ref> Operations of the mission and the spacecraft will be handled jointly by ESA and the consortium behind the mission's development, through a coordinated Instrument Operations and Science Data Centre (IOSDC).<ref name="ariel-1"/> A Mission Operations Centre (MOC) will be set up at the [[European Space Operations Centre]] (ESOC) in [[Darmstadt]], Germany, while a concurrent ARIEL Science Operations Centre (SOC) will be set up at the [[European Space Astronomy Centre]] (ESAC) near [[Madrid]], Spain.<ref name="ariel-1"/> The MOC will be responsible for the spacecraft itself, while the SOC will be responsible for archiving mission data and scientific data downlinked from the spacecraft. The IOSDC will help develop results from the mission based on data received by the SOC.<ref name="ariel-1"/>
In August 2017 [[NASA]] conditionally selected ''Contribution to ARIEL Spectroscopy of Exoplanets'' (''CASE'') as a [[Explorers_program#Missions_of_Opportunity_(MO)_and_international_missions|Partner Mission of Opportunity]], pending the result of ESA's Cosmic Vision selection.<ref name="JPL">{{cite web|title=NASA Selects Proposals to Study Galaxies, Stars, Planets|url=https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=6918|publisher=[[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]]|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref> Under the proposal NASA would provide two [[fine guidance sensor]]s for the ARIEL spacecraft in return for the participation of US scientists in the mission.<ref name="COPAG">{{cite web|title=FINESSE and ARIEL + CASE: Dedicated Transit Spectroscopy Missions for the Post-TESS Era|url=https://cor.gsfc.nasa.gov/copag/AAS_Jan2018/bean_finesse_case.pdf||publisher= NASA Cosmic Origins Program Analysis Group (COPAG)|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref>
== Spacecraft == The design of the ARIEL spacecraft is based on that intended for the ''[[EChO|Exoplanet Characterisation Observatory]]'' (''EChO'') mission, and has heritage from the thermal design of ''[[Planck (spacecraft)|Planck]]''.<ref name="ariel-1"/><ref name="esa-1">{{cite web|author1=Science & Technology Portal staff|title=ARIEL: Spacecraft|url=http://sci.esa.int/ariel/59800-spacecraft/|website=ESA Science & Technology Portal|publisher=[[European Space Agency]]|accessdate=22 March 2018|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20180322044912/http://sci.esa.int/ariel/59800-spacecraft/|archivedate=22 March 2018|language=en-GB|date=20 March 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The body of the spacecraft is split into two distinct modules known as the Service Module (SVM) and the Payload Module (PLM). The SVM is shaped as a 'sandwich' structure, consisting of three [[aluminum]] V-Grooves and three pairs of low conductivity [[Fiberglass|fibreglass]] bipod struts supporting the PLM.<ref name="esa-1"/> A basic horizontal telescope configuration is used for the PLM itself, housing all of the spacecraft's scientific instruments and its oval 1.1 × 0.7 metre (3.6 × 2.3 feet) [[primary mirror]].<ref name="esa-1"/><ref name="ariel-2">{{cite web |author1=ARIEL Space Mission staff |title=Facts & Figures |url=https://ariel-spacemission.eu/ariel-media/ |website=ARIEL Space Mission |publisher=ARIEL Consortium |accessdate=22 March 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180322054107/https://ariel-spacemission.eu/ariel-media/ |archivedate=22 March 2018 |language=en-GB}}</ref> At launch, the spacecraft will have a fuelled mass of ~{{convert|1200|kg|lbs}}, and will have a dry mass of ~{{convert|950|kg|lbs}}.<ref name="ariel-2"/> The PLM will account for around {{convert|300|kg|lbs}} of that mass.<ref name="ariel-2"/>
=== Telescope === The ARIEL telescope's assembly is an off-axis [[Cassegrain telescope]] followed by a third parabolic mirror to recollimate the beam. The telescope uses an oval 1.1 × 0.7 metre (3.6 × 2.3 feet) [[primary mirror]]; the system has a diffraction limit of about 3 µm, and a focal ratio (f) of 13.4.<ref name='ARIEL Payload'>[http://sci.esa.int/ariel/59801-payload/ ARIEL - Payload]. ESA. 20 March 2018.</ref> The system will acquire images in the visible and near-infrared spectrum.<ref name='ARIEL Payload'/> Its [[infrared spectroscopy|infrared spectroscope]] will operate between 1.95 µm and 7.8 µm, which requires to be passively cooled to a temperature of -218°C (55 K).<ref name="ariel-1"/><ref name='ARIEL Payload'/>
== Launch and trajectory == The ARIEL spacecraft will be launched in mid-2028 by [[Arianespace]]'s 6-2 variant of its [[Ariane 6]] rocket,<ref name="esa-2">{{cite web|author1=Science & Technology Portal staff|title=ESA's next science mission to focus on nature of exoplanets|url=http://sci.esa.int/cosmic-vision/59796-esa-s-next-science-mission-to-focus-on-nature-of-exoplanets/|website=ESA Science & Technology Portal|publisher=[[European Space Agency]]|accessdate=22 March 2018|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20180322105424/http://sci.esa.int/cosmic-vision/59796-esa-s-next-science-mission-to-focus-on-nature-of-exoplanets/|archivedate=22 March 2018|language=en-GB|date=20 March 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="stfc-1">{{cite web|last1=Warren|first1=Melissa|title=UK part of ARIEL exoplanet project selected as ESA's next medium-class science mission|url=https://www.stfc.ac.uk/news/uk-part-of-ariel-exoplanet-project/|website=[[Science and Technology Facilities Council]]|publisher=[[Government of the United Kingdom|Her Majesty's Government]]|accessdate=22 March 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180322105041/https://www.stfc.ac.uk/news/uk-part-of-ariel-exoplanet-project/|archivedate=22 March 2018|language=en-GB|date=20 March 2018}}</ref> currently in development.<ref name="bbc-2">{{cite web|last1=Amos|first1=Jonathan|title=Full thrust on Europe's new Ariane 6 rocket|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-40366736|website=[[BBC News]]|publisher=[[BBC|British Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=22 March 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180322110946/http://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-40366736|archivedate=22 March 2018|language=en-GB|date=22 June 2017}}</ref><ref name="spacenews-1">{{cite web|last1=Pultarova|first1=Tereza|title=ArianeGroup CFO Pierre Godart on Ariane 6 cost savings, micro launchers and reusability|url=http://spacenews.com/arianegroup-cfo-pierre-godart-on-ariane-6-cost-savings-micro-launchers-and-reusability/|website=[[SpaceNews]]|publisher=Pocket Ventures, LLC|accessdate=22 March 2018|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20180322112321/http://spacenews.com/arianegroup-cfo-pierre-godart-on-ariane-6-cost-savings-micro-launchers-and-reusability/|archivedate=22 March 2018|language=en-US|date=25 October 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> It will be launched from the [[Guiana Space Centre]] in [[Kourou]], [[French Guiana]],<ref name="esa-2"/><ref name="stfc-1"/> from the l'Ensemble de Lancement Ariane 4 (Ariane Launch Area 4) being purpose-built for future Ariane 6 launches.<ref name="euronews-1">{{cite web|author1=''Euronews'' staff|title=Race to build Ariane 6 rocket launch pad|url=http://www.euronews.com/2017/12/14/race-to-build-ariane-6-rocket-launch-pad|website=[[Euronews]]|publisher=[[Naguib Sawiris|Media Globe Networks]] and [[NBCUniversal]]|accessdate=22 March 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180322110944/http://www.euronews.com/2017/12/14/race-to-build-ariane-6-rocket-launch-pad|archivedate=22 March 2018|language=en-GB|date=14 December 2017}}</ref> ARIEL will be launched to the L<sub>2</sub> [[Lagrangian point]], in a position located at a distance of {{convert|1,500,000|km|mi}} from [[Earth]],<ref name="esa-2"/> where it will benefit from the planet's blockage of light from the [[Sun]] to "maximise" the potential for exoplanet targets.<ref name="stfc-1"/>
== See also == {{Portal|Astronomy|Spaceflight}} * [[CHEOPS]] and [[PLATO (spacecraft)|PLATO]] – Cosmic Vision exoplanetology missions * [[Fast Infrared Exoplanet Spectroscopy Survey Explorer|FINESSE]] – NASA equivalent to ARIEL * [[List of space telescopes]] {{Clear}}
== References == '''Notes''' {{Notelist|2}} '''Citations''' {{Reflist}}
== External links == * ''[https://ariel-spacemission.eu ARIEL]'' official website * ''[http://sci.esa.int/ariel/ ARIEL]'' at the European Space Agency

{{Infobox television | show_name = Adele at the BBC | image = Adele - Adele at the BBC (Official Title Card).png | image_upright = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | show_name_2 = | genre = | creator = | based_on = <!-- {{based on|work|author}} --> | developer = | writer = | screenplay = | story = | director = | creative_director = | presenter = [[Graham Norton]] | starring = [[Adele]] | judges = <!-- Organized by broadcast credit order, with new main cast added to the end of the list --> | voices = <!-- Organized by broadcast credit order, with new main cast added to the end of the list --> | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | num_seasons = <!-- Or num_series. Increment when new seasons/series begin. See template documentation for more info.--> | num_episodes = <!-- Value is incremented when new episodes air. See template documentation for more info.--> | list_episodes = | executive_producer = Guy Freeman | producer = Anouk Fontaine, Lawrie Jordan, Daniel Brookes | editor = | location = London, United Kingdom | cinematography = | camera = | runtime = 65 minutes | company = | distributor = | budget = | network = [[BBC One]] | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_run = <!-- The nation in which the series first aired, if different from country parameter --> | first_aired = {{Start date|2015|11|20|df=yes}} | last_aired = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = <!-- To be used only for remakes, spin-offs, and adaptations --> | website = http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b06pyvw0 | website_title = Adele at the BBC | production_website = | production_website_title = }}
'''''Adele at the BBC''''' (also known as '''''Adele Live in London''''' to some international markets)<ref>{{cite news|first=Erin|last=Strecker|title=BBC America Will Air 'Adele: Live in London' Special|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/6859174/adele-live-in-london-special-bbc-america|date=January 28, 2016|accessdate=March 30, 2016}}</ref><ref name="titleireland">{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/ten/blogs/television/2015/1111/741117-on-the-box-weekly-tv-preview/ |title=On the Box – Weekly TV Preview |work=RTÉ Ten |publisher=RTÉ |date=11 November 2015 |accessdate=18 March 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160329102717/http://www.rte.ie/ten/blogs/television/2015/1111/741117-on-the-box-weekly-tv-preview/ |archivedate=29 March 2016 |df= }}</ref> is a television special featuring British singer and songwriter [[Adele]], hosted by [[Graham Norton]] for [[BBC One]], and which was recorded at [[The London Studios]], London, United Kingdom<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/london_studios/status/662698990043922432 |title=The London Studios on Twitter: "We are so excited for ADELE AT THE BBC which was filmed in our studios earlier this week." |publisher=Twitter.com |date=2015-11-06 |accessdate=2015-11-23}}</ref> on 2 November 2015. The programme featured Adele and her live band performing songs from her repertoire and third studio album ''[[25 (Adele album)|25]]'' (2015), as well as other songs from her other two albums, ''[[19 (Adele album)|19]]'' (2008) and ''[[21 (Adele album)|21]]'' (2011), alongside Adele being interviewed by Norton.
The show featured the first public performance of her single "[[Hello (Adele song)|Hello]]" and two other tracks from ''25'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/business/6769249/bob-shennan-bbc-director-of-music-adeles-exclusive-tv |title=Bob Shennan, BBC Director of Music, Discusses Adele's Beeb-Exclusive TV Comeback |work=Billboard |date= |accessdate=2015-11-23}}</ref> and her first television appearance since the [[85th Academy Awards]] (2013).<ref name=BBC>{{cite news|title=BBC Music presents 'Adele at the BBC'|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/articles/4LkVwJFf6lNYBCzJNpn3kkx/bbc-music-presents-adele-at-the-bbc|accessdate=27 October 2015|publisher=BBC}}</ref> It also featured sketch sections, where Adele interacted with her fans, including a group of Adele impersonators.<ref name="telegraph1">{{cite web|author=Bernadette McNulty |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/music/artists/adele-graham-norton-bbc/ |title=Adele at the BBC, with Graham Norton |publisher=Telegraph.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-11-23}}</ref> The show was broadcast on Friday 20 November on BBC One from 20:30 – 21:35 GMT, the same day that her new album ''25'' was released.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/proginfo/2015/46/adele-at-the-bbc |title=Adele at the BBC |work=BBC Media Centre |publisher=BBC |date=3 November 2015 |accessdate=3 November 2015}}</ref>
Since this was broadcast, numerous other artists have at "''at the BBC''" specials too: [[Michael Bublé]], [[Harry Styles]], [[Sam Smith (singer)|Sam Smith]], [[U2]] and [[Ariana Grande]].
==Background== Following the release of ''[[21 (Adele album)|21]]'' (2011), Adele was considering quitting the music industry altogether, stating she thought it was better to "go out on a high". However, in early 2012 she announced she was simply taking a hiatus from music in order to "take time and live a little bit".<ref name="MTV2012">Kaufman, Gil (3 April 2012) [http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1682315/adele-new-single.jhtml "Adele To Release New Single This Year"]. MTV. Retrieved 19 October 2012</ref> Her hiatus from music came to an end after the birth of her first child in October 2012, with Adele stating her son inspired her to start recording music again in order for him to "know what I do".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://radio.com/2015/10/23/adele-admits-almost-quitting-music-after-21-in-interview-with-carson-daly/|title=Adele Admits Almost Quitting Music After ’21’|date=23 October 2015|accessdate=26 October 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160327085021/http://radio.com/2015/10/23/adele-admits-almost-quitting-music-after-21-in-interview-with-carson-daly/|archive-date=2016-03-27|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/474548/adele-gives-birth-to-baby-boy-reports |title=Adele Gives Birth to Baby Boy |newspaper=Billboard |date=21 October 2012}}</ref> In early October, Adele released a letter to her fans through social media addressing the album, in which she confirmed that the album would be titled ''25''.<ref name="billboard1">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6737433/adele-new-album-25-release-letter |title=Adele Finally Shares Update on New Album '25': 'I'm Sorry It Took So Long' |publisher=Billboard |date=2013-02-24 |accessdate=2015-10-22}}</ref>
Adele confirmed that ''25'' would be released on 20 November 2015, and revealed its cover simultaneously on [[Facebook]] and [[Twitter]].<ref name="25 - Time">{{cite news|title=Adele Just Shared the Release Date for New Album 25|url=http://time.com/4083224/adele-25-new-album-release-date/|last=Feeney|first=Nolan|date=22 October 2015|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|accessdate = 23 October 2015}}</ref> On October 2, 2015 numerous music journalists began reporting that it was suspected that Adele had been offered a one-hour TV special on the [[BBC]], however these reports were not confirmed.<ref>{{cite web|author=Mark Yapching |url=http://www.vinereport.com/article/adele.new.album.release.date.singer.to.release.new.album.titled.25.on.november.20.will.be.unveiled.during.one.hour.bbc.special/3352.htm |title=Adele new album release date: one-hour BBC special to show off new album |publisher=Vinereport.com |date=2015-10-02 |accessdate=2015-10-28}}</ref> On 27 October, following the reports [[BBC One]] announced plans for ''Adele at the BBC'', a one-hour special presented by [[Graham Norton]] in which he will talk to Adele about her new album.<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-34638507 |title=Adele to film BBC One special with Graham Norton |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=27 October 2015 |accessdate=27 October 2015}}</ref> The show was recorded before a live audience on 2 November and was transmitted on BBC One on 20 November 2015.<ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref name="autogenerated2"/> Tickets for the live show, which were free, were made available through a lottery style system and were requested by the public.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://mic.com/articles/127479/adele-bbc-special-taping-and-ticket-info-for-adele-live-in-london |title=Adele BBC Special: Taping and Ticket Info for 'Adele Live in London' |publisher=Mic |date=28 October 2015 |accessdate=3 November 2015}}</ref>
The show marks the first live performances by Adele of three songs from the album ''25'': "[[Hello (Adele song)|Hello]]", "[[When We Were Young (Adele song)|When We Were Young]]", and "[[Million Years Ago (song)|Million Years Ago]]".<ref name=Reveal>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.reveal.co.uk/showbiz-celeb-gossip/news/a677940/adele-at-the-bbc-review-honest-funny-and-spectacular.html |title=Adele at the BBC review: honest, funny and spectacular – Celebrity News News |publisher=Reveal |date=2015-11-18 |accessdate=2015-11-23}}</ref>
==Songs performed== #"[[Rolling in the Deep]]"<ref name=Reveal/> #"[[Hello (Adele song)|Hello]]"<ref name=Reveal/> #"[[Rumour Has It (Adele song)|Rumour Has It]]"<ref name=Reveal/> #"[[Skyfall (Adele song)|Skyfall]]"<ref name=Reveal/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/b06pyvw0/adele-at-the-bbc |title=BBC iPlayer – Adele at the BBC |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2015-11-23}}</ref> #"[[Million Years Ago (song)|Million Years Ago]]"<ref name="telegraph1"/> #"[[Hometown Glory]]"<ref name="telegraph1"/> #"[[When We Were Young (Adele song)|When We Were Young]]"<ref name=Reveal/> #"[[Someone like You (Adele song)|Someone like You]]"<ref name=Reveal/>
*"[[Make You Feel My Love]]" is also featured, as part of a sketch in which Adele is seen auditioning for a television special alongside a roomful of impersonators, posing as a nanny named "Jenny", before appearing on stage to surprise them.<ref>{{cite news|last=Reid |first=Joe |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2015/11/adele-surprised-impersonators-bbc |title=Adele Surprised a Room Full of Adele Impersonators, Leading to Tears |publisher=Vanity Fair |date=21 December 2015 |accessdate=11 February 2016}}</ref>
==Broadcasting== The programme was broadcast on 20 November 2015 on BBC One, the same day that her new album ''[[25 (Adele album)|25]]'' was released.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> BBC One aired an extended version of the programme on New Year's Day 2016, including further footage of the sketch in which Adele posed as Jenny. By 4 December 2015, footage of the scenes had been viewed 37 million times on the BBC's [[YouTube]] site, making it the most watched programme on there.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fletcher |first=Harry |url=http://www.digitalspy.com/music/news/a776248/adele-just-keeps-breaking-records-as-her-lookalike-sketch-racks-up-record-37-million-views-for-bbc-youtube/ |title=Adele just keeps breaking records, as her lookalike sketch racks up record 37 million views for BBC YouTube |publisher=Digital Spy |date=4 December 2015 |accessdate=11 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Doran |first=Sarah |url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2015-12-04/adele-adds-new-uk-tour-dates-as-her-bbc-impersonator-clip-breaks-youtube-record |title=Adele tickets: new tour dates announced for London's 02 Arena |publisher= |work=Radio Times |date=4 December 2015 |accessdate=11 February 2016}}</ref>
Prior to the show's announcement [[BBC Worldwide]] had secured numerous pre-sales for the one-off event, with broadcasters in Belgium, Canada, the Netherlands and Spain. The BBC secured deals with [[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroeporganisatie|VRT]], [[CTV Television Network|CTV]], [[NPO 3]] and [[Canal+ (Spanish TV channel)|Canal Plus]] respectively for hour-long BBC One show, BBC Worldwide offered international broadcasters the choice of buying the original 60-minute version of the show, hosted by Graham Norton and with his interview with Adele, or a 45-minute performance-only edit.<ref>{{cite web|author=Hannah Gannagé-Stewart |url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/news/bbcw-scores-adele-pre-sales/5095988.article |title=BBCW scores Adele pre-sales | News | Broadcast |publisher=Broadcastnow.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-10-28}}</ref>
In Ireland the programme was simulcast on [[RTÉ2]], where it aired as ''Adele Live in London''.<ref name="titleireland"/> ==Reception== The programme received a five-star review from ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', which described it as 'a stroke of genius' and 'old-fashioned, generous, fun and moving.'.<ref name="telegraph1"/> Overnight viewing figures indicated that the one-off special was viewed by 4.54 million viewers, giving the programme a 19.8% audience share in that evening's 8.30pm timeslot.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hegarty |first=Tasha |url=http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/news/a774818/uk-tv-ratings-im-a-celebrity-attracts-7-million-viewers-on-friday-night/ |title=UK TV Ratings: I'm a Celebrity attracts 7 million viewers on Friday night |publisher=Digital Spy |date=21 November 2015 |accessdate=4 March 2016}}</ref> Consolidated figures show that the special was watched by a total of 6.36 million viewers and was the 11th most watched programme on BBC one during its week of broadcast.
==See also== * [[2015 in British television]]
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== *{{BBC programme}}
{{Adele}}
[[Category:2015 television specials]] [[Category:Adele]] [[Category:BBC Television programmes]] [[Category:British television specials]] [[Category:Music television specials]]

{{Infobox military conflict |conflict=Battle of Bi |partof= |image=Battle of Bi.jpg |caption=Battle of Bi |date= 597 BC |place= Bi, near modern day [[Xingyang]], [[Henan Province]] |casus= |territory= |result=Chu victory, hegemony of [[King Zhuang of Chu]] |combatant1=[[Chu (state)|Chu]]
[[Zheng (state)|Zheng]] |combatant2=[[Jin (Chinese state)|Jin]] |commander1= King Zhuang of Chu, [[Sunshu Ao]], [[Zi Zhong]], [[Zi Fan]] |commander2= [[Xun Linfu]], [[Shi Hui (Spring and Autumn period)|Shi Hui]], [[Zhao Shuo]] |strength1=Unknown |strength2=Unknown |casualties1=Unknown |casualties2=Unknown }} The '''Battle of Bi''' ({{zh|t=邲之戰|p=Bì zhī Zhàn}}) was fought during the [[Spring and Autumn period]] in 597 BC, between the major states of [[Chu (state)|Chǔ]] and [[Jin (Chinese state)|Jìn]]. Occurring three and a half decades after the [[Battle of Chengpu]], where Jin decisively defeated Chu, the battle was a major victory for Chu, cementing the position of its ruler King Zhuang as a hegemon among the states of the Zhou Dynasty. ==Background== The states of Jin and Chu were both among the most powerful of their time, but while Jin was considered a legitimate Zhou state in terms of culture and lineage, the state of Chu - whose territory encompassed many non-Chinese cultures in the middle [[Yangtze River]] - was considered a half-civilised state at best. Jin-Chu rivalry last came to a head with the decisive defeat of Chu at the Battle of Chengpu, where [[Duke Wen of Jin]] became hegemon among the states; after the death of Duke Wen, Chu attempted to reassert its position with northern campaigns, but the presence of Zhao Dun as premier of Jin rendered them unwilling to risk direct conflict. This situation would change dramatically with the death of Zhao Dun in 601 BC, as well as the death of [[Duke Cheng of Jin]] the following year, followed by that of Zhao's successor [[Xi Que]] ([[:zh:郤缺|郤缺]]) in 598 BC. King Zhuang made use of the resulting instability among the Jin leadership, and personally led a campaign northward. ==Campaign== King Zhuang targeted the state of [[Zheng (state)|Zheng]], which was an ally of Jin, and successfully forced Zheng to switch allegiance to Chu. Meanwhile, Xun Linfu, the new commander of the Jin armies, led his forces to relieve Zheng, only to learn of the surrender of Zheng en route, while camped along the northern bank of the [[Yellow River]]. This created a rift among the Jin commanders, about whether to meet the Chu forces in battle. At the same time, Chu's armies retreated by 30 ''li'' and decamped, awaiting the Jin offensive. ==Battle== Xun Linfu, after hearing of Zheng's switch of allegiance, was in favour of retreating; however, his adjutant [[Xian Hu]], maintaining that it would be cowardly to avoid battle as the hegemonic state, led his own troops across the Yellow River without instructions. This forced the rest of the army to follow suit. Meanwhile, on the Chu side, King Zhuang was intimidated by the presence of the Jin army; even his commander Sunshu Ao was initially in favour of retreat. [[Wu Can (Spring and Autumn period)|Wu Can]], a Chu commander, advised against this, citing the inexperience of Xun Linfu as the supreme commander, the rashness of Xian Hu as adjutant, and the conflict between the Jin commanders. King Zhuang thus resolved to face down the Jin army, even though negotiations for a truce continued between the two armies. The battle began only when two generals from the Jin army, dissatisfied at Xun Linfu's hesitation, decided to provoke the Chu forces. King Zhuang personally pursued the generals; Xun Linfu sent a force to escort the two generals back to Jin lines, but the rolling dust from this relief force was mistaken as a general advance by the Jin army. Fearing that the king could be cut off by the army, Sunshu Ao immediately ordered a general advance from the Chu army; this unexpected attack overwhelmed Jin forces, which then collapsed and were routed. King Zhuang, upon winning the battle, led his generals to water their horses from the Yellow River; a request to pursue and destroy the remnant forces was rebuffed on the grounds that, with the humiliation of Chengpu avenged, there was no need for more slaughter. ==References== *{{citation |last=Peers |first=C.J. |year=1990 |title=Ancient Chinese Armies: 1500-200 BC |publisher=Osprey Publishing }} {{coord missing|Henan}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bi, Battle Of}} [[Category:595 BC]] [[Category:6th-century BC conflicts]] [[Category:Battles involving the Zhou dynasty]] [[Category:6th century BC in China]] [[Category:Chu (state)]] [[Category:Jin (Chinese state)]]

'''Cinemagic''' is an international children's [[film festival]] in [[Belfast]], [[United Kingdom|UK]], and in [[Dublin]], Ireland, founded in 1988 that bills itself as the ''World Screen Festival'' for [[youth|young people]]. The organisation is a company [[Limited By Guarantee]] and a [[registered charity]].
Cinemagic's patrons include [[Dermot O'Leary]], [[Brian Cox (actor)|Brian Cox]] and [[Julian Fellowes]].
== See also == *[[Northern Ireland Screen]]
==External links== *[http://www.cinemagic.org.uk/ Official site]
[[Category:Culture in Belfast]] [[Category:Film festivals in Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Children's film festivals]]
{{film-festival-stub}}

'''CoffeeCon''' is the only coffee festival for enthusiasts. Unlike coffee festivals for the coffee industry this festival is for the end user. The another difference is its coffee university typically offering over 30 different coffee classes. CoffeeCon travels to major coffee cities in the United States. It was created by coffee author and video producer Kevin Sinnott{{cite web|url=http://townhall.com/columnists/johnstossel/2005/05/04/coffee_talk/page/full|title=Coffee talk|work=townhall.com|accessdate=16 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1994-06-05/features/9406050031_1_gourmet-coffees-roast-percolator|title=The Real Mr. Coffee|work=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=16 October 2014}} who wrote the book ''The Art & Craft of Coffee'' and produced a how to video called ''Coffee Brewing Secrets''. ==History== While working on specialized projects, Sinnott noticed several industry B-to-B coffee events such as the [[Specialty Coffee Association of America]] and the [[National Coffee Association]] and that some local coffee shops were holding brewing seminars but there were simply no large scale festivals exclusively for coffee consumers. He decided to turn his book and his video into a live event. He created CoffeeCon as a place where coffee enthusiasts could taste samples from regional coffee roasters side-by-side, learn about coffee from national and local coffee experts by attend coffee topic classes on almost every brewing method. He hosts the event and calls it a coffee meet-up. The first CoffeeCon was on February 25, 2012 started with a grant for the local tourism commission in Warrenville, IL.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20120223/news/702239887/|title=Learn how to brew the perfect cup of Joe at CoffeeCon in Warrenville|work=Daily Herald|accessdate=16 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2012/02/14/all-means-of-brewing-to-be-on-display-at-coffeecon/|title=All Means Of Brewing To Be On Display At CoffeeCon « CBS Chicago|publisher=|accessdate=16 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://sprudge.com/consumer-convention-in-warrenville-illinois-coffeecon-2012.html|title=Consumer Convention: CoffeeCON 2012|work=[[Sprudge]]|accessdate=16 October 2014}} It attracted over 1,000 consumers. The second event was held May 4, 2013 again in Warrenville, IL {{cite web|url=http://chicagotonight.wttw.com/2013/05/03/weekend-events-around-town-53-55|title=Weekend Events Around Town: 5/3 - 5/5|work=Chicago Tonight - WTTW|accessdate=16 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.coffeedetective.com/coffeecon-2013-review.html|title=My review of the CoffeeCON 2013 event for coffee lovers.|work=Coffee Detective|accessdate=16 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://theshot.coffeeratings.com/2013/05/coffeecon-2013/|title=CoffeeCON 2013 - Espresso News and Reviews - TheShot.coffeeratings.com|publisher=|accessdate=16 October 2014}} During 2014 Sinnott decided it was time to take the show on the road. His first stop was Chicago on April 12, 2014 at the Zhou B Art Center.{{cite web|url=http://articles.redeyechicago.com/2014-04-10/entertainment/49041759_1_saturday-sunday-logan-theatre-samples|title=Things to do in Chicago on April 11, 12, 13, 2014|work=RedEye Chicago|accessdate=16 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.brokehipster.com/2014/04/16/coffeecon-2014-chicago/|title=CoffeeCon 2014- Chicago - BrokeHipster.com - Chicago's Best Source For Free Drinks, Free Food and Free Culture|publisher=|accessdate=16 October 2014}} He wanted to add art elements to enhance the coffeehouse flavor of the event as well as a Writer's Roundtable Panel to discuss the topic of new media writing. Next stop was San Francisco on July 26, 2014 at Terra Galleries.{{cite web|url=http://www.sfbg.com/pixel_vision/2014/08/04/all-buzz-report-coffeecon-san-francisco|title=All the buzz: a report from CoffeeCon San Francisco|publisher=|accessdate=16 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.7x7.com/arts-culture/weeks-hottest-events-pedalfest-coffeecon-sf-marathon-more|title=This Week's Hottest Events: Pedalfest, CoffeeCon, SF Marathon, & More|publisher=|accessdate=16 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://sprudge.com/coffeecon-san-francisco.html|title=20 Things That Verily Happened At CoffeeCon San Francisco|author=Leif Haven|work=Sprudge|accessdate=16 October 2014}} CoffeeCon LA was on November 8, 2014 and was held at the historic [[Mack Sennett]] Studios in Silver Lake. Mack Sennett's real name was Michael Sinnott. He was a silent movie director and produced the KeyStone Cops. Kevin Sinnott stated "It was like a coming home. I believe Mack would be proud that another Sinnott was work at his studio. CoffeeCon sited Mack Sennett Studios historic connection with CoffeeCon's founder. CoffeeCon NYC was on March 7, 2015. CoffeeCon Chicago occurred on July 25, 2015. On January 27–28, 2017, CoffeeCon held its first ever, multi-day convention. The event was held at the Seattle Center Armory, in [[Seattle, Washington]].{{cite web|url=https://www.eventbrite.com/e/coffeecon-seattle-2017-tickets-19325213233#|title=CoffeeCon Seattle 2017|author=Leif Haven|work=EventBrite.com|accessdate=February 1, 2018}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Event ! Date ! Location ! Approximate
attendance |- | "CoffeeCon 2012" | February 25, 2012{{cite web|url=http://wecoqa.bunn.com/home-connect/connect-us/home-products-blog?date=2012-03|title=Blog - BUNN® Home Product Insider Video- trifecta® MB at CoffeeCon 2012|date=23 May 2014|publisher=Wecoqa.Bunn.com|accessdate=February 1, 2018}} | [[Warrenville, Illinois]] | 1,000+{{cite web|url=https://gardencollage.com/nourish/farm-to-table/the-buzz-reporting-from-coffeecon-los-angeles/|title=Grow Your Own Buzz: Reporting From Los Angeles CoffeeCon|publisher=GardenCollage.com|accessdate=February 1, 2018}} |- | "CoffeeCon 2013" | May 4, 2013 | Warrenville, Illinois | Approximately 2,000{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/naperville-sun/community/chi-ugc-article-coffeecon-2013-the-consumer-coffee-event-re-2013-03-28-story.html|title=CoffeeCON 2013 – The Consumer Coffee Event Returns|publisher=ChicagoTribune.com|accessdate=February 1, 2018}} |- | "CoffeeCon 2014 - Chicago" | April 12, 2014 | [[Zhou brothers#Art and Life in the United States|Zhou B Art Center]]
[[Chicago, Illinois]] | |- | "CoffeeCon 2014 - San Francisco" | July 26, 2014 | Terra Galleries
[[San Francisco, California]] | 700+{{cite web|url=http://www.coffee-con.com/coffeecon-san-francisco-reflections/|title=CoffeeCon San Francisco Reflections|publisher=Coffee-con.com|accessdate=February 1, 2018}} |- | "CoffeeCon 2014 - [[Los Angeles]]" | November 8, 2014{{cite web|url=http://www.lamag.com/digestblog/hot-sips-coffeecon-2014-5-predictions-future-brew/|title=CoffeeCON 2013 – The Consumer Coffee Event Returns|publisher=LAMag.com|accessdate=February 1, 2018}} | Mack Sennett Studios
[[Silverlake, California]] | |- | "CoffeeCon 2015 - New York City" | March 7, 2015{{cite web|url=https://www.tasteusa.com/event/coffee-con-nyc-2015|title=Coffee Con NYC 2015|publisher=TasteUSA.com|accessdate=February 1, 2018}} | Broad Street Ballroom
[[New York City, New York]] | |- | "CoffeeCon 2015 - Chicago" | July 25, 2015{{cite web|url=https://chicagotonight.wttw.com/2015/07/23/weekend-events-around-town-july-24-26|title=Weekend Events Around Town: July 24–26|publisher=ChicagoTonight.wttw.com|accessdate=February 1, 2018}} | Morgan Manufacturing
Chicago, Illinois | |- | "CoffeeCon 2016 - Los Angeles" | January 30, 2016{{cite web|url=http://www.coffee-con.com/announcement-coffeecon-la-2016-saturday-january-30-buy-tickets-now/|title=Announcement: CoffeeCon LA 2016, Saturday, January 30. Buy Tickets now!|publisher=Coffee-Con.com|accessdate=February 1, 2018}} | Magic Box LA at The Reef
Los Angeles, California | |- | "CoffeeCon 2016 - New York City" | June 4, 2016{{cite web|url=http://www.coffee-con.com/my-personal-guide-to-coffeecon-ny/|title=My Personal Guide to CoffeeCon NY|publisher=Coffee-Con.com|accessdate=February 1, 2018}} | Industry City
[[Brooklyn|Brooklyn, New York City]] | 1,000+{{cite web|url=http://theareligroup.com/blog/coffeecon/|title=CoffeeCon 2016: A Community of Connoisseurs|publisher=TheareliGroup.com|accessdate=February 1, 2018}} |- | "CoffeeCon 2017 - Seattle" | January 27–28, 2017 | Seattle Center Armory
Seattle, Washington | |- | "CoffeeCon 2017 - Los Angeles" | February 25–26, 2017{{cite web|url=https://www.eventbrite.com/e/coffeecon-la-2017-tickets-31460620563#|title=CoffeeCon LA 2017|publisher=EventBrite.com|accessdate=February 1, 2018}} | Magic Box LA at The Reef
Los Angeles, California | |- | "CoffeeCon 2017 - Chicago" | October 7–8, 2017{{cite web|url=https://www.eventbrite.com/e/coffeecon-chicago-2017-tickets-35362896375#|title=CoffeeCon Chicago 2017|publisher=EventBrite.com|accessdate=February 1, 2018}} | Revel Space
Chicago, Illinois | |} ==Upcoming conventions== Four cities are scheduled to host CoffeeCon in 2018: Los Angeles,{{cite web|url=http://www.welikela.com/event/coffeecon-the-reef-2018/|title=CoffeeCon 2018 at The Reef in Downtown L.A.|work=WeLikeLA.com|accessdate=January 31, 2018}} New York,{{cite web|url=https://www.perfectdailygrind.com/specialty-coffee-event/coffeecon-2018-2/|title=CoffeeCon New York 2018|work=PerfectDailyGrind.com|accessdate=January 31, 2018}} Seattle{{cite web|url=https://www.thestranger.com/events/25638688/coffeecon-seattle-2018|title=CoffeeCon Seattle 2018|work=TheStranger.com|accessdate=January 31, 2018}} and Chicago.{{cite web|url=https://www.perfectdailygrind.com/specialty-coffee-event/coffeecon-2018-4/|title=CoffeeCon Chicago 2018|work=PerfectDailyGrind.com|accessdate=January 31, 2018}} ==Features of the convention== [[George Howell (entrepreneur)|George Howell]] and Kenneth Davids teach a special Taste Like An Expert seminar that teaches consumers the vocabulary of [[Coffee cupping|coffee tasting]] and trains the palate of the attendees. Coffee growers are invited to teach about coffee sustainability. Popular classes include grinding, water, hand pour methods and Turkish Coffee. Coffeemaker designers such as [[Alan Adler]] the inventor of the [[AeroPress]] and Joe Behm the inventor of the Brazen coffeemaker conduct classes on how to use their coffeemakers.http://www.fastcompany.com/3027638/creation-stories/the-aeropress-inventors-secret-to-a-perfect-cup-of-coffeehttp://baristamagazine.com/blog/?p=9217 Home roasting hobbyists are given space to give roasting demos. The Future of Coffee panel was a new first at CoffeeCon 2014 San Francisco and is present at every CoffeeCon. ==References== {{portal|Coffee}} {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.coffee-con.com/ CoffeeCon - Main Website] *[https://twitter.com/CoffeeConEvent Twitter page] {{Coffee}} [[Category:Coffee culture]] [[Category:Food and drink festivals]]

page.title: Countries affected by the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami

revision.comment: replace image with one in English and tweak caption
revision.text:
{{Update|date=December 2016}} {{refimprove|date=October 2017}} [[File:US Navy 050102-N-9593M-040 A village near the coast of Sumatra lays in ruin after the Tsunami that struck South East Asia.jpg|thumb|A village near the coast of [[Sumatra]] lies in ruins|200px]] [[File:2004 Indian Ocean earthquake - affected countries.png|thumb|Countries directly affected by the earthquake and tsunami]] This article lists the '''countries affected by the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami|2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and the resulting tsunami]]''' in alphabetical order – for detailed information about each country affected by the [[earthquake]] and [[tsunami]], see their individual articles. Countries with a smaller number of casualties, as well as those that lost citizens who were travelling abroad, are listed further on in the article.
==Countries suffering major casualties and damage== {{Unreferenced section|date=September 2015}} [[File:2004 Tsunami casualties and damage.png|thumb|upright=1.5|{{legend|red|severe damage and loss of life}}{{legend|orange|moderate damage and some loss of life}}{{legend|yellow|minor damage and no loss of life}}{{legend|dodgerblue|loss of citizens abroad}}]] ; {{flagdeco|IND}} [[Effect of the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake on India|Effect on India]] 10,749 casualties were confirmed on 27 January 2008, most of them in the Indian state of [[Tamil Nadu]]. There were 5,640 people missing, nearly all of them on the [[Andaman and Nicobar Islands]]. In the meantime, the death toll was slashed down by 1,458, and the number of missing by 2,927 on the Andaman and Nicobar Islands.
; {{flagdeco|IDN}} [[Effect of the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake on Indonesia|Effect on Indonesia]] [[Indonesia]]'s Ministry of Health confirmed 131,028 deaths on June 18, 2005, mainly in the northern province [[Aceh]] of the island [[Sumatra]]. Some 37,000 people are missing.
; {{flagdeco|MAS}} [[Effect of the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake on Malaysia|Effect on Malaysia]] Despite its proximity to the incident, [[Malaysia]] escaped the kind of damage that struck countries thousands of miles further away (most of its western coast is shielded by Sumatra). The number of deaths currently stands at 68 with 5 people missing.
; {{flagdeco|Maldives}} [[Effect of the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake on the Maldives|Effect on the Maldives]] In the [[Maldives]], 82 were killed and 26 reported missing and presumed dead.
; {{flagdeco|MYA}} [[Effect of the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake on Myanmar|Effect on Myanmar]] Independent media reports 90 people killed in [[Myanmar]] due to the tsunami. The official death toll is 61. Witnesses in Myanmar estimate up to 600 deaths.
; {{flagdeco|SOM}} [[Effect of the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake on Somalia|Effect on Somalia]] Villages and coastal communities in [[Somalia]], as far as {{convert|4,500|km|mi|abbr=on}} from the epicenter of the earthquake, were swept away and destroyed by the huge waves. 176 people were confirmed dead, 136 were missing and more than 50,000 were displaced.
; {{flagdeco|SRI}} [[Effect of the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake on Sri Lanka|Effect on Sri Lanka]] [[Sri Lanka]]n authorities report 31,229 confirmed deaths, and 4,093 people missing. Other authorities are speaking from 38,940 combined dead and missing people. The south and east coasts were worst hit. Nearly 2,000 of the dead were on the ''[[Queen of the Sea train disaster|Queen of the Sea]]'' holiday train destroyed by the tsunami. One and a half million people were [[displaced person|displaced]] from their homes, and many orphaned or separated from their families.
; {{flagdeco|THA}} [[Effect of the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake on Thailand|Effect on Thailand]] The [[Thailand|Thai]] government reports 5,395 confirmed deaths, 8,457 injuries and 2,817 missing on 20 June 2005. Damage was confined to the six southern provinces facing the [[Andaman Sea]]. The Thai government was keen to point out that the rest of the country was operating normally, and that even some resorts in the south had re-opened.
==Countries suffering some casualties and damage==
{| class="wikitable" |class=nowrap|{{flag|Kenya}} |Waves struck Kenya causing some minor damage. One person was reported to have drowned at Watamu, near [[Mombasa, Kenya|Mombasa]]. |- |class=nowrap|{{flag|Seychelles}} |Three killed, six people missing. A major bridge in [[Victoria, Seychelles|Victoria]] was destroyed. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|{{flag|South Africa}} |One boy died after swimming in the Quinera River at [[Gonubie]], close to [[East London, South Africa|East London]]; an adult dead at Blue Horizon Bay near [[Port Elizabeth]], the furthest point from the [[epicenter]] of the [[earthquake]] where a tsunami-related death was reported. ''General observations:'' Ocean level variance two to three meters outside normal reported in [[KwaZulu-Natal]] and [[Eastern Cape]], and a surge of 1.5 m was observed as far as [[Struisbaai]] in the [[Western Cape]], 8500 km from the epicentre of the earthquake. Some steps were taken in South Africa to warn ports and disaster management centers, although full details are not public.
Large concrete blocks were uprooted in [[East London, South Africa|East London]] harbor, where boats also broke from their moorings. Boats and cars were submerged at the Algoa Bay Yacht Club in [[Port Elizabeth]] harbor. [[Durban]] harbor, Africa's busiest general cargo port and home to the largest and busiest container terminal in the Southern Hemisphere, was closed for some time on 27 December because of unusually strong surges across the entrance channel. |- |class=nowrap|{{flag|Tanzania}} |10 killed, an unknown number of people missing. An oil tanker temporarily ran aground in [[Dar es Salaam]] harbor, damaging an oil pipeline. |- |class=nowrap|{{flag|Yemen}} |One child killed, 40 fishing boats wrecked on [[Socotra]] Island. |}
==Countries suffering damage only== {| class="wikitable" |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|{{flag|Australia}} |Tremors felt along the north-western coast, some minor flooding. Seas off Western Australia reportedly surged between [[Geraldton, Western Australia|Geraldton]], 425 km north of [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]], where several boats were ripped from their moorings, and [[Busselton, Western Australia|Busselton]], 230 km south of Perth, where a father and son in a boat were washed out to sea, but were later rescued. No direct casualties were reported within Australia.
Despite early worries about [[Cocos (Keeling) Islands]], no casualties were reported. People swimming at [[Christmas Island]] were sucked 150m out to sea, but were safely carried back to shore after a pause. At roughly 2 pm that day a single wave surged between 5 and 10 m beyond the normal high water point on Mullaloo Beach, Perth engulfing people. No injuries were reported. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|{{flag|Madagascar}} |Flooding in low-lying coastal districts. No reported casualties. Waves reported variously between 1.6 and 10 meters in height swept through southeastern coastal areas. Over a thousand displaced. Problems were exacerbated by the approach of [[Cyclone Chambo]]. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|{{flag|Mauritius}} |No reports of casualties, however a village in the north of the island was completely submerged. Police issued warnings to bathers to stay out of the water, although this had the opposite effect. Crowds thronging the beaches to watch the phenomenon. Speculation is that coral reefs surrounding much of the island protected the coastline. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|{{flag|Oman}} |Waves hit coastline; no casualties. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|{{flag|Réunion}} |Over 200 boats sunk; damage to port infrastructure estimated at over €500,000. |- |}

Australians were asked to observe a minute's silence at 11.59am. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[Austria]] || 86 Austrians confirmed dead. 85 died in Thailand and one in Sri Lanka. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[Belgium]] || 11 Belgian tourists were confirmed killed in Thailand. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[Brazil]] || The Brazilian diplomat Lys Amayo de Benedek D'Avola and her 10-year-old son died in Phi Phi, Thailand. These are people who had not been in touch with family or friends in the Netherlands for some time before the tsunami, and were filed as "regular missing persons". |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[New Zealand]] || The Foreign Affairs Ministry confirmed 6 New Zealand deaths including an elderly New Zealand-born woman, who held Canadian citizenship. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[Effect of the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake on Norway|Norway]] || 84 people died, among them jazz musician [[Sigurd Køhn]]. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[Philippines]] || Eight people have been reported dead and several were injured, in Phuket, Thailand. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[Poland]] || According to Polish Ministry of Foreign Affairs one Polish tourist died and 12 people were missing. The number of Polish tourists in the affected areas was estimated to be around 2,000. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[Portugal]] || Four reported dead and 4 still missing, from a total of 230 Portuguese thought to be in the region at the time, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[Romania]] || It was initially reported the deaths of two Romanian tourists in Phuket, Thailand, but were later found safe. Is estimated at more than 20 the number of tourists from this country in the affected region, but according to Gaginschi Cristian, representative of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, there is no evidence that any Romanian citizen was affected by the earthquake. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[Russia]] || At least 2 are dead at Phuket, Thailand, and 7 are missing, according to the [[Russian Embassy]]. About 800 Russian tourists were at Phuket alone. Around 250 Russian tourists were in Sri Lanka, all of whom are safe. |- |}
===S – Z=== {| class="wikitable" |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[Singapore]] || 17 dead and 2 missing. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[South Africa]] || ''Casualties in South East Asia:'' 14 South Africans were confirmed dead. All these 14 people died in [[Phuket city|Phuket]] or on the [[Phi Phi Islands]], Thailand. By 26 January 2005 the South African [[Department of International Relations and Cooperation]] had traced the whereabouts of all 2,896 South Africans who were known to have been in South East Asia at the time of the disaster. This includes those confirmed dead.<ref>{{cite web|title=Statement on the Status of Unaccounted and Missing South Africans Following the Tsunami Disaster|url=http://www.dfa.gov.za/docs/2005/asia_quake0126.htm|publisher=South African Department of International Relations and Cooperation|accessdate=3 May 2015|date=25 January 2005}}</ref> |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[South Korea]] || The Ministry of Foreign Affairs reported 17 dead and 3 missing. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[Spain]] || According to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, 2 confirmed dead, both in Khao Lak beach, in Phuket, Thailand. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[Sweden]] || Sweden was likely the most seriously affected country outside of the disaster area. According to Swedish authorities, some 20,000–30,000 citizens were in the tsunami-affected areas at the time, mainly in Thai resorts. 543 persons were reported deceased, and over 1,500 in need of emergency medical help and/or transportation home. 528 bodies had been identified as of May 16, 2006.<ref>{{cite web|title=554 döda och saknade efter tsunamin|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=2145&artikel=600013&date=2004-12-26|publisher=[[Sveriges Radio]]|accessdate=3 May 2015|language=Swedish|date=21 April 2005}}</ref> The Swedish government and especially the minister for foreign affairs [[Laila Freivalds]] was heavily criticized for being slow to act. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[Switzerland]] || Over 2,200 Swiss nationals are estimated to have been in the affected area at the time of disaster. 106 have been confirmed as deceased by the Department of Foreign Affairs, and many more injured; 6 persons are still missing (as of 20 November 2005). |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[Taiwan]] || Three confirmed dead, and many injured. Thirty-five fishing boats from Taiwan in Phuket, Thailand, were beached and damaged; sailors suffered minor injuries. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[Turkey]] || According to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Turkey, one Turkish national killed in [[Phuket Province|Phuket]], Thailand. A plane, which was sent to Maldives by Turkish government to gather all the Turks in the region, returned with only 13 survivors and AKUT, a well-known Turkish search and rescue organisation that was taken there by the plane. Turkish GSM operator [[Turkcell]] announced that signals from 2,500 of its subscribers were received in the area, meaning at least 2,500 Turks were present when the disaster occurred.<ref>{{cite web|title=Deprem bölgesinde 6 Türk kayıp|url=http://arsiv.ntv.com.tr/news/304576.asp|publisher=[[NTV (Turkey)|NTV]]|accessdate=3 May 2015|language=Turkish|date=10 January 2005}}</ref> |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[Ukraine]] || According to The Ukrainian Government, 38 citizens died, including a United Nations official. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[United Kingdom]] || On 26 December over 10,000 British holidaymakers were estimated to have been in the region. There are 149 Britons confirmed dead and 1 missing. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[United States]] || The [[United States Department of State|US State Department]] reports 18 dead and 15 missing, presumed dead. Nine died in Sri Lanka and 24 in Thailand. The State Department was working through a list of 18 unaccounted for as of February 8. It is understood that the U.S./UK military installation at the Indian Ocean island of [[Diego Garcia]] was unaffected by the disaster. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top|[[Vietnam]] || One Vietnamese national confirmed dead and three injured in Thailand. Dozens of Vietnamese shopkeepers in the area were affected. |- |}
==Detection of the tsunami outside the Indian Ocean region== {{Unreferenced section|date=August 2014}} {| class="wikitable" width=100% |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top| [[American Samoa]] |Wave fluctuations of 13 cm from crest to trough at [[Pago Pago]]. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top| [[Antarctica]] |Wave fluctuations of 73 cm due to the tsunami were detected at [[Showa Station (Antarctica)|Showa Station]], {{convert|8900|km|mi|abbr=on}} from the epicenter. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top| [[Brazil]] |Wave fluctuations of 30 cm at [[Rio de Janeiro]]; 60 cm at [[Niterói]]. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top| [[Chile]] |Wave fluctuations of 19 cm from crest to trough at [[Iquique]]. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top| [[Fiji]] |Wave fluctuations of 11 cm at [[Suva]]. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top| [[Russia]] |Wave fluctuations of 29 cm at Pacific Ocean coast of Russia [[Far East]]. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top| [[Mexico]] |Wave fluctuations of 89 cm at [[Manzanillo, Colima]], due to focusing of tsunami energy from the Pacific plate rise and local terrain. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top| [[New Zealand]] |Wave fluctuations of 65 cm at [[Jackson Bay]] and 50 cm at Waitangi on [[Chatham Island]]. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top| [[Peru]] |Wave fluctuations of 50 cm from crest to trough at [[Callao]]. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top| [[United States]] |Wave fluctuations of 22 cm at [[San Diego, California]], and 6 cm at [[Hilo, Hawaii]]. |- |class=nowrap style=vertical-align:top| [[Vanuatu]] |Wave fluctuations of 18 cm at [[Port Vila]]. |- |}
