revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} '''Silje Marie Redergård''' (26 June 1989 – 15 October 1994)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://byblis.net/gravsted/tiller.html|title=Tiller kirkegård|website=byblis.net|language=no|access-date=23 February 2018}}</ref> was a Norwegian girl who was [[Child murder#By other children|killed by two boys]] in the village of [[Rosten]] near [[Trondheim]] on 15 October 1994. The boys, aged five and six, beat, kicked, stoned and stripped Redergård naked, leaving her in the snow to die of [[hypothermia]]. The boys were directed to undergo psychological evaluation, as Norwegian law did not allow the punishment of persons under the age of 15.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/somethind-died-with-silje-does-the-killing-of-five-year-old-silje-marie-redergaard-by-her-own-1444162.html|title=Something died with Silje|last=Karacs|first=Imre|date=20 October 1994|work=[[The Independent]]|access-date=10 February 2018}}</ref> The names of the boys were not publicly released.
The case has been compared to the [[murder of James Bulger]], which took place in the United Kingdom twenty months earlier.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/2010/mar/20/norway-town-forgave-child-killers|title=The Norway town that forgave and forgot its child killers|last=James|first=Erwin|last2=MacDougall|first2=Ian|author-link=Erwin James|date=20 March 2010|work=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=10 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/james-bulger-documentary-jon-venables-robert-thompson-murder-child-sex-what-went-wrong-rehabilitate-a8203306.html|title=James Bulger murder: How failure to deal with killer Jon Venables was the latest episode in a tragedy shaming a nation|last=Lusher|first=Adam|date=9 February 2018|work=The Independent|access-date=10 February 2018}}</ref>
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Redergard, Silje, Death of}} [[Category:1994 crimes in Norway]] [[Category:Murder in 1994]] [[Category:Murder committed by minors]] [[Category:October 1994 events in Europe]] [[Category:Murder in Norway]] [[Category:Events in Trondheim]] [[Category:20th century in Trondheim]]

{{noref|date=January 2018}}{{italic title}} '''''Edward The King''''' is a 2008 two-act play by American playwright [[David Brendan Hopes]]. The play is an adaptation of [[Christopher Marlowe|Christopher Marlowe's]] play ''[[Edward II (play)|Edward II]]'', which in turn is a dramatization of the real-life story of [[Edward II of England]].
==Overview== Beset by the duties of his birth and dominated by a heroic father, Edward looks forward to a life of apparent conformity and desperate subterfuge, until he meets [[Piers Gaveston]] in a dirty alley. It is love and rebellion at first sight. From then on, Edward steers a perilous course between desire and safety, which does not entirely end even when he becomes king, and faces not only the usual enemies of unconventional love, but his queen and her lover as well. Edward the King neatly straddles the 14th and 21st centuries, which manage to appear almost equally violent and inhospitable to love.
==External links== *[http://www.doollee.com/PlaywrightsH/hopes-david-brendan.html#84327 ''Edward The King'' on The Playwrights Database] *[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/117712.html ''Edward The King'' World Premier at GayFest NYC 2008 on Playbill News]

revision.text:
{{about|the television musical|the plant called evening primrose|Oenothera}} {{Infobox Musical |name= Evening Primrose |subtitle= |image=EveningPrimroseCastRecording.jpg |caption=Original television soundtrack recording |music=[[Stephen Sondheim]] |lyrics=Stephen Sondheim |book=[[James Goldman]] |basis=John Collier's short story |productions= 1966 US television series ''[[ABC Stage 67]]'' <!-- Please do not include production-specific (acting, directing, etc.) awards --> |awards= }}
'''''Evening Primrose''''' is a [[musical theatre|musical]] with a book by [[James Goldman]] and lyrics and music by [[Stephen Sondheim]]. It is based on a [[John Collier (fiction writer)|John Collier]] [[short story]] published in the 1951 collection ''Fancies and Goodnights''.
Written originally for television, the musical focuses on a poet who takes refuge from the world by hiding out in a department store after closing. He meets a community of night people who live in the store and falls in love with a beautiful young girl named Ella. Bizarre complications arise when the leader of the group forbids their relationship.
==Synopsis== Poet Charles Snell takes refuge from the world by hiding out in a department store after closing ("If You Can Find Me, I'm Here"). Once there he finds a secret group who have lived in the store for years. The leader of the group, Mrs. Monday, permits Charles to stay after he convinces her that he is a poet.
Charles meets and is smitten with a beautiful young girl, Ella Harkins, Mrs. Monday's maid. Ella, who is now 19, has lived in the store since she was separated from her mother at age six, falling asleep in the women's hat department. Ella is unhappy and wants to leave, but is afraid of the "Dark Men". Should someone try to return to the outside world and risk revealing the group's existence, the Dark Men take them away and another [[mannequin]] appears in the clothing department.
Charles realizes Ella has not seen the sun for thirteen years, but she replies that she remembers ("I Remember"). Charles has fallen in love with Ella; as he plays cards with members of the group, he has a quiet duet with Ella ("When"). Ella finally decides to leave with Charles ("Take Me To The World"). Charles is initially reluctant to leave his now-comfortable life, but then understands that he loves Ella more than poetry. Mrs. Monday and the others hear their plans, and they call the Dark Men, as Ella and Charles try to escape.
The store opens the next morning with a couple on the sidewalk who resemble Ella and Charles from behind, but turn out to be strangers when the camera pans to their faces. They're looking at a window display in which Ella and Charles are now mannequins dressed as a bride and groom, with the night watchman acting as their minister.
==Productions== [[File:Evening Primrose Anthony Perkins Charmian Carr 1966 redone.jpg|thumb|[[Anthony Perkins]] as Charles Snell; [[Charmian Carr]] as Ella Harkins]] Written specifically for the [[television]] [[anthology series]] ''[[ABC Stage 67]]'', it aired on November 16, 1966.<ref name="epiepenburgnyt">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/25/theater/25primrose.html?_r=1&ref=television |title=Piepenburg, Erik. "'60s Sondheim TV Show Is Now on (Legal) DVD," ''The New York Times'', Monday, October 25, 2010 |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=2010-10-25 |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref> It was directed by [[Paul Bogart]], set design by John Ward, set decorated by Budd Gourmen, costume design by William McHone, and lighting design by Walter Urban. The cast starred [[Anthony Perkins]] as Charles Snell, [[Charmian Carr]] as Ella Harkins, [[Larry Gates]] as Roscoe Potts, [[Dorothy Stickney]] as Mrs. Monday, and Margaret Bannerman, Margaret Barker, Leonard Elliot, Mike Meola, Dorothy Sands, and Margaretta Warwick as store people. The one-hour program was taped on an early Sunday morning at the now-defunct [[Stern's|Stern Brothers]] [[department store]] in [[Manhattan]].<ref name="epiepenburgnyt"/>
The ''Evening Primrose'' telecast was in [[color television|color]], but the original master tape has never been found. [[Black-and-white|Black-and-white (B&W)]] versions are available for viewing at the [[Museum of Television & Radio]] branches in [[New York City]] and [[Beverly Hills]]. A newly discovered pristine B&W 16-[[millimetre|millimeter]] copy was used for [[DVD]]s which were released commercially for the first time on October 26, 2010.<ref name="epiepenburgnyt"/>
The first professional theatrical production was staged in London as part of the ''Lost Musicals'' series. It opened at the Lilian Baylis Studio on July 3, 2005 and closed on July 24. Directed by Ian Marshall Fisher, it starred [[Betsy Blair]] as Mrs. Monday, Michael Matus as Charles Snell, Jennifer Higham as Ella Harkins, James Vaughan as Store Doorman/Night Watchman, and Gary Raymond as Roscoe, with Sylvia Seymour, Martin Gaisford, Myra Sands, David O'Brien and Andrew Beavis in supporting roles.<ref>[https://www.londontheatre.co.uk/theatre-news/news/casting-confirmed-for-lost-musicals-evening-primrose "Casting confirmed for Lost Musicals "Evening Primrose"] londontheatre.co.uk, 14 June 2005</ref>
On October 22, 2010, the St. George's Society in New York City had a one night only semi staged performance at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater at [[John Jay College of Criminal Justice]]. The show was directed and designed by [[Tony Walton]], musical supervision and orchestration by Sean Patrick Flahaven, and musical director Mary-Mitchell Campbell, sound design by Bernard Fox. The cast had [[Carmen De Lavallade]] (Mrs. Billbee) --she also directed some choreography, Jessica Grové (Ella), [[Sean Palmer]] (Charles), [[Candice Bergen]] (Mrs. Monday), John Cunningham (Roscoe Potts), Sondra Lee (Augusta), and [[William Duell]] (Billy).<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Portantiere |first1=Michael |last2= |first2= |year=2011 |title=Back into the light |journal=The Sondheim Review |volume=XVII |issue=3 |page=44|publisher=Sondheim Review, Inc. |issn=1076-450X |doi= |url= |accessdate= }}</ref>
The DVD was commercially released for the first time on April 20, 2010, by [[E1 Entertainment]] and the [[Archive of American Television]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1= |first1=|last2= |first2= |year=2010 |title=Take me to the world|journal=The Sondheim Review |volume=XVI |issue=4 |page=5 |publisher=Sondheim Review, Inc. |issn=1076-450X |doi= |url= |accessdate= }}</ref>
==Musical score== *"If You Can Find Me, I'm Here" *"Charles Meets Mrs. Monday" (instrumental) *"Charles And Ella" (instrumental) *"Check List" (instrumental) *"The Basement" (instrumental) *"I Remember" *"When" *"Take Me To The World" *"The Ball" (instrumental) *"Roscoe And The Guard" (instrumental) *"The Ball, Part 2" (instrumental) *"Escape" (instrumental) *"Take Me To The World" (Reprise) *"Final Credits" (instrumental)
==Recordings== An official soundtrack recording was not released commercially until 2008, when Kritzerland, Inc. issued it in a limited release of 3,000 copies.<ref>Suskin, Steven. [https://archive.is/20120906044131/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/117614.html Sondheim's "Evening Primrose" and Kelli O'Hara's "Wonder in the World"], playbill.com, May 12, 2008</ref> Previously, the four vocal selections had been recorded by [[Mandy Patinkin]] and [[Bernadette Peters]] for his 1990 ''Dress Casual'' album. Patinkin sang "If You Can Find Me, I'm Here," Peters sang "I Remember", and the other two were performed as duets. In 1997, [[Liz Callaway]] and [[Gary Beach]] recorded them for a [[Varèse Sarabande]] release entitled ''Sondheim at the Movies''. A studio recording with [[Neil Patrick Harris]] as Charles and Theresa McCarthy as Ella was released by [[Nonesuch Records]] in 2001.<ref>Suskin, Steven. [https://archive.is/20120908071723/http://www.playbill.com/features/article/66631-ON_THE_RECORD_The_Frogs_Evening_Primrose_Subways The Frogs, Evening Primrose, Subways"], playbill.com, October 18, 2001</ref> They recorded "If You Can Find Me, I'm Here", "I Remember", "When?", and "Take Me to the World".
"I Remember" has been recorded by [[David Kernan]] on the recording of the musical revue ''[[Side by Side by Sondheim]]'', [[Sarah Brightman]], [[Judy Collins]], [[John Pizzarelli]], [[Mark Murphy (singer)|Mark Murphy]], [[Cleo Laine]], [[Maureen McGovern]], [[Betty Buckley]], [[Julia Migenes]], [[Dianne Reeves]], [[Myrra Malmberg]], [[Madeline Eastman]], and [[Barbra Streisand]]. [[Dawn Upshaw]] included "Take Me to the World" on her 1994 musical theatre album ''I Wish It So''.
[[Barbra Streisand]] recorded the song "Take Me to The World" with [[Antonio Banderas]] for her 2016 album ''[[Encore: Movie Partners Sing Broadway]]''.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.sondheimguide.com/primrose.html ''Evening Primrose'' on The Stephen Sondheim Reference Guide] *[http://www.sondheim.com/shows/evening_primrose/ ''Evening Primrose'' plot and production information at sondheim.com] *[http://www.concertonet.com/scripts/review.php?ID_review=3025 Information on the 2005 London production] *{{imdb title|0060384}}
{{Stephen Sondheim}}
[[Category:1966 musicals]] [[Category:Musicals based on short fiction]] [[Category:Musical television specials]] [[Category:Musicals by Stephen Sondheim]]

revision.text:
{{pp-pc1}} {{pp-move-indef}} {{calendar}} {{This date in recent years}} {{Day}}
This day marks the approximate midpoint of winter in the Northern Hemisphere and of summer in the Southern Hemisphere (starting the season at the December solstice).
==Events== * [[211]] – Roman Emperor [[Septimius Severus]] dies at Eboracum (modern York, England) while preparing to lead a campaign against the [[Caledonians]]. He leaves the empire in the control of his two quarrelling sons. * [[634]] – [[Battle of Dathin]]: [[Rashidun army|Rashidun]] forces under [[Yazid ibn Abi Sufyan]] defeat an outnumbered [[Byzantine]] force near [[Gaza City|Gaza]] in [[Palaestina Prima|Palestine]]. * [[960]] – The coronation of Zhao Kuangyin as [[Emperor Taizu of Song]], initiating the [[Song dynasty]] period of China that would last more than three centuries. *[[1169]] – A [[1169 Sicily earthquake|strong earthquake]] struck the Ionian coast of Sicily, causing tens of thousands of injuries and deaths, especially in [[Catania]]. *[[1454]] – In the [[Thirteen Years' War (1454–66)|Thirteen Years' War]], the Secret Council of the [[Prussian Confederation]] sends a formal act of disobedience to the [[Grand Masters of the Teutonic Knights|Grand Master]]. *[[1488]] – [[Bartolomeu Dias]] commands the first European expedition to reach South Africa and the Indian Ocean. *[[1555]] – [[John Rogers (Bible editor and martyr)|John Rogers]] is [[burned at the stake]], becoming the first English [[Protestant]] [[martyr]] under [[Mary I of England]]. *[[1703]] – In [[Edo]] (now Tokyo), 46 of the [[Forty-seven Ronin]] commit [[seppuku]] (ritual suicide) as recompense for avenging their master's death. *[[1758]] – [[Macapá]], [[Brazil]] is founded. *[[1789]] – [[George Washington]] is unanimously elected as the first [[President of the United States]] by the [[U.S. Electoral College]]. *[[1794]] – The French legislature abolishes [[slavery]] throughout all territories of the [[French First Republic]]. It will be reestablished in the [[French West Indies]] in 1802. *[[1797]] – The [[1797 Riobamba earthquake|Riobamba earthquake]] strikes [[Ecuador]], causing up to 40,000 casualties. *[[1801]] – [[John Marshall]] is sworn in as [[Chief Justice of the United States]]. *[[1810]] – The [[Royal Navy]] seizes [[Guadeloupe]]. *[[1820]] – The [[Chilean Navy]] under the command of [[Thomas Cochrane, 10th Earl of Dundonald|Lord Cochrane]] completes the 2-day long [[Capture of Valdivia]] with just 300 men and 2 ships. *[[1825]] – The [[Ohio Legislature]] authorizes the construction of the [[Ohio and Erie Canal]] and the [[Miami and Erie Canal]]. *[[1846]] – The first [[Mormon pioneers]] make their exodus from [[Nauvoo, Illinois]], westward towards [[Salt Lake Valley]]. *[[1859]] – The [[Codex Sinaiticus]] is discovered in [[Egypt]]. *[[1861]] – [[American Civil War]]: In [[Montgomery, Alabama]], delegates from six break-away [[U.S. state]]s meet and form the [[Confederate States of America]]. *[[1899]] – The [[Philippine–American War]] begins with the [[Battle of Manila (1899)|Battle of Manila]]. *[[1932]] – [[Second Sino-Japanese War]]: [[Harbin]], [[Manchuria]], [[Defense of Harbin|falls to]] [[Empire of Japan|Japan]]. *[[1938]] – Adolf Hitler appoints himself as head of the [[Oberkommando der Wehrmacht|Armed Forces High Command]]. *[[1941]] – The [[United Service Organization]] (USO) is created to entertain American troops. *[[1945]] – [[World War II]]: [[Santo Tomas Internment Camp]] is liberated from Japanese authority. * 1945 – World War II: The [[Yalta Conference]] between the "Big Three" ([[Winston Churchill|Churchill]], [[Franklin D. Roosevelt|Roosevelt]], and [[Joseph Stalin|Stalin]]) opens at the [[Livadia Palace]] in the [[Crimea#Soviet Union: 1922.E2.80.931991|Crimea]]. * 1945 – World War II: The [[British Indian Army]] and [[Imperial Japanese Army]] begin a series of battles known as the [[Battle of Pokoku and Irrawaddy River operations]]. *[[1948]] – [[Dominion of Ceylon|Ceylon]] (later renamed [[Sri Lanka]]) becomes independent within the [[Commonwealth of Nations|British Commonwealth]]. *[[1961]] – The [[Angolan War of Independence]] and the greater [[Portuguese Colonial War]] begin. *[[1966]] – [[All Nippon Airways Flight 60]] plunges into [[Tokyo Bay]], killing 133. *[[1967]] – [[Lunar Orbiter program]]: [[Lunar Orbiter 3]] lifts off from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral's]] Launch Complex 13 on its mission to identify possible landing sites for the [[Surveyor program|Surveyor]] and [[Apollo program|Apollo]] spacecraft. *[[1969]] – [[Yasser Arafat]] takes over as chairman of the [[Palestine Liberation Organization]]. *[[1974]] – The [[Symbionese Liberation Army]] kidnaps [[Patty Hearst]] in [[Berkeley, California]]. * 1974 – [[M62 coach bombing]]: The [[Provisional Irish Republican Army]] (IRA) explodes a bomb on a bus carrying off-duty [[British Armed Forces]] personnel in [[Yorkshire]], England. Nine soldiers and three civilians are killed. *[[1975]] – [[1975 Haicheng earthquake|Haicheng earthquake]] (magnitude 7.3 on the [[Richter magnitude scale|Richter scale]]) occurs in [[Haicheng, Liaoning]], China. *[[1976]] – In [[Guatemala]] and [[Honduras]] an [[1976 Guatemala earthquake|earthquake]] kills more than 22,000. *[[1977]] – A [[Chicago Transit Authority]] [[elevated train]] [[1977 Chicago Loop derailment|rear-ends another and derails]], killing 11 and injuring 180, the worst accident in the agency's history. *[[1992]] – A [[1992 Venezuelan coup d'état attempts|coup d'état]] is led by [[Hugo Chávez]] against [[Venezuela]]n President [[Carlos Andrés Pérez]]. *[[1997]] – En route to [[Lebanon]], two Israeli [[Sikorsky CH-53 Sea Stallion|Sikorsky CH-53]] troop-transport helicopters [[1997 Israeli helicopter disaster|collide in mid-air]] over northern Galilee, [[Israel]] killing 73. *[[1998]] – The 5.9 {{M|w}} [[February 1998 Afghanistan earthquake|Afghanistan earthquake]] shakes the [[Takhar Province]] with a maximum [[Mercalli intensity scale|Mercalli intensity]] of VII (''Very strong''). With 2,323 killed, and 818 injured, damage is considered extreme. *[[1999]] – Unarmed West African immigrant [[Shooting of Amadou Diallo|Amadou Diallo is shot 41 times]] by four plainclothes New York City police officers on an unrelated stake-out, inflaming race relations in the city. *[[2003]] – The [[Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]] adopts a new constitution, becoming a loose confederacy between Montenegro and Serbia. *[[2004]] – [[Facebook]], a mainstream online [[social networking site]], is founded by [[Mark Zuckerberg]]. *[[2015]] – [[TransAsia Airways Flight 235]] with 58 people on board, en route from the Taiwanese capital [[Taipei]] to [[Kinmen]], crashes into the [[Keelung River]] just after take-off, killing 43 people. <!-- Please do not add the Super Bowl game or other routine sporting events to this section. They are not sufficiently notable in this context. -->
==Births== <!-- Please do not add yourself or anyone else without a biography in Wikipedia to this list. --> *[[1447]] – [[Lodovico Lazzarelli]], Italian poet (d. 1500) *[[1465]] – [[Frans van Brederode]], Dutch rebel (d. 1490) *[[1495]] – [[Francesco II Sforza]], Duke of Milan (d. 1535) * 1495 – [[Jean Parisot de Valette]], Grand Master of the Knights Hospitaller (d. 1568) *[[1505]] – [[Mikołaj Rej]], Polish poet and author (d. 1580) *[[1575]] – [[Pierre de Bérulle]], French cardinal and theologian, founded the [[French school of spirituality]] (d. 1629) *[[1646]] – [[Hans Erasmus Aßmann]], German poet and politician (d. 1699) *[[1676]] – [[Giacomo Facco]], Italian violinist and composer (d. 1753) *[[1677]] – [[Johann Ludwig Bach]], German violinist and composer (d. 1731) *[[1688]] – [[Pierre de Marivaux]], French author and playwright (d. 1763) *[[1725]] – [[Dru Drury]], English entomologist and author (d. 1804) *[[1740]] – [[Carl Michael Bellman]], Swedish poet and composer (d. 1795) *[[1778]] – [[Augustin Pyramus de Candolle]], Swiss botanist, mycologist, and academic (d. 1841) *[[1799]] – [[Almeida Garrett]], Portuguese journalist and author (d. 1854) *[[1818]] – [[Emperor Norton]], San Francisco eccentric and visionary (d. 1880) *[[1831]] – [[Oliver Ames (governor)|Oliver Ames]], American financier and politician, 35th [[Governor of Massachusetts]] (d. 1895) *[[1848]] – [[Jean Aicard]], French poet, author, and playwright (d. 1921) *[[1849]] – [[Jean Richepin]], French poet, author, and playwright (d. 1926) *[[1862]] – [[Édouard Estaunié]], French novelist (d. 1942) *[[1865]] – [[Abe Isoo]], Japanese minister and politician (d. 1949) *[[1868]] – [[Constance Markievicz]], Irish revolutionary and first woman elected to the UK [[House of Commons]] (d. 1927) *[[1871]] – [[Friedrich Ebert]], German lawyer and politician, 1st [[President of Germany (1919–1945)|President of Germany]] (d. 1925) *[[1872]] – [[Gotse Delchev]], Bulgarian and Macedonian revolutionary activist (d. 1903) *[[1873]] – [[Étienne Desmarteau]], Canadian shot putter and discus thrower (d. 1905) *[[1875]] – [[Ludwig Prandtl]], German physicist and engineer (d. 1953) *[[1877]] – [[Eddie Cochems]], American football player and coach (d. 1953) *[[1881]] – [[Eulalio Gutiérrez]], Mexican general and politician, [[President of Mexico]] (d. 1939) * 1881 – [[Fernand Léger]], French painter and sculptor (d. 1955) *[[1883]] – [[Reinhold Rudenberg]], German-American inventor and a pioneer of [[electron microscopy]] (d. 1961) *[[1891]] – [[M. {{unreferenced|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox Convention | name = Glamourcon | image = | caption = | status = Defunct | genre = Glamour (Adult) | venue = | location = | country = United States | first = | last = | organizer = Robert Schulz | filing = For Profit | attendance = | website = {{official|http://www.glamourcon.com/}} }} '''Glamourcon''' was a fan convention that took place twice a year, once in [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]] and once in [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]], that centers upon [[glamour model]]s and [[glamour photography]], with its guests typically being ''[[Playboy]]'' [[Playmate of the Month|Playmates]], ''[[Penthouse (magazine)|Penthouse]]'' [[Pet of the Month|Pets]], ''[[Hustler]]'' Honeys, ''[[Perfect 10 (magazine)|Perfect 10]]'' [[Model (person)|Models]], soft core [[pornographic actresses]] and other [[pin-up model]]s. A [[portmanteau]] of the phrase "glamour convention", it was founded by [[entrepreneur]] Robert Schulz.
==External links== *{{official|http://www.glamourcon.com}} *[http://www.unratedmagazine.com/articles/Archive/2008/Glamourco-44-Chicago_2008-08-23.cfm "Glamourcon 44 Chicago"]. ''Unrated Magazine''. Chicago. August 2008.
[[Category:Defunct multigenre conventions]] [[Category:Defunct fan conventions]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox theatre | name = Goodspeed Opera House | image = GoodspeedOperaHouse.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = The Goodspeed Opera House from the Connecticut River | image_map = | map_caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_map_caption= | address = 6 Main Street | city = [[East Haddam, Connecticut|East Haddam]], [[Connecticut]] | country = [[United States]] | designation = | architect = | owner = Goodspeed Musicals | tenant = | operator = | capacity = | type = Regional theatre | opened = October 24, 1877 <!--{{Start date|YYYY|MM|FF|df=y}}--> | reopened = June 8, 1963 | yearsactive = | rebuilt = | closed = | demolished = | othernames = | production = | currentuse = | website = {{URL|http://www.goodspeed.org}} {{Infobox NRHP | embed = yes | name = Goodspeed Opera House | coordinates ={{Coord|41|27|6.33|N|72|27|45.06|W|region:US-CT|display=title,inline}} | area = | built = 1876-77 | architect = Jabez Comstock<ref name=nrhp/> | architecture = | added = July 30, 1971 | refnum = 71000901<ref name=nrhp>{{NRISref|2010a}}</ref> | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = Private | nrhp_type2 = cp | nocat = yes | designated_nrhp_type2 = April 29, 1983 | partof = [[East Haddam Historic District]] | partof_refnum = 83001273 }} }}
'''Goodspeed Musicals''' is a non-profit organization dedicated to the preservation and advancement of musical theater and the creation of new works, located in [[East Haddam, Connecticut]]. A distinctive feature of the view from the [[Connecticut River]], the Goodspeed Opera House is the birthplace of some of the world's most famous musicals, including ''[[Annie (musical)|Annie]]'', ''[[Man of La Mancha]]'' and ''[[Shenandoah (musical)|Shenandoah]]''.
== Goodspeed Opera House == The Opera House was originally built by a local merchant and banker, William Goodspeed. Construction began in 1876 and finished in 1877. Despite the name, it was not in fact an [[opera house]], but rather a venue for presenting plays. Its first play, ''Charles II'', opened on October 24, 1877. After William Goodspeed's death, the opera house fell into disrepair, facing a series of less glamorous uses—from a militia base during [[World War I]] to a [[general store]] and a Department of Transportation storage facility.
The building is unique for a theater. The theater itself is actually located on the top two floors of the building making for interesting and sometimes difficult scenery and show load-ins. Scenery is loaded-in from the dock area up a vacant elevator shaft that is now outfitted with a winch system to haul the scenery up to the stage level. Much care has to be taken in order to get the scenery up the shaft without scratching or ruining the scenery. One story told around Goodspeed is that while loading in the scenery for Annie's original pre-Broadway run, a strong gust of wind took a large piece of scenery out of the hands of the loaders and blew it into the Connecticut River.
== Goodspeed Musicals ==
Goodspeed Musicals was formed in 1959 by a group of concerned citizens after the state of Connecticut had condemned the building. The state agreed to sell the building to the group for one dollar, provided they acquire enough funding to restore and maintain it. The restoration project took nearly four years, and the Goodspeed Opera House was rededicated on June 8, 1963. The first performance in the new opera house was ''[[Oh, Lady! Lady!]]'' Under the direction of [[Michael P. Price]] since 1968, Goodspeed Musicals has sent 19 productions to Broadway.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/people/Goodspeed-Opera-House/#.U7LoUbGzmYk|title=Goodspeed Opera House Theatre Credits|publisher=}}</ref> Goodspeed productions have won more than a dozen [[Tony Award]]s, while Goodspeed Musicals itself has won two special Tonys, one for outstanding contributions to American Musicals and the other for outstanding achievement by a regional theatre.
In 1984, Goodspeed Musicals added a second performance venue—the [[Norma Terris Theatre]]—in nearby [[Chester, Connecticut]]. While the main stage presents a mixture of revivals and new musicals as part of its 3 production season, The Norma Terris also presents three new musicals each season. Several original plays debuted there or at the opera house before going on to [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] and winning [[Tony Award]]s.
In addition to the two theaters, Goodspeed Musicals pursues its mission through the Max Showalter Center for Education in Musical Theatre, which offers internships and new writers' residency programs, as well as the Scherer Library of Musical Theatre, which houses the largest musical theatre research facility in the United States. Goodspeed Musicals has also built state-of-the-art production facilities including scenery shops, costume shops and a large costume storage facility.
Critic fellows from the [[Eugene O'Neill Theater Center]] in Waterford, CT travel to the Goodspeed each summer to practice reviewing full productions.
Tours of many of the Goodspeed facilities can be scheduled in advance for a small fee. Tickets to the opera house or theatre productions should be ordered in advance as most performances in the relatively small theater sell-out quickly.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ctvisit.com/tours/goodspeed-opera-house-tour/summary/2236 |title=Visit CT |work=Visit CT |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714194527/http://www.ctvisit.com/tours/goodspeed-opera-house-tour/summary/2236 |archivedate=2014-07-14 |df= }}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Connecticut}} *[[National Register of Historic Places listings in Middlesex County, Connecticut]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.goodspeed.org/ Goodspeed Musicals official website] * {{IBDB name}} * [http://www.andrewmcgibbonphotography.com/goodspeed-opera-house Google Virtual Tour of Goodspeed Opera House] * [https://www.atlasobscura.com/places/goodspeed-opera-house Goodspeed on Atlas Obscura]

revision.text:
{{POV|talk=POV Fork|date=June 2018}} In political theory and theology, to '''immanentize the eschaton''' means trying to bring about the [[eschatology|eschaton]] (the final, heaven-like stage of history) in the [[Immanence|immanent]] world. In all these contexts it means "trying to make that which belongs to the afterlife happen here and now (on Earth)".{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} Theologically the belief is akin to [[postmillennialism]] as reflected in the [[Social Gospel]] of the 1880–1930 era,{{cite book|author=David W. Miller |title=God at Work : The History and Promise of the Faith at Work Movement|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jeyqcbS6xx0C&pg=PA28|date=2006|publisher=Oxford University Press|page=28}} as well as Protestant reform movements during the [[Second Great Awakening]] in the 1830s and 1840s such as abolitionism.{{cite book|author=Douglas M. Strong|title=Perfectionist Politics: Abolitionism and the Religious Tensions of American Democracy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J5T2tGOKYOMC&pg=PA30|date= 2002|publisher=Syracuse U.P.|page=30}} ==Origin== Modern usage of the phrase started with [[Eric Voegelin]] in ''The New Science of Politics'' in 1952. Conservative spokesman [[William F. Buckley]] popularized Voegelin's phrase as "Don't immanentize the eschaton!" Buckley's version became a political slogan of [[Young Americans for Freedom]] during the 1960s and 1970s.{{cite web | title = Immanent Corrections | author = Jonah Goldberg | url = http://article.nationalreview.com/?q=ODQ5Y2ZiNjAzMjdlNDAwMTk2MTgxNGVlYTE1Nzc5YjQ=#more | publisher = [[National Review]] | date = 2002-01-16 | accessdate = 2008-11-06}} Voegelin identified a number of similarities between ancient [[Gnosticism]] and the beliefs held by a number of modern political theories, particularly Communism and Nazism. He identified the root of the Gnostic impulse as belief in a lack of concord within society as a result of an inherent disorder, or even evil, of the world. He described this as having two effects:{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} *The belief that the disorder of the world can be transcended by extraordinary insight, learning, or knowledge, called a ''Gnostic Speculation'' by Voegelin (the Gnostics themselves referred to this as ''[[gnosis]]''). *The desire to implement a policy to actualize the speculation, or as Voegelin said, to ''Immanentize the Eschaton'', to create a sort of heaven on earth within history. One of the more oft-quoted passages from Voegelin's work on Gnosticism is that "The problem of an ''[[Theory of forms|eidos]]'' in history, hence, arises only when a Christian [[Transcendence (religion)|transcendental]] fulfillment becomes immanentized. Such an immanentist [[Hypostasis (Christianity)|hypostasis]] of the eschaton, however, is a theoretical fallacy."{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} The book ''[[Fire in the Minds of Men]]'' explores the idea further.{{cite web | title=Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy | author= | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E03EFDB1539F933A15750C0A965948260 | publisher=[[The New York Times]] | date=1983-03-20 | accessdate=2008-11-06 | quote=At once erudite and dramatic, the book explores the roots of the modern belief that a just and beautiful new world will spring into being if only we can overthrow evil powers and institutions.}}[https://books.google.com/books?id=a4PRx21WVqMC&printsec=frontcover ''Fire in the Minds of Men'', introduction] ==Christianity== The [[Lutheran Confessions]] directly reject the idea of an immanentized eschaton, condemning the belief "that before the resurrection of the dead the godly shall take possession of the kingdom of the world, the ungodly being everywhere suppressed."{{cite web | title = Augsburg Confession ACXVII | url = http://bookofconcord.org/augsburgconfession.php#article17.5 | accessdate = 2012-01-09}} The ''[[Catechism of the Catholic Church]]'' makes an oblique reference to the desire to "Immanentize the Eschaton" in article 676:
The Antichrist's deception already begins to take shape in the world every time the claim is made to realize within history that messianic hope which can only be realized beyond history through the eschatological judgment. The Church has rejected even modified forms of this falsification of the kingdom to come under the name of millenarianism, especially the "intrinsically perverse" political form of a secular messianism.
At the end of the 12th century, [[Joachim of Fiore]] theorized the coming of an age of earthly bliss right before the end of time. Although not a full immanentization, Joachim has opened the way to an anticipation of the eschaton in the course of time. His ideas have influenced the thoughts on an immanentized eschaton.{{Cite book|title=Gioacchino da Fiore nella cultura contemporanea: atti del 6 Congresso Internazionale di Studi Gioachimiti, San Giovanni in Fiore, 23 - 25 settembre 2004|last=Potestà|first=Gian Luca (Ed.)|publisher=Viella|year=2005|isbn=8883341872|location=Roma|pages=}} ==Political Interpretations== In contemporary terminology this process is sometimes described as "hastening the eschaton" or "hastening the [[apocalypse]]. In this sense it refers to a phenomenon related to [[millenarianism]] and the specific Christian form [[millennialism]] which is based on a particular reading of the Christian Bible's [[Book of Revelation]] especially popular among evangelicals in the United States {{cite book |last1=Landes |first1=Richard Allen |title=Heaven on Earth: The varieties of the Millennial experience |date=2011 |publisher=Oxford |location=England |accessdate=8 September 2018}} Some [[Conservatism|conservative critics]] sometimes use these terms as a pejorative reference to certain projects such as [[Nazism]], [[socialism]], and [[communism]]. ==In popular culture== The phrase is cited in the [[Discordian]] text ''[[Principia Discordia]]'', first published in 1965, and appears fifteen times in [[Robert Anton Wilson]] and [[Robert Shea]]'s 1975 ''[[The Illuminatus! Trilogy]]'', in the first of which the first line of the novel is, "It was the year when they finally immanentized the Eschaton." In [[Ken Macleod]]'s 1997 science fiction novel ''The Stone Canal'', one of the chapters is called, "Another crack at Immanentising the Eschaton." The phrase is also used in issue four of Warren Ellis' 2007 comic, ''[[Doktor Sleepless]]''. It appears to be the goal of the title character to bring about the end of the world, driven by disappointment over how the future of the past has transpired. Sleepless wants to end the world to keep it from getting worse. The phrase is quoted several times, and can be regarded as the driving force behind the comic. It is quoted (on a banner) in [[Larry Niven]] and [[Jerry Pournelle]]'s 2009 novel ''[[Escape from Hell (novel)|Escape from Hell]]''. It was used in the lyrics of the two [[Rave music|rave]] singles "[[All You Need Is Love (The JAMs song)|All You Need Is Love]]" by [[The KLF#The Justified Ancients of Mu Mu|The Justified Ancients of Mu Mu]] in 1987, and the [[Shamen]]'s "Destination Eschaton" in 1995. ==See also== *[[Postmillennialism]] *[[Premillennialism]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://archive.is/20130415182151/http://www.profam.org/pub/rs/rs_1709.htm "Diversity, Diversity"] in ''The Religion & Society Report'' (Volume 17 Number 9 September 2000) from The Howard Center. *[http://www.culturewars.com/2004/Gorenberg.htm "The Once and Future Heresy"]: ''The End of Days: Fundamentalism and the Struggle for the Temple Mount'' by Gershom Gorenberg, Reviewed by Thomas J. Herron. *[http://www.alternet.org/story/15814/why_ecocide_is_'good_news'_for_the_gop Why Ecocide Is 'Good News' for the GOP]—''[[Alternet]]'' (May 4, 2003) {{DEFAULTSORT:Immanentize The Eschaton}} [[Category:Eschatology]] [[Category:Discordianism]]

revision.text:
[[File:Magnetosphere rendition.jpg|300px|thumb|Artist's depiction of [[solar wind]] striking Earth's [[magnetosphere]] (size and distance not to scale)]]
A severe geomagnetic storm struck Earth on March 13, 1989. It occurred during [[solar cycle 22]] and caused a nine-hour outage of [[Hydro-Québec's electricity transmission system]].
==Geomagnetic storm and auroras== The geomagnetic storm causing this event was itself the result of an ejection known as a [[coronal mass ejection]] on March 9, 1989.<ref>[http://evworld.com/article.cfm?storyid=246 Geomagnetic Storms Can Threaten Electric Power Grid] ''Earth in Space'', Vol. 9, No. 7, March 1997, pp.9-11 (American Geophysical Union)</ref> A few days before, on March 6, a very large X15-class [[solar flare]] also occurred.<ref name="sohowww.nascom.nasa.gov">http://sohowww.nascom.nasa.gov/hotshots/X17/</ref> Three-and-a-half days later, at 2:44 [[12-hour clock|am]] [[Eastern Time Zone|EST]] on March 13, a severe geomagnetic storm struck [[Earth]].<ref name="Bnet">{{cite web|title=Space weather: Page 1 |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1511/is_n8_v16/ai_17253896/pg_1 |publisher=[[Discover (magazine)|Discover]] |accessdate=2008-01-20 |date=August 1995 |first=Eric J. |last=Lerner |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130602100449/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1511/is_n8_v16/ai_17253896/pg_1 |archivedate=2013-06-02 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Scientists probe northern lights from all angles |url=http://www.cbc.ca/health/story/2005/10/22/northern_lights_051022.html |publisher=[[CBC News]] |date=2005-10-22 |accessdate=2008-01-13}}</ref> The storm began on Earth with extremely intense [[aurora (astronomy)|auroras]] at the poles. The aurora could be seen as far south as [[Texas]] and [[Florida]].<ref name="storm"/> As this occurred near the end of the [[Cold War]], an unknown number of people worried that a nuclear first strike might be in progress.<ref name="storm">{{cite web|url=http://www.solarstorms.org/SWChapter1.html|title=A Conflagration of Storms|accessdate=2009-04-07}}</ref> Others incorrectly considered the intense auroras to be associated with the Space Shuttle mission [[STS-29]], which had been launched on March 13 at 9:57:00 AM.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-29/mission-sts-29.html |title=STS-29 |publisher=Science.ksc.nasa.gov |accessdate=2010-08-09}}</ref> The burst caused short-wave radio interference, including the disruption of radio signals from [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|Radio Free Europe]] into Russia. It was initially believed that the signals had been [[Radio jamming|jammed]] by the Soviet government.
As midnight came and went, a river of charged particles and electrons in the ionosphere flowed from west to east, inducing powerful electrical currents in the ground that surged into many natural nooks and crannies.<ref name="storm"/>
Some satellites in polar orbits lost control for several hours. [[Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite|GOES weather satellite]] communications were interrupted, causing weather images to be lost. NASA's TDRS-1 communication satellite recorded over 250 anomalies caused by the increased particles flowing into its sensitive electronics.<ref name="storm"/> The Space Shuttle Discovery was having its own problems: a sensor on one of the tanks supplying hydrogen to a fuel cell was showing unusually high pressure readings on March 13. The problem went away after the solar storm subsided.
Anecdotal evidence suggests that one of the UK's nuclear submarines noticed a variation in [[Extremely low frequency|ELF]] signal strength around the same time{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}}. Because the [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|MoD]] files are still classified, this is not yet possible to confirm or deny.
== Quebec blackout == [[File:ExtremeEvent 19890310-00h 19890315-24h.jpg|thumb|right|320px|GOES-7 monitors the space weather conditions during the Great Geomagnetic storm of March 1989, the Moscow neutron monitor recorded the passage of a CME as a drop in levels known as a [[Forbush decrease]].<ref>{{cite web | title=Extreme Space Weather Events | publisher=[[National Geophysical Data Center]] | url=http://sxi.ngdc.noaa.gov/sxi_greatest.html}}</ref>]]
The variations in the [[earth's magnetic field]] also tripped [[circuit breaker]]s on [[Hydro-Québec]]'s [[Hydro-Québec's electricity transmission system|power grid]]. The utility's very long transmission lines and the fact that most of Quebec sits on [[Canadian Shield|a large rock shield]] prevented current flowing through the earth, finding a less resistant path along the 735 kV power lines.<ref name="HQ_solarstorm">{{cite web |url=http://www.hydroquebec.com/learning/notions-de-base/tempete-mars-1989.html |title=Understanding Electricity - March 1989 - Hydro-Québec |author=Hydro-Québec |accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref>
The [[James Bay Project|James Bay]] network went offline in less than 90 seconds, giving [[Quebec]] its second massive [[power outage|blackout]] in 11 months.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archives.radio-canada.ca/environnement/catastrophes_naturelles/clips/14150/ |title=Le Québec dans le noir |date=13 March 1989|first=Michel |last=Morin |first2=Gilles |last2=Sirois |first3=Bernard |last3=Derome |publisher=[[Radio-Canada]]| language=French |accessdate=2009-03-21}}</ref> The power failure lasted nine hours and forced the company to implement various mitigation strategies, including raising the trip level, installing [[Flexible AC transmission system|series compensation]] on [[High voltage|ultra high voltage]] lines and upgrading various monitoring and operational procedures. Other [[public utility|utilities]] in North America and Northern Europe and elsewhere implemented programs to reduce the risks associated with [[geomagnetically induced current]]s.<ref name="HQ_solarstorm"/>
== Military ==
One of the few publicly reported military operations impacted was the [[Australian Army]] component of the [[United Nations]] (UN) [[peacekeeping]] force which was deployed to [[Namibia]] at the time. The storm occurred just as the advance elements of the contingent arrived in Namibia, but the effects were believed to last for weeks afterwards. The [[Australian contribution to UNTAG]] was heavily reliant on HF radio communications which were severely impacted.<ref>{{cite book | last = Horner | first = David | title = Australia and the New World Order: The Official History of Australian Peacekeeping, Humanitarian and Post-Cold War Operations | work = From Peacekeeping to Peace Enforcement: 1988–1991 | publisher = [[Cambridge University Press]] | isbn = 978-0-521-76587-9 | year = 2011 | volume = 2 | url = http://www.cambridge.org/aus/catalogue/catalogue.asp?isbn=9780521765879 | accessdate = 29 July 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | editor-last = Sowry | editor-first = Brendan | title = United Nations Transition Assistance Group (UNTAG) in Namibia | work = Training Information Bulletin Number 63 | publisher = [[Australian Army]] | issue = Draft | publication-date = 1992 | year = 1992 }}</ref>
==Aftermath== In August 1989, another storm caused a halt of all trading on the [[Toronto Stock Exchange]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newscientist.com//article/mg12316812.400-solar-storms-halt-stock-market-as-computers-crash|title=Solar storms halt stock market as computers crash|last=Dayton|first=Leigh|date=1989-09-09|website=New Scientist|access-date=2018-08-01}}</ref>
Since 1996, geomagnetic storms and [[solar flare]]s have been monitored from the [[Solar and Heliospheric Observatory]] (SOHO) satellite, a joint project of [[NASA]] and the [[European Space Agency]].
Because of serious concerns that utilities have failed to set protection standards and are unprepared for a severe solar storm such as the [[Solar storm of 1859|Carrington Event]], the [[Federal Energy Regulatory Commission]] has ordered the [[North American Electric Reliability Corporation]] to create standards that would require power grids to be somewhat protected from solar storms and equipment to be continuously tested for possible effects of solar storms.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/electricity-solar-storms/column-u-s-orders-power-grid-to-prepare-for-solar-storms-kemp-idUSL6N0LN3HU20140218|title=COLUMN-U.S. orders power grid to prepare for solar storms: Kemp|last=Kemp|first=John|editor-last=Brown|editor-first=Veronica|work=Reuters|date=2014-02-18|access-date=2018-08-01|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{cite act|title=Reliability Standards for Geomagnetic Disturbances|type=Order|number=779|date=May 16, 2013|article=Part 40|articletype=18 CFR|page=Federal Energy Regulatory Commission|url=https://www.ferc.gov/whats-new/comm-meet/2013/051613/E-5.pdf|access-date=2018-08-01|ref=}}</ref> Similarly, the [[Nuclear Regulatory Commission]] has begun a phased rule-making, published in the [[Federal Register]], to examine the sufficiency of cooling systems of stored spent fuel rods of nuclear power plants now considered vulnerable to long-term power outages from events such as space weather, high-altitude nuclear burst [[electromagnetic pulse]]s or cyber attacks.<ref>{{Federal Register|77|16175}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of solar storms]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{Solar storms}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Geomagnetic Storm, 1989}} [[Category:Geomagnetic storms|March 1989]] [[Category:1989 natural disasters]] [[Category:Hydro-Québec]] [[Category:Electric power blackouts]] [[Category:1989 in Canada]] [[Category:1989 in science]] [[Category:March 1989 events]]

revision.comment: Corrected a previous edit that incorrectly substituted a year with an age (cleaning up usage as well). Added a citation that corroborates the change.
revision.text:
'''Marvin Hewitt''' (born 1922) was an [[United States|American]] [[impostor]] who became, among other things, a university [[physics]] professor.
Hewitt was a [[high school]] drop-out with no qualifications who wanted to become an academic.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/law/columnists/gary_slapper/article3990945.ece|title=Weird cases: faking it|date=May 23, 2008|publisher=''[[The Times]]''|accessdate=6 January 2010 | location=London | first=Gary | last=Slapper}}</ref> He always used names and identities of real-life people in his impostures. He later claimed that he had a "compulsion to teach".
Hewitt's first imposture began in 1945 when he selected a famous name from a list of university teachers and used it to apply for a position of an aerodynamic engineer. However, the name was too recognizable and he was soon exposed.
The next identity Hewitt adopted was that of [[Julius Ashkin]], a physics professor. He applied and was accepted first into a pharmacological college in [[Philadelphia]] and the next year into teacher's college in [[Minnesota]]. When he began to gain academic fame, the real Ashkin wrote him to suggest that he stop.
Hewitt proceeded to adopt the persona of Georg Hewitt, former chief researcher of [[Radio Corporation of America]]. When he was found out, he switched to that of philosophy professor Clifford Berry.
In 1954, Hewitt was on his fifth teaching job as Dr. Kenneth Yates, an associate professor of physics at the [[University of New Hampshire]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Professor Marvin Hewitt’s Twisting Journey from Dropout to Rocket Scientist | url = http://www.newenglandhistoricalsociety.com/professor-marvin-hewitts-twisting-journey-dropout-rocket-scienti/ | website = New England Historical Society | access-date = December 6, 2017 }}</ref> At that stage two other colleges had discovered that his credentials were false when they noticed that the real Kenneth Yates was currently working for an oil company. They had only removed him from the [[faculty (teaching staff)|faculty]] and the university authorities had decided to let him leave quietly when the details leaked out.
The president of the university, Dr. Robert F. Chandler, had described Hewitt as good physicist with talent for teaching. Officially he was not fired for incompetence but because he had misrepresented his qualifications. He received support from previous and current colleagues who showered praises on him. The [[United States Atomic Energy Commission|U.S. Atomic Energy Commission]] and the [[British Admiralty]] approached him.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}}
Since approximately that time, there have been no reports of any further exploits by Hewitt in the media.
==References== {{reflist}} *{{cite book |title=Impostors: Six Kinds of Liar |last=Burton |first=Sarah |year=2001 |publisher=Penguin |isbn=0-14-028250-5 }} {{refend}} *[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,857410,00.html The Compulsion.] [[Time magazine]]. March 15, 1954 *[https://books.google.com/books?id=PFQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA57&lpg=PA57&dq=Honest+career+for+Ph%28ony%29D&source=bl&ots=kXxlxyHO8n&sig=7HYwWT2xi96tfllc1FgqHG5XQtE&hl=en&ei=NkuLS8WxKYG1tgf8oMSvDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CAgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Honest%20career%20for%20Ph%28ony%29D&f=false Honest career for Ph(ony)D: brilliant hoaxer Marvin Hewitt becomes a respected engineer.] [[Life magazine]]. January 21, 1957, pp. 57–82.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hewitt, Marvin}} [[Category:1922 births]] [[Category:Possibly living people]] [[Category:Impostors]] [[Category:People who fabricated academic degrees]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Italic title}} [[File:Elevationvanda.jpg|thumb|Machine for the fireworks for the peace of Aix la Chapelle in May 1749 performed in Green Park; structure designed by Franco-Italian architect [[Giovanni Niccolò Servandoni]]]] The '''''Music for the Royal Fireworks''''' ([[HWV]] 351) is a [[Suite (music)|suite]] for wind instruments composed by [[George Frideric Handel]] in 1749 under contract of [[George II of Great Britain]] for the fireworks in London's [[Green Park]] on 27 April 1749. It was to celebrate the end of the [[War of the Austrian Succession]] and the signing of the [[Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle (1748)|Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle]] (Aachen) in 1748.
== Rehearsal and final production == During the preparations Handel and the [[John Montagu, 2nd Duke of Montagu|Duke of Montagu]], the [[Master General of the Ordnance]] and the officer responsible for the Royal Fireworks, had an argument about adding violins. The duke made clear to Handel that King George had a preference for only martial instruments and drums, and hoped there would be "no fiddles". Handel omitted the string instruments against his will. Also against Handel's will, there was a full rehearsal of the music in [[Vauxhall Gardens]] and not in Green Park. On 21 April 1749 an audience, claimed to be over twelve thousand people, each paying two [[Shilling (British coin)|shilling]]s and six [[Penny (British pre-decimal coin)|pence]] ([[Half crown (British coin)|half a crown]]) rushed to get there, causing a three-hour traffic jam of carriages on [[London Bridge]], the only vehicular route to the area south of the river.<ref>{{cite book |last=Hunter |first=David |date= |title=The Lives of George Frideric Handel |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Uwc3CwAAQBAJ&pg=PA82&dq=Royal+Fireworks+%22no+fiddles%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjdr4zh3e3XAhVsKsAKHfABCB4Q6AEISDAG#v=onepage&q=Royal%20Fireworks%20%22no%20fiddles%22&f=false |location= |publisher=Boydell & Brewer |page=85 |isbn=978-1783270613 }}</ref>
Six days later, on 27 April, the performing musicians were in a specially constructed building that had been designed by [[Giovanni Niccolò Servandoni|Servandoni]], a theatre designer, who used four Italians to assist him.<ref>Jacob Simon (1985) Handel, a celebration of his life and times, 1685–1759, p. 212. National Portrait Gallery (Great Britain).</ref> [[Andrea Casali]] and [[Andrea Soldi]] designed the decorations. The fireworks themselves were devised and controlled by [[Gaetano Ruggieri]] and [[Giuseppe Sarti]], both from [[Bologna]].<ref name=Hogwood>"The Ruggieri family represents one of the longest surviving dynasties in the pyrotechnical trade; they later fired the celebrations for the French Revolution and were still around to supervise the display in New York Harbour when the Statue of Liberty was rededicated in 1986." [[Christopher Hogwood]] (2005) ''Handel: water music and music for the royal fireworks'' Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, p. 80 {{ISBN|978-0-521-83636-4}}</ref><ref>Great Britain. Board of Ordnance ''A description of the machine for the fireworks, with all its ornaments, and a detail of the manner in which they are to be exhibited in St. James's Park, Thursday, 27 April 1749, on account of the general peace, signed at Aix La Chapelle, 7 October 1748. Published by order of His Majesty's Board of Ordnance''. London: printed by W. Bowyer, sold by R. Dodsley, and M. Cooper. 1749.</ref><ref name=Bomgardner>{{cite book|last1=Bomgardner|first1=David L.|title=The Story of the Roman Amphitheatre|date=2000|publisher=Routledge|location=Abingdon, Oxon.|isbn=113470738X|page=225}}</ref> [[Charles Frederick (MP)|Charles Frederick]] was the controller, captain [[Thomas Desaguliers]] was the chief fire master.<ref name=Plots>{{cite book|last1=Fraser|first1=Antonia [et al.]|title=Gunpowder Plots: A Celebration of 400 Years of Bonfire Night|date=2005|publisher=Penguin Books|location=London|isbn=978-0-14-190933-2}}</ref> The display was not as successful as the music itself: the weather was rainy causing many misfires and in the middle of the show the right [[pavilion]] caught fire. Also, a woman's clothes were set on alight by a stray rocket and other fireworks burned two soldiers and blinded a third. Yet another soldier had blown his hand off during an earlier rehearsal for the 101 cannons which were used during the event.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://londonist.com/2013/03/fire-and-18th-century-traffic-jams-handel-and-the-royal-fireworks |title=Fire And 18th Century Traffic Jams: Handel And The Royal Fireworks |last=Holdsworth |first=Rachel |date=March 2013 |website=londonist.com |publisher=The Londonist Ltd |access-date=3 December 2017 }}</ref>
== Music and instrumentation == ''Music for the Royal Fireworks'' opens with a [[French overture]] and includes a [[bourrée]] and two [[minuet]]s.
The work is in five [[Movement (music)|movements]]:
{{Listen|type=music |filename = George Frideric Handel - Music for the Royal Fireworks 1 (Overture) The sound quality is better music.ogg |title = 1. Overture |filename2 = George Frideric Handel - Music for the Royal Fireworks 2 (Bourre) The sound quality is better music.ogg |title2 = 2. Bourrée |filename3 = George Frideric Handel - Music for the Royal Fireworks 3 (Peace) The sound quality is better music.ogg |title3 = 3. ''La Paix'': Largo alla siciliana |filename4 = George Frideric Handel - Music for the Royal Fireworks 4 (La Rejouissance) The sound quality is better music.ogg |title4 = 4. ''La Réjouissance'': Allegro |filename5 = George Frideric Handel - Music for the Royal Fireworks 5 (Minuet) The sound quality is better music.ogg |title5 = 5. Menuets I and II }}
A [[siciliana]] movement was popular in [[baroque music]].
It was scored for a large wind band ensemble consisting of 24 [[oboe]]s, 12 [[bassoon]]s and a [[contrabassoon]], nine [[natural trumpet]]s, nine [[natural horn]]s, three pairs of [[kettledrum]]s, and side drums which were given only the direction to play ''[[ad libitum]]''; no side drum parts were written by Handel. Handel was specific about the numbers of instruments to each written part. In the overture there are assigned three players to each of the three trumpet parts; the 24 oboes are divided 12, 8 and 4; and the 12 bassoons are divided 8 and 4. The side drums were instructed when to play in ''La Réjouissance'' and the second ''Menuet'', but very likely also played in the ''Ouverture''.
Handel re-scored the suite for full orchestra for a performance on 27 May in the [[Foundling Hospital]]. Handel noted in the score that the violins were to play the oboe parts, the cellos and double basses the bassoon part, and the violas either a lower wind or bass part. The instruments from the original band instrumentation play all the movements in the revised orchestral edition except the ''Bourrée'' and the first ''Menuet'', which are played by the oboes, bassoons, and strings alone.<ref>Preface notes and score Fr. Chrysander, ''Water-Music, Firework-Music, Concertos and Double Concertos for Full Orchestra by George Frederic Handel'', reprinted 1965, Gregg Press Inc., New Jersey, U.S.A.</ref>
== Recordings == There are many recordings. Handel's ''[[Water Music]]'', although it was composed more than thirty years earlier, is often paired with the ''Music for the Royal Fireworks'' as both were written for outdoor performance. Together, these works constitute Handel's most famous music for what we would now consider the orchestra. Older recordings tend to use arrangements of Handel's score for the modern orchestra, for example, the arrangements by [[Hamilton Harty]] and [[Leopold Stokowski]]. More recent recordings tend to use more [[historically informed performance]] methods appropriate for [[baroque music]] and often use authentic instruments.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://gfhandel.org/reviews/waterfireglossa.htm | title=Le Concert Spirituel (on period instruments) | last=Vickers | first=David | date=June 2003 | website=Music for the Royal Fireworks | publisher=gfhandel.org | accessdate=20 April 2014 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140421081719/http://gfhandel.org/reviews/waterfireglossa.htm | archivedate=21 April 2014 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
There are also arrangements for pipe organ, alone or with brass.<ref>{{Cite AV media notes | title=Handel-Biggs: Firework Music (Suite from the Music for the Royal Fireworks) for Organ Solo (with Pipe Organ Registrations) | year=1944 | first=E. Power | last=Biggs | publisher=The B. F. Wood Music Co. Inc |location=New York }}</ref> In 1970, [[José Feliciano]] recorded for his ''Fireworks'' LP part of the work transcribed for classical guitar by himself.
This music was performed under the baton of [[Andrew Davis (conductor)|Andrew Davis]] for the [[Golden Jubilee of Elizabeth II]] on 1 June 2002, at the [[Garden at Buckingham Palace|Buckingham Palace gardens]], complete with fireworks.<ref>{{YouTube|4BQemxvhhDQ|Queen's Jubilee Concerts, Buckingham Palace (2002)}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * {{IMSLP|work=Music for the Royal Fireworks, HWV 351 (Handel, George Frideric)|cname=''Music for the Royal Fireworks''}} *[http://mdz1.bib-bvb.de/~db/0001/bsb00016884/images/ Score] (E-book) of ''Fireworks Music'' (ed. [[Friedrich Chrysander]], Leipzig 1886)
{{George Frideric Handel}}

revision.text:
'''Oraşul de Floci''', also ''Cetatea de Floci'' or ''Târgul de Floci'' is a lost city of [[Wallachia]], now in [[Romania]].
The city was located at the confluence of [[Ialomiţa River]] and the [[Danube]], on the old riverbed of the Ialomiţa. The name meant "The [[Wool|Fleece]] City" in [[Romanian language|Romanian]], as it was an important [[market town]]. The city is first mentioned in 1431 during the rule of [[Dan II of Wallachia]], but probably existed as trading post in the previous century.
It was set on fire by [[Stephen III of Moldavia]] during the wars with Wallachia under the rule of [[Radu The Beautiful]] (who was an ally of the [[Ottoman Empire]]). The city recovered quickly, but it was once again destroyed by the [[Poland|Polish]] and [[Tatars|Tatar]] troops of [[Simion Movilă]].
[[Michael the Brave]], the famous Prince of [[Wallachia]], was presumably born in this city
The city finally decayed due to the [[Russo-Turkish War, 1768-1774]], when most inhabitants fled due to the fighting. In the place of the city was formed the village [[Piua-Petrii]], which was destroyed, in turn, during the floods of early 20th century. Currently, the ruins of the city are located in the territory of the [[Giurgeni]] commune.
==References== *[http://ns.cimec.ro/Arheologie/orasul_de_floci/index.html Institutul de Memorie Culturală - Oraşul de Floci] (accessed 20 December 2005)
==External links== *[http://cimec.cilea.it/ArchWebRo/arh/oras_fl/main_eng.htm A lost city in Medieval Muntenia]

page.title: Reactions to the death of Osama bin Laden

revision.text:
[[File:White House celebrations, May 2 2011.jpg|thumb|right|Americans celebrating after the death of [[Osama bin Laden]] in front of the [[White House]].]] [[File:Ground Zero Memorial 5-1-11.jpg|thumb|right|Memorial at the [[World Trade Center site]] on May 1, 2011, when the death of Osama bin Laden was announced]] [[File:Don't tread on me.jpg|thumb|right|Celebrating with the [[Gadsden flag]], early morning, May 2, 2011, hours after President Obama announced Osama bin Laden's death]]
On May 1, 2011, [[United States President]] [[Barack Obama]] confirmed that [[al-Qaeda]] leader [[Osama bin Laden]] [[Death of Osama bin Laden|had been killed]] in [[Osama bin Laden's compound in Abbottabad|his compound]] in [[Abbottabad]], northeastern Pakistan. Bin Laden's death was welcomed throughout most of the world as a fitting end to a figure who had inspired mass bloodshed, and a positive and significant turning point in the fight against [[al-Qaeda]] and related groups. Those who welcomed it included the [[United Nations]], [[European Union]], [[NATO]], and some nations in Asia, Africa, Oceania, South America, and the Middle East, including [[Yemen]], [[Lebanon]], [[Saudi Arabia]], [[India]], [[Israel]], [[Indonesia]], [[Somalia]], the [[Philippines]], [[Turkey]], [[Iraq]], [[Australia]], [[Argentina]], and the rebel [[National Transitional Council|Libyan Republic]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5h0B4t5TOkA9TulK0IK4JYjRG8UqA?docId=CNG.f6de33d85ff1350769dec913bc2a4047.01|title=Death of Bin Laden: Live report|last=|first=|date=May 2, 2011|work=|accessdate=May 2, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130131013904/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5h0B4t5TOkA9TulK0IK4JYjRG8UqA?docId=CNG.f6de33d85ff1350769dec913bc2a4047.01|archive-date=January 31, 2013|dead-url=yes|publisher=Google News|agency=[[Agence France-Presse]]|arxiv=}}</ref>
His killing was condemned, however, by the [[Hamas]] administration of the [[Gaza Strip]], the [[Muslim Brotherhood]],<ref name="WSJ_SB10001424052748704569404576298362912711604">{{cite news | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704569404576298362912711604 | title = World Cheers Bin Laden Killing, Prepares for Strikes | last = MacDonald | first = Alistair | last2 = Bradley | first2 = Matt | date = May 2, 2011 | work = [[The Wall Street Journal]] | accessdate = May 2, 2011 }}</ref> and the [[Taliban]]. [[Iran]] and the Muslim Brotherhood opined that bin Laden's death removed "the last excuse" for western forces to remain in the Middle East, and urged their withdrawal. The monitoring of Jihadist websites after bin Laden's death, by intelligence agency [[SITE Institute|SITE]], revealed encouragement of attacks in retaliation for his killing.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://montrealgazette.com/news/Osama+Laden+followers+strike+Canada/4713814/story.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110506151349/http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/Osama+Laden+followers+strike+Canada/4713814/story.html|archivedate=2011-05-06|title=Osama bin Laden's followers may strike in Canada|date=May 2, 2011}}</ref>
=={{flag|United States}}== [[File:Crowd at Ground Zero.jpg|right|thumb|Celebratory crowd at Ground Zero following the announcement.]] [[File:Times Square on the night Osama bin Laden killed.jpg|thumb|Woman in [[Times Square]], [[New York City]], celebrating bin Laden's death]] [[File:Flagwaving in Times Square on the night Osama bin Laden killed.jpg|right|thumb|Flagwaving in Times Square on May 2, 2011.]] Even before the official announcement, crowds gathered spontaneously to celebrate outside the [[White House]], where thousands assembled.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://washingtonexaminer.com/local/2011/05/crowds-rejoice-white-house-after-news-bin-ladens-death|title=Crowds Rejoice at White House after News of Bin Laden's Death|author1=Babay, Emily|author2=Hughes, Brian|date=May 2, 2011|work=[[The Washington Examiner]]|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Hundreds of New Yorkers also gathered in [[Times Square]] and at [[World Trade Center site|Ground Zero]], the site of the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2011/05/hundreds_gather_at_ground_zero.html| title=Hundreds Gather at Ground Zero, Times Square|date=May 2, 2011|work=[[The Star-Ledger]]| accessdate=May 3, 2011}}</ref> In [[Dearborn, Michigan]], a suburb of [[Detroit]] with a large [[Muslim]] and [[Arab American|Arab]] population, a small crowd gathered outside the City Hall in celebration, many of them of Middle Eastern descent.<ref>{{cite news|author=Salazar, Evan| url= http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2011/05/01/state/n220658D41.DTL |title=Crowds Gather in NYC, DC after Bin Laden Killed | work = [[San Francisco Chronicle]]|date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011}}{{dead link|date=September 2013}}</ref> From the beginning to the end of Obama's speech, 4,000 tweets per second were sent on [[Twitter]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Twitter Reactions To Osama Bin Laden's Death (Tweets)|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/05/02/osama-bin-laden-death-tweets_n_856119.html |work=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=May 2, 2011|accessdate=May 2, 2011|first=Craig|last=Kanalley}}</ref>
Fans attending a nationally televised ''[[Sunday Night Baseball]]'' [[Major League Baseball]] game between two [[National League East]] [[Mets–Phillies rivalry|rival]]s, the [[Philadelphia Phillies]] and the [[New York Mets]], at [[Citizens Bank Park]] in [[Philadelphia]] initiated [[U-S-A! cheer]]s in response to the news, confusing players and officials alike because no official announcement was made until later.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/mlb/blog/big_league_stew/post/Video-Phillies-fans-chant-8216-U-S-A-8217-?urn=mlb-wp5081|title=Video: Phillies fans chant ‘U-S-A!’ after Osama bin Laden news|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/print?id=6463361&type=story|title=Phillies Crowd Erupts in 'U-S-A' Cheers|date=May 2, 2011| accessdate= May 2, 2011|first=Adam|last=Rubin, Adam| publisher = [[ESPN]]}}</ref> Likewise, at [[WWE]] [[Extreme Rules (2011)|Extreme Rules 2011]], a pay-per-view broadcast emanating from the [[St. Pete Times Forum]] in [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]], [[Florida]], newly crowned WWE Champion [[John Cena]] announced the news to the audience following the event's conclusion, resulting in a massive "U-S-A!" chant from the crowd.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lordsofpain.net/news/wwe/John_Cena_Addresses_Osama_Bin_Laden_s_Death_Following_Extreme_Rules_PPV.html |title=John Cena Addresses Osama Bin Laden's Death Following Extreme Rules PPV |publisher=LordsofPain.net |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120105202306/http://www.lordsofpain.net/news/wwe/John_Cena_Addresses_Osama_Bin_Laden_s_Death_Following_Extreme_Rules_PPV.html# |archive-date=2012-01-05 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | title = Wrestler's bizarre declaration of Osama bin Laden's death | work = The Telegraph | accessdate = 2011-09-15 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/howaboutthat/8490123/Wrestlers-bizarre-declaration-of-Osama-bin-Ladens-death.html | location=London | date=May 3, 2011}}</ref> Students at [[Ohio State University]] celebrated by jumping into Mirror Lake, a tradition done before [[Michigan–Ohio State football rivalry|playing rivals Michigan in football]]. Hundreds of students at the [[University of Notre Dame]], located in [[Notre Dame, Indiana|Notre Dame]], [[Indiana]], spontaneously gathered and celebrated by setting off fireworks, yelling loud chants, and running through busy student centers and libraries, many screaming the entire way through and carrying American flags.<ref>{{cite web |author=Doyle, Megan |url=http://www.ndsmcobserver.com/news/campus-reacts-to-osama-bin-laden-s-death-1.2217544 |title=Campus Reacts to Osama Bin Laden's Death |work=The Observer |date=May 3, 2011 |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320064359/http://www.ndsmcobserver.com/news/campus-reacts-to-osama-bin-laden-s-death-1.2217544# |archive-date=2012-03-20 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Students at the [[University of Southern California]] celebrated on USC's Greek Row, playing the national anthem and blasting fireworks.<ref>{{cite web | author= Zotos, Alexis | url= http://www.atvn.org/index.php/news/story/celebrations_erupt_at_usc_over_bin_ladens_death/ | title= Students Celebrate on USC's Row After News Spreads of Bin Laden's Death – Celebrations Erupt at USC over Bin Laden's Death | work= [[Annenberg TV News]] | date= May 2, 2011 | accessdate= August 11, 2011 | archive-url= https://archive.is/20120724094606/http://www.atvn.org/index.php/news/story/celebrations_erupt_at_usc_over_bin_ladens_death/# | archive-date= 2012-07-24 | dead-url= yes | df= }}</ref> Students from many other universities, including cadets from the [[U.S. Military Academy]] and [[U.S. Air Force Academy]], also celebrated when they got the news.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/nextgen-journal/bin-ladens-dead-college-s_b_856162.html |title=NextGen Journal: How Did Students Respond to Osama's Death at Different Colleges? | work = [[The Huffington Post]] |date=May 2, 2011|accessdate=May 3, 2011}}</ref> [[Indian Americans]] hailed the U.S. Special Forces, and accused Pakistan of sheltering bin Laden and other terrorists.<ref>{{cite web| author = Staff | url=http://post.jagran.com/indians-americans-hail-osamas-killing-say-pakistan-exposed-1304398557 |title=Indian Americans Hail Osama's Killing, Say Pakistan Exposed | work = [[Jagran Post]] |date=May 3, 2011 |accessdate= August 10, 2011}}</ref>
All four [[major television network|major broadcast television network]]s ([[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]], [[CBS]], [[NBC]] and [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]]) interrupted their regularly scheduled programming to cover the news.<ref name=ew52>Hibberd, James (May 2, 2011). [http://insidetv.ew.com/2011/05/01/osama-bin-laden-dead/ "Primetime Interrupted: Osama Bin Laden Dead"]. ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''. Retrieved May 2, 2011.</ref> NBC, most notably, interrupted an episode of the [[Celebrity Apprentice]], hosted by Obama's eventual successor [[Donald Trump]]. Nine television networks in total carried Obama's announcement, watched by 56.5 million Americans, his largest audience since election night.<ref>{{cite news | author = Schechner, Sam | date = May 4, 2011 | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703834804576301821550865988 | title = Obama Drew Big TV Crowd | work = [[The Wall Street Journal]] | accessdate = May 4, 2011 }}</ref>
In addition to the jubilant celebrations, many visitors quietly reflected at the [[Pentagon Memorial]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2011-05-02/news/bs-md-pentagon-memorial-20110502_1_pentagon-memorial-pentagon-attack-world-trade-center |title=Pentagon Memorial Draws Visitors | work = [[The Baltimore Sun]] |date= |accessdate=May 5, 2011}}</ref>
===Current and former officials=== Former U.S. President [[George W. Bush]] said that "this momentous achievement marks a victory for America, for people who seek peace around the world, and for all those who lost loved ones on [[September 11, 2001]]".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2011/05/02/president-george-w-bush-congratulates-obama-bin-laden-killing/ |title=President George W. Bush Congratulates Obama on Bin Laden Killing |publisher= [[Fox News]]|date=April 7, 2010 |accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> Former U.S. President [[Bill Clinton]] described it as "a profoundly important moment for people all over the world who want to build a common future of peace, freedom, and cooperation for our children".<ref>{{cite web |author=McMorris-Santoro, Evan |url=http://tpmlivewire.talkingpointsmemo.com/2011/05/bill-clinton-i-congratulate-the-president-on-death-of-bin-laden.php |title=Bill Clinton: 'I Congratulate The President' On Death Of Bin Laden |work=[[Talking Points Memo]] |date=May 1, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110503184100/http://tpmlivewire.talkingpointsmemo.com/2011/05/bill-clinton-i-congratulate-the-president-on-death-of-bin-laden.php# |archive-date=2011-05-03 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> [[United States Secretary of State|U.S. Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] said: "The fight [against [[terrorism]]] continues, and we will never waver. I know there are some who doubted this day would ever come, who questioned our resolve and our reach. But let us remind ourselves, this is America. We rise to the challenge, we persevere, and we get the job done."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2011/05/162339.htm |title=Remarks on the Killing of Usama bin Ladin |publisher= [[United States Department of State|U.S. State Department]] | author = [[Hillary Clinton|Clinton, Hillary Rodham]] |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 3, 2011}}</ref>
[[Mayor of New York City|New York City Mayor]] [[Michael Bloomberg]] said that he hoped the death of bin Laden "would comfort those who lost loved ones" in the [[September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001 attacks]].<ref name="Trotta">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/02/us-obama-binladen-bloomberg-idUSTRE7410RV20110502|title=Mayor Bloomberg Hopes bin Laden Death Comforts Victims|author1=Trotta, Dan |author2=Philip, Barbara |date=May 2, 2011| publisher =[[Reuters]]|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> Former National Security Advisor and Secretary of State [[Condoleezza Rice]] characterized the news as "absolutely thrilling", adding that she was "overwhelmed with gratitude and continue[s] to be amazed at what our military has achieved".<ref name="MSNReaction">{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/42853022/ns/world_news-south_and_central_asia/|title=Reaction to Bin Laden's Death Flows In|date=May 2, 2011|publisher =[[msnbc.com]]|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> The event was also applauded by past [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] presidential contenders, including former [[Governor of Massachusetts|Massachusetts governor]] [[Mitt Romney]], former [[Governor of Minnesota|Minnesota governor]] [[Tim Pawlenty]], and Senator [[John McCain]].<ref name="Camia">{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/theoval/post/2011/05/reacting-to-death-of-osama-bin-laden-/1|title=Reacting to Death of Osama bin Laden|author =Camia, Catalina |date= May 1, 2011|work=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> Several U.S. senators questioned whether Pakistani authorities knew about bin Laden's presence in Pakistan, and had protected him.<ref name="IBT">{{cite web| url= http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/140393/20110502/osama-bin-laden-pakistan-levin-reid-lieberman.htm|title= Pakistan Has Much To Explain: Sen. Levin|date=May 2, 2011|accessdate=May 2, 2011| work = [[International Business Times]]}}</ref>
On May 12, 2011, former [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] Justice [[John Paul Stevens]], speaking at a [[Northwestern University]] symposium, told the audience that based on his knowledge of the facts, "It was not merely to do justice and avenge Sept. 11, [but] to remove an enemy who had been trying every day to attack the United States.... I haven't the slightest doubt it was entirely appropriate for American forces to act" as they did.<ref>{{cite news | url= https://blogs.wsj.com/law/2011/05/13/justice-stevens-okays-bin-laden-killing/ | author = Bravin, Jess | date= May 13, 2011 | title= Justice Stevens Okays Bin Laden Killing | work = [[The Wall Street Journal]] | accessdate=May 14, 2011}}</ref>
In an interview with ''[[60 Minutes]]'', U.S. Secretary of Defense [[Robert Gates]] said "I worked for a lot of these guys [referring to the eight [[Commander in chief#United States|U.S. commanders-in-chief]] he has worked for during his career]. And this is one of the most courageous calls, decisions that I think I've ever seen a president make. For all of the concerns that I've just been talking about. The uncertainty of the intelligence. The consequences of it going bad. The risk to the lives of the Americans involved. It was a very gutsy call."<ref>{{cite news| title= Robert Gates: The Soldiers' Secretary | url= http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/05/12/60minutes/main20062368.shtml | publisher= [[CBS News]] | date=May 12, 2011 | work= [[60 Minutes]] | accessdate= May 21, 2011}}</ref>
=={{flag|Pakistan}}==
===Government=== Following the death of bin Laden, [[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Asif Ali Zardari]] convened emergency talks with [[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister]] [[Yousuf Raza Gilani]] and security chiefs in [[Islamabad]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dawn.com/2011/05/02/zardari-gilani-security-chiefs-in-emergency-talks.html |title=Pakistan Will Not Allow Use of Its Soil for Terrorism, Says PM |date=May 2, 2011 |work=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]] |accessdate=May 2, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yOIJjv4E?url=http://www.dawn.com/2011/05/02/zardari-gilani-security-chiefs-in-emergency-talks.html |archivedate=May 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Gilani said: "We will not allow our soil to be used against any other country for terrorism and therefore I think it's a great victory, it's a success and I congratulate the success of this operation."<ref name=autogenerated3 /> Later Gilani blamed the world for their failure to capture bin Laden.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/2011/05/04/world-shares-blame-for-failure-on-bin-laden-gilani.html |title=World Shares Blame for 'Failure' on bin Laden: Gilani |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |work=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]] |date= |accessdate=May 5, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110507055155/http://www.dawn.com/2011/05/04/world-shares-blame-for-failure-on-bin-laden-gilani.html |archivedate=May 7, 2011 }}</ref>
