The day after the raid, the Pakistani government lashed out at the U.S., saying that the United States had taken "an unauthorized unilateral action" that would not be tolerated in the future. The foreign ministry further said, "Such an event shall not serve as a future precedent for any state, including the United States."<ref name="NYT20110503">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/04/world/asia/04pakistan.html|title=Pakistan Pushes Back Against U.S. Criticism on Bin Laden|last=Perlez|first=Jane|date=May 3, 2011|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=May 3, 2011}}</ref>
[[Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam (F)|JUI-F]] deputy parliamentary leader Mufti Kifayatullah, in the Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Assembly, declared "Osama is a hero..." and that "The great Muslim heroes are being killed here in Pakistan and it is a matter of shame for the Pakistan Army when the foreign forces come and kill people on our soil."<ref name="TN20110503">{{cite news|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/TodaysPrintDetail.aspx?ID=44885&Cat=7&dt=5/4/2011|title=JUI-F shocked over Osama bin Laden's killing|last=Shah|first=Syed Bukhar|date=May 3, 2011|work=[[The News International]]|accessdate=May 3, 2011}}</ref>
Foreign Secretary [[Salman Bashir]] said, "Any other country that would ever act on assumption that it has the right to unilateralism of any sort will find as far as Pak is concerned that it has made a basic mistake".<ref name="NDTV"/> He further stated that Pakistani military had scrambled [[General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon|F-16s]] after they became aware of the attack but that they reached the compound after American helicopters had left.<ref name="wsj20110505">{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704810504576305033789955132|title=Pakistan Warns U.S. Against Raids |author1=Wright, Tom |author2=Rosenberg, Matthew | date=May 6, 2011|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|accessdate=May 6, 2011}}{{verify source|date=May 2011}}</ref> Bashir also warned the U.S. and India against any such [[Operation Neptune Spear|covert operations]] in the future, saying this would lead to a "terrible catastrophe".<ref name="NDTV">{{cite web| author = Staff | date = May 5, 2011 | url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/world/pakistan-slams-us-for-unilateral-action-warns-india-too-103614|title=Pakistan Slams U.S. for Unilateral Action, Warns India Too|publisher=[[NDTV]] | accessdate = August 9, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/159157/pakistan-warns-us-india-against.html |title= Pakistan Warns US, India Against Covert Operations| agency = [[Indo-Asian News Service]] | work = [[Deccan Herald]] |date= May 5, 2011 |accessdate= August 9, 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://www.stockinvestips.com/2011/05/pakistan-warns-india-us-against.html "Pakistan Warns India, Us Against Invading Its Territory And Further Raids"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519023943/http://www.stockinvestips.com/2011/05/pakistan-warns-india-us-against.html |date=2011-05-19 }}. May 5, 2011.</ref>
Former [[President of Pakistan|Pakistani President]] [[Pervez Musharraf]] criticized the operation, saying, "America coming to our territory and taking action is a violation of our sovereignty, handling and execution of the operation [by U.S. forces] is not correct. The Pakistani government should have been kept in the loop."<ref name="Guard20110502">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/may/02/osama-bin-laden-pakistan-awkward-questions|title=Osama Bin Laden: Dead, But How Did He Hide So Long?|date=May 2, 2011|work= [[The Guardian]]|accessdate=May 2, 2011|author1=MacAskill, Ewen |author2=Walsh, Declan |location=London}}</ref>
Speaking at the [[Lahore Press Club]], former Foreign Minister [[Shah Mehmood Qureshi]] criticised the government and openly demanded an explanation from top officials regarding the incident. He also called for President Zardari and Prime Minister Gillani to resign.<ref name="tribune">{{cite news|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/163842/zardari-and-gilani-should-resign-qureshi/|title=Zardari and Gilani Should Resign: Qureshi|work=[[The Express Tribune]]|date=May 7, 2011}}</ref> Terming the American raid as "unprovoked aggression", Qureshi added that instead of addressing the nation during the crisis, Zardari instead chose to write an opinion piece in a foreign newspaper.<ref name="tribune"/>
Cricketer-turned-politician [[Imran Khan]] said Pakistan had "lost its dignity and self-esteem" in the wake of the Osama operation and lashed out at the government and the intelligence. "The big questions that everyone began asking, and for which no answers have been forthcoming, were: who allowed the Americans to come to Pakistan and carry out this attack? And whatever happened to the [[Pakistani Army]] and its intelligence?"<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2011-05-04/news/29509012_1_pakistani-army-prime-minister-gilani-pakistan-government |title=Pakistan Has Lost Dignity, Self-Esteem Following US' Osama Operation: Imran Khan |work=Economic Times |date=May 4, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120403025839/http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2011-05-04/news/29509012_1_pakistani-army-prime-minister-gilani-pakistan-government |archivedate=April 3, 2012 }}</ref>
===Military=== Pakistan's military officials declined to comment, referring questions to the foreign ministry.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704569404576298433471341062 |title=New Test for U.S.-Pakistan Relations |author=Wright, Tom |date=May 2, 2011 |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |accessdate=May 2, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150321053538/http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704569404576298433471341062 |archivedate=March 21, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> After the operation, Pakistan's [[Inter-Services Intelligence]] admitted that there had been an intelligence failure. An official stated that the same compound had been raided in 2003, but since then had not been monitored.<ref name="BBC20110503x">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-13268517|title=Pakistan Admits Bin Laden Intelligence Failure|date=May 3, 2011|publisher = [[BBC News Online]]|accessdate=May 3, 2011}}</ref> However, this account was disputed by American officials who said that satellite photos show that even as late as 2004, the site was an empty field.<ref name="Reuters20110505">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/05/us-binladen-pakistan-isi-idUSTRE74408220110505|title=Special Report: Why the U.S. Mistrusts Pakistan's Spies| author = Allbriton, Chris|date= May 5, 2011|publisher = [[Reuters]] |accessdate=May 5, 2011}}</ref> Pakistan's Military chief [[Ashfaq Parvez Kayani]] called the operation a "misadventure" and stated that no further raids would be tolerated. In addition he announced that the number of private [[Americans in Pakistan|American military personnel in Pakistan]] will be reduced "to the minimum essential".<ref name="nyt20110505">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/06/world/asia/06react.html|title=Pakistani Army Chief Warns U.S. on Another Raid|last=Perlez|first=Jane|date=May 5, 2011|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=May 5, 2011}}</ref>
According to a statement by [[Pakistan Air Force]] Chief Marshal [[Rao Qamar Suleman]], there had been an air-surveillance failure. Qamar covered the inquiry by saying that the air space was unable to detect the American helicopters because the [[radar]] installed on the western borders were inactive on the day of the incident. The U.S. helicopters also reportedly used radar-evading measures, such as [[stealth technology]], to avoid detection.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.zeenews.com/news704752.html|title=Pak Radars Were Inactive During Osama Raid| publisher = [[Zee News]]|date=May 7, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/secret-radarevading-stealth-helicopters-used-in-commando-raid-20110506-1ec07.html|title=Secret Radar-Evading Stealth Helicopters Used in Commando Raid|work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=May 7, 2011}}</ref>
===Public=== A poll conducted among educated respondents from [[Lahore]], [[Karachi]] and [[Islamabad]] showed that 75% of them disapproved of the U.S. operation and 66% disbelieved that Osama Bin Laden had been killed at the compound in Abbottabad.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/163178/66-of-pakistanis-dont-believe-osama-bin-laden-is-dead-poll/|title=66% of Pakistanis Don't Believe Osama Bin Laden Was Killed: Poll| work = [[The Express Tribune]] | date=May 6, 2011}}</ref> There was also frustration and fierce criticism among the public and in [[Pakistani media]] against the military for its inability and failure in not detecting the American raid and allowing it to occur. A local resident, in reference to the security forces, commented: "This is what they are paid for, to defend the borders, not to run bakeries and banks and real-estate empires."<ref name="bbcnews">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-13311257|title=Pakistan's Army Ridiculed after Bin Laden Raid|publisher = [[BBC News Online]] |date=May 6, 2011}}</ref>
Numerous mobile [[text message]]s were observed doing the rounds in the country, apparently ridiculing the defence agencies for the security lapse.<ref name="bbcnews" /> There was mounting public outrage against President Zardari, who offered no official remarks even five days after the incident.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/TodaysPrintDetail.aspx?ID=45767&Cat=2&dt=5/8/2011|title=Presidency Replies to Army Criticism of Civilians|work=[[The News International]]|date=May 8, 2011}}</ref> Zardari also left for state visits to [[Kuwait]] and [[Russia]] immediately after the operation<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2011%5C05%5C06%5Cstory_6-5-2011_pg7_9|title=Zardari To Visit Kuwait, Russia|work= [[The News International]] |date=May 6, 2011}}</ref> while Prime Minister Gillani left for a three-day state visit to France after the operation as well,<ref>{{cite news| author = Staff | url=http://www.thenewstribe.com/2011/05/02/pm-gilani-to-visit-france-from-may-3/|title=PM Gilani To Visit France from May 3|publisher = [[The News Tribe]] |date=May 2, 2011 | accessdate = August 9, 2011}}</ref> provoking public sentiment that both had got their priorities wrong.
=={{flag|China|name=People's Republic of China}}==
===Government=== The People's Republic of China (PRC) said on Monday evening that the death of Osama bin Laden was "a milestone and a positive development for the international anti-terrorism efforts". [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China|Chinese Foreign Ministry]] spokeswoman [[Jiang Yu]] made the remarks when asked to comment on the killing of the al-Qaida leader.<ref>[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/china/2011-05/03/c_13855711.htm] [[Xinhua News Agency]].</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/china/2011-05/03/c_13855711.htm| title=China Says Bin Laden's Death 'Milestone' for International Anti-Terrorism Efforts|publisher=[[Xinhua News Agency]] | date=May 2, 2011| accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> China supported Pakistan amid growing questions in the U.S. about whether the country was complicit in harboring Osama bin Laden<ref name="spegele1">{{cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704740604576301112983040114 | work= [[The Wall Street Journal]] | author =Spegele, Brian | title=China Defends Pakistan Effort on Terrorism | date=May 4, 2011}}</ref> saying the, "Pakistani government's determination to fight terrorism are staunch and its actions have been vigorous."<ref name="eurasiareview1">Staff (May 15, 2011). [http://www.eurasiareview.com/osama-bin-laden-pakistan-and-china-analysis-15052011/ "Osama Bin Laden, Pakistan and China – Analysis"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516154320/http://www.eurasiareview.com/osama-bin-laden-pakistan-and-china-analysis-15052011/ |date=2011-05-16 }}. [[South Asia Analysis Group]] (via [[Eurasia Review]]). Retrieved August 10, 2011.</ref> [[Premier of the People's Republic of China|Chinese Premier]] [[Wen Jiabao]] discussed the issue with the U.S. in official talks. He asked the U.S. to respect Pakistan's sovereignty, and acknowledge its sacrifices in the war against terror.<ref>[http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/05/19/China-assures-Pakistan-on-partnership/UPI-55161305783120/]. [[United Press International]].</ref> China also indicated that it would be assisting Pakistan in strengthening its Counter-Terrorism efforts, police force and army, with a specific focus on dealing with the specific domestic issues in Pakistan.
===Political analysis=== The vice president of the [[University of International Relations]] stated that bin Laden's death, and the aftermath of such, would not affect Beijing's policies towards Islamabad.<ref name="eurasiareview1"/> Political analyst [[Hasan Askari Rizvi|Hasan Askari]] stated that while the PRC and Pakistan will remain close, China would not risk its relations with the West over it, citing technological and monetary concerns.<ref>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gg3VbghEVKFnXDP7NJbT7L2O9QMg?docId=CNG.dd035276a74a1dfc4910aded0e7a6b3b.b71]. [[Agence France-Presse]] (via [[Google News]]).</ref>
===Public response=== Public reaction in the PRC to the death of Osama bin laden was mixed:<ref name="spegele1"/> an online poll of 500,000 Chinese citizens, conducted by [[Phoenix Television]] indicated that sixty percent agreed that bin Laden's death was a sad event because "he was an anti-US warrior".<ref name="eurasiareview1"/> On the other hand, on [[Sina Weibo]], many Chinese citizens were celebrating bin Laden's death, since his agenda has been responsible for deaths in [[Xinjiang]]. Some tech-savvy Chinese activists and intellectuals even used the event to criticise, or call attention to, PRC's domestic policies.<ref name="spegele1"/>
== {{flag|India}} ==
===Military=== In the wake of [[Operation Neptune's Spear]] there were calls for similar strikes conducted by India against [[Hafiz Muhammad Saeed]] and [[Dawood Ibrahim]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/158519/indias-osama-still-large.html |title=India's 'Osama' Still at Large |work = [[Deccan Herald]] |date= |accessdate=May 12, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-05-03/india/29499048_1_indian-intelligence-special-forces-anti-india |title=Why can't India do a US to the likes of Dawood, Saeed? – Times Of India |publisher=Articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date=May 3, 2011 |accessdate=May 12, 2011}}</ref><ref name="tribune1">{{cite web| author =[[Aditi Phadnis]] |url= http://tribune.com.pk/story/162161/taking-a-lesson-from-the-us-raid-can-india-hunt-down-terrorists-in-pakistan |title=After Bin Laden: 'Can India Hunt Down Terrorists in Pakistan?' | work = [[The Express Tribune]] |date=May 3, 2011 |accessdate=May 12, 2011}}</ref> with Indian Army Chief [[Vijay Kumar Singh|General V K Singh]] telling reporters, "I would like to say only this that if such a chance comes, then all the three arms (of the [[Indian Defense Forces]]) are competent to do this". Indian [[Pradeep Vasant Naik|Air Chief Marshal P V Naik]] said that India has the capability to carry out such surgical strikes against terrorists.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pakobserver.net/detailnews.asp?id=91160 |title=Without Osama |publisher=Pakobserver.net |date=December 13, 2001 |accessdate=May 12, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316084847/http://pakobserver.net/detailnews.asp?id=91160 |archivedate=March 16, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
Following the death of bin Laden in Pakistan, the [[Border Security Force]] of India was put on high alert along India's 553 km border with Pakistan, in Punjab.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-05-02/india/29495146_1_indo-pak-border-indo-pak-border-districts |title=The Times of India, May 2, 2011 |publisher=Articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 12, 2011}}</ref> However, a former Pakistani Air Force commander dismissed this as the rhetoric of "paper tigers", and Indian [[Minister for Home Affairs (India)|Minister for Home Affairs]] [[P. Chidambaram]] cautioned that India might be unable to carry out such an attack because, "We don't have our forces on Pakistani soil. We are not invited there. We don't have any support from Pakistan."<ref name="tribune1"/>
===Public=== The public in [[India]] celebrated the death of bin Laden across its various cities, by thanking and congratulating the United States.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://in.reuters.com/news/pictures/slideshow?articleId=INRTR2LWA6#a=4 |title=Reuters – India Celebrates death of bin Laden |publisher=In.reuters.com |date= May 2, 2011|accessdate=May 10, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gujaratseniors.com/2011/05/ahmedabad-celebrates-death-of-osama-bin.html |title=Ahmedabad Celebrates the death of Osama Bin Laden |publisher=Gujaratseniors.com |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 10, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110512054904/http://www.gujaratseniors.com/2011/05/ahmedabad-celebrates-death-of-osama-bin.html# |archive-date=2011-05-12 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://msnbcmedia.msn.com/j/MSNBC/Components/Slideshows/_production/gss-110502-binladen/gss-110503-osama01-330a.grid-8x2.jpg |title=MSNBC Media – India thanks United States for killing bin laden. |date= |accessdate=May 10, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dakshintimes.com/dakshina-kannada/udupi/news/11051829514/udupi-celebrates-osama-s-death-distributed-sweets.html |title=Dakshin Times – Udupi celebrates Osama's death |publisher=Dakshintimes.com |date=May 3, 2011 |accessdate=May 10, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323084121/http://www.dakshintimes.com/dakshina-kannada/udupi/news/11051829514/udupi-celebrates-osama-s-death-distributed-sweets.html# |archive-date=2012-03-23 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Gowhar |first=Imran |url=http://www.mid-day.com/news/2011/may/030511-Sri-Ram-Sene-terrorist-Osama-Bin-Laden-death-Bangalore.htm |title=Bangalore celebrates bin laden's death |publisher=Mid-day.com |date=May 3, 2011 |accessdate=May 10, 2011}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated6>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Osama+death+leaves+world+with+tough+questions+on+terror/-/539546/1155774/-/5xc4mg/-/ |title=Business Daily – New Delhi celebrating Osama's death |publisher=Businessdailyafrica.com |date= |accessdate=May 10, 2011}}</ref> In the Indian capital [[New Delhi]], crowds gathered in the streets to celebrate the occasion, thanking U.S. President Barack Obama.<ref name=autogenerated6 /> "Festival like celebrations" were seen in [[Ahmedabad]], where people lit firecrackers and burned photographs of bin Laden while shouting slogans.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://in.reuters.com/news/pictures/slideshow?articleId=INRTR2LWA6#a=4 |title=Reuters – India celebrates Osama's death |publisher=In.reuters.com |date= May 2, 2011|accessdate=May 10, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gujaratseniors.com/2011/05/ahmedabad-celebrates-death-of-osama-bin.html |title=Ahmedabad celebrates the death of Osama Bin Laden |publisher=Gujaratseniors.com |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 10, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110512054904/http://www.gujaratseniors.com/2011/05/ahmedabad-celebrates-death-of-osama-bin.html# |archive-date=2011-05-12 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Monday, May 2, 2011 |url=http://www.globalnews.ca/topics/osama/story.html?id=4709329 |title=Global News Canada – India Celebrates the death of Osama |publisher=Globalnews.ca |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 10, 2011}}</ref> People in the coastal town of [[Udupi]] rejoiced on Monday by exchanging greetings and distributing sweets. Celebratory crowds in Udupi, headed by the chief of [[Shiroor Matha]], shouted slogans and burned an [[effigy]] of bin Laden.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfxkutam.com/news.asp?id=3539 |title=SFXKutam – Udupi celebrating Osama's death |publisher=Sfxkutam.com |date=May 6, 2011 |accessdate=May 10, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dakshintimes.com/dakshina-kannada/udupi/news/11051829514/udupi-celebrates-osama-s-death-distributed-sweets.html |title=Dakshin Times, May 3, 2011 – Udupi celebrates Osama's death, distributed sweets |publisher=Dakshintimes.com |date=May 3, 2011 |accessdate=May 10, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323084121/http://www.dakshintimes.com/dakshina-kannada/udupi/news/11051829514/udupi-celebrates-osama-s-death-distributed-sweets.html# |archive-date=2012-03-23 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> In [[Bangalore]], over 100 members of the [[Sri Ram Sene]] converged in [[Freedom Park, Bangalore|Freedom Park]] in a jubilant mood to celebrate with firecrackers and the passing out of sweets to passers-by.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gowhar |first=Imran |url=http://www.mid-day.com/news/2011/may/030511-Sri-Ram-Sene-terrorist-Osama-Bin-Laden-death-Bangalore.htm |title=Mid Day, News – Sri Ram Sene celebrates bin Laden's death in Bangalore |publisher=Mid-day.com |date=May 3, 2011 |accessdate=May 10, 2011}}</ref> The news of bin Laden's death was watched by 42.6 million Indians.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newkerala.com/news/world/fullnews-201593.html |title=New Kerala News |publisher=Newkerala.com |date= |accessdate=May 10, 2011}}</ref>
===Government=== [[Prime Minister of India]] [[Manmohan Singh]] welcomed the news of bin Laden's death, saying, "I welcome it as a significant step forward and hope that it will deal a decisive blow to Al-Qaeda and other terrorist groups. The international community and Pakistan in particular must work comprehensively to end the activities of all such groups who threaten civilized behaviour and kill innocent men, women and children."<ref>{{cite web|title=Prime Minister of India|url=http://pmindia.nic.in/lprel.asp?id=1252|date=May 2, 2011|publisher=Prime Minister's Office}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[Minister for Home Affairs (India)|Minister for Home Affairs]] [[P. Chidambaram]] said that bin Laden hiding near Islamabad was a matter of grave concern for India as evidence the country was a "sanctuary" for terrorists. He called on Pakistan to arrest the "many of the perpetrators of the [[2008 Mumbai attacks|Mumbai terror attacks]], including the controllers and the handlers of the terrorists who actually carried out the attack", who he alleged "continue to be sheltered in Pakistan".<ref>{{cite news|title=India Uses Osama Death to Pressure Pakistan|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704569404576298211101277924|date=May 2, 2011|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | last = Wright | first = Tom }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenewstribe.com/2011/05/02/osamas-killing-evidence-of-terrorists%E2%80%99-%E2%80%98sanctuaries%E2%80%99-in-pakistan/ |title=The NewsTribe, May 2, 2011 |publisher=Thenewstribe.com |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 12, 2011}}</ref><br> [[Minister of External Affairs (India)|Minister of External Affairs]] [[S. M. Krishna]] hailed the killing of bin Laden as "historic" and a "victorious milestone" in the global war against terrorism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newkerala.com/news/world/fullnews-200465.html |title=New Kerala News, May 2, 2011 |publisher=Newkerala.com |date=September 11, 2001 |accessdate=May 10, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/world/2011-05/02/content_12430634.htm |title=ChinaDaily, May 2, 2011 |publisher=Chinadaily.com.cn |date= |accessdate=May 10, 2011}}</ref> The Chief Minister of Gujarat, [[Narendra Modi]], expressed his happiness about bin Laden's death,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.daijiworld.com/news/news_disp.asp?n_id=100858 |title=New Delhi – Now Laden Gone, we should hunt down Dawood Ibrahim (who is believed to be sheltered by Pakistan, in Pakistan) |publisher=Daijiworld.com |date= |accessdate=May 10, 2011}}</ref> and the [[Bharatiya Janata Party]] (BJP) also hailed the news.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/audio-news-video/AV-India/BJP-hails-Osama-s-death-but-says-more-needs-to-be-done/Article2-692504.aspx |title=BJP hails Osama's death |publisher=Hindustantimes.com |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 10, 2011}}</ref> The BJP said that bin Laden was the most dangerous face of global and jihadi terrorism and needed to be punished for his evil ideologies and stressed that his death in Pakistan proved India's repeated assertion that "Pakistan is the epicenter of global terrorism".<ref name="newkerala2001">{{cite web|url=http://www.newkerala.com/news/world/fullnews-200733.html |title=New Kerala News – New Delhi, May 2, 2011 |publisher=Newkerala.com |date=September 11, 2001 |accessdate=May 10, 2011}}</ref> Senior BJP leader [[Sushma Swaraj]] (also the opposition leader in the Indian Parliament) said, "Osama was enemy number one of humanity".<ref name="newkerala2001"/>
==Organizations==
===Supranational union=== * {{flag|European Union}} – the [[President of the European Parliament|European Parliament President]], [[Jerzy Buzek]] said, "We have woken up in a more secure world."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/02/us-binladen-reaction-idUSTRE7411TN20110502|title=Bin Laden's Death Makes the World Safer, Leaders Say|author=Allbritton, Chris|publisher= [[Reuters]]|date=May 2, 2011}}</ref>
===International organizations=== * [[Interpol (organization)|Interpol]] – Interpol's Secretary General [[Ronald Noble]] congratulated the U.S. and its counterparts worldwide for the gathering and sharing of intelligence that permitted the U.S. to locate bin Laden and launch a targeted operation to bring him to justice. He stated that since the death of bin Laden does not represent the demise of al-Qaeda affiliates and those inspired by al-Qaeda, no continent or region of the world is safe from terrorism. He urged the network of Interpol National Central Bureaus and all law enforcement agencies to be on full alert for acts of retaliation from al-Qaeda if they should attempt to prove they still exist.<ref name=interpol01>{{cite web |author=Press release |url=http://www.interpol.int/Public/ICPO/PressReleases/PR2011/PR033.asp |title=Al-Qaeda Dealt Severe Blow by bin Laden Death, But Global Terror Threat Remains High, Says Interpol |publisher=[[Interpol]] |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * The [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation]]'s Secretary General said, "Bin Laden ... was responsible for many unjustified bloodshed and attacks against innocent civilians", and emphasized the OIC's condemnation of terrorism. He stated the necessity of bringing terrorists to justice, but said that counter-terrorism activities should focus on the causes of terrorism.<ref>{{dead link|date=May 2011}} {{cite web|title=Press Release on the Killing of Osama bin Laden|url=http://www.oic-oci.org/topic_detail.asp?t_id=5264|publisher=[[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation]]|accessdate=May 4, 2011}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * {{flag|NATO}} – [[Secretary General of NATO|NATO Secretary General]] [[Anders Fogh Rasmussen]] said the killing of bin Laden is a "significant success" for the security of NATO allies.<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698|title=Osama bin Laden Dead|publisher= [[BBC News Online]] | date=May 2, 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|UN}} – Secretary-General [[Ban Ki-moon]] hailed bin Laden's death as "a watershed moment in our common global fight against terrorism".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/02/us-binladen-un-idUSTRE7414W720110502 |title=U.N. Chief Ban Hails bin Laden Death as Watershed |publisher= [[Reuters]] |date=April 26, 2011 |accessdate=May 3, 2011 | author =Charbonneau, Louis}}</ref>
===Islamic organizations=== * [[Ahmadiyya Muslim Community]] national spokesman [[Harris Zafar]] said: "As a Muslim, I am happy that a known terrorist like Osama bin Laden has been brought down and his reign of terror has come to an end. His actions ran counter to the true, peaceful, message of Islam, and he created so much mistrust and misconception of Islam. I hope other Muslims will realize that he was not a leader of Muslims. He was only a leader of extremists."<ref>{{cite news| author = Zafir, Harris|url=https://live.washingtonpost.com/osama-bin-laden-death-muslim-community-reaction.html|title= Muslims' Reaction to Osama Bin Laden's Death| work = [[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> * The [[Council on American-Islamic Relations]] issued a statement saying: "We join our fellow citizens in welcoming the announcement that Osama bin Laden has been eliminated as a threat to our nation and the world through the actions of American military personnel. ... Bin Laden never represented Muslims or Islam. In fact, in addition to the killing of thousands of Americans, he and Al-Qaeda caused the deaths of countless Muslims worldwide."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/05/01/bin.laden.us.reacts/|title=U.S. Leaders, Political Groups, Welcome News of Bin Laden's Death|publisher= [[CNN]]|accessdate=May 2, 2011|date=May 2, 2011}}</ref> * The [[Islamic Society of North America]] (ISNA) said it "joins all Americans in thanking President Obama for fulfilling his promise to bring Osama Bin Laden, leader of al-Qaeda, and perpetrator of the 9/11 attacks, to justice". ISNA President [[Imam Magid]] said that the "ideology of bin Laden is incompatible with Islam".<ref>{{cite web|title=ISNA Welcomes Justice For 9/11 Victims|url=http://www.isna.net/events/Special-Announcement/ISNA-Welcomes-Justice-For-9-11-Victims---.aspx|accessdate=May 4, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110505232754/http://www.isna.net/events/Special-Announcement/ISNA-Welcomes-Justice-For-9-11-Victims---.aspx#|archive-date=2011-05-05|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> * The [[Muslim American Society]] announced: "Justice has been served." Praying that bin Laden's death will bring solace to all families that have been victimized by al-Qaeda, President [[Ahmed El Bendary]] stated, "His crimes were against all humanity. It is correct and fair that Bin Laden should be held accountable for his crimes".<ref>{{cite web|title=Muslim American Society Responds to the Killing of bin Laden|url=http://www.sovanow.com/index.php?/news/article/muslim_american_society_responds_to_the_killing_of_bin_laden/|accessdate=May 4, 2011}}</ref> * The [[Muslim Brotherhood]] in [[Egypt]] issued a statement in which it condemned bin Laden's killing, calling it an "assassination".<ref name="WSJ_SB10001424052748704569404576298362912711604" /> Muslim Brotherhood second-in-command [[Mahmud Ezzat]], in contrast, said: "Islam is not bin Laden. After September 11, there had been a lot of confusion. Terrorism was mixed up with Islam. In the coming phase, everyone will be looking to the West for just behaviour." He added that, with bin Laden dead, western forces should now pull out of [[Iraq]] and [[Afghanistan]].<ref name=afplive>{{cite news | url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5h0B4t5TOkA9TulK0IK4JYjRG8UqA?docId=CNG.f6de33d85ff1350769dec913bc2a4047.01 | title=Death of bin Laden: Live Report | agency = [[Agence France-Presse]] | publisher = [[Google News]] | accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> * The [[Muslim Judicial Council]], the largest Islamic representative body in [[Islam in South Africa|South Africa]], condemned the way in which bin Laden was killed. The council described bin Laden's death as a failure of justice, saying he should instead have been captured and put on trial, and also that the way the body was buried at sea contradicts Muslim customs and was disrespectful to a community of over a billion people.<ref>{{cite news|author=Eliseev, Alex|title=Muslim Judicial Council Questions bin Laden Killing|url=http://www.eyewitnessnews.co.za/articleprog.aspx?id=64992|accessdate=May 5, 2011|publisher=[[Eyewitness News]]|date=May 4, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110507035617/http://www.eyewitnessnews.co.za/articleprog.aspx?id=64992#|archive-date=2011-05-07|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> * The [[Muslim Public Affairs Council]] expressed great relief over bin Laden's death. MPAC president [[Salam Al-Marayati]] explained: "the elimination of bin Laden represents a swift blow against terrorism." He said that he felt it was a game-changer, but that he did not "think we've achieved victory against terrorism".<ref>{{cite web |author1=Julien, Steve |author2=Ross, Mike |date=May 2, 2011 |title=Muslim Public Affairs Council Greets bin Laden's Death with 'Sense of Relief' |url=http://www.scpr.org/news/2011/05/02/muslim-public-affairs-council-greets-bin-ladens-de/ |publisher=[[KPCC]] |accessdate=August 11, 2011 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120909051138/http://www.scpr.org/news/2011/05/02/muslim-public-affairs-council-greets-bin-ladens-de/# |archive-date=2012-09-09 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *The [[Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigades]] in the [[West Bank]] of the [[Palestinian territories]], the military wing of the [[Fatah]] party, was reported by the [[Ma'an News Agency]] to have mourned bin Laden's death, declaring in a statement: "The Islamic nation was shocked with the news that bin Laden had been killed by the non-believers. He left a generation who follows the education he gave in Jihad. The fighters in Palestine and around the world who have lost their leaders did not stop their mission and will continue in the tutelage of their masters. We tell the Israeli and the American occupiers that we have leaders who have changed history with their Jihad and their steadfastness. We are ready to sacrifice our lives to bring back peace." Ma'an later reported that the group's spokesman denied issuing the statement.<ref>[http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=384230 "Al-Aqsa Brigades: Jihad To Continue Without bin Laden"]. [[Ma'an News Agency]]. May 3, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=384458 "Al-Aqsa Spokesman Denies bin Laden Statement"]. [[Ma'an News Agency]]. May 3, 2011.</ref> * An [[Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]] member said: "This news has been a catastrophe for us. At first we did not believe it, but we got in touch with our brothers in Pakistan who have confirmed it."<ref name=afplive/> *[[Hamas]] denounced the killing of bin Laden: "We condemn the assassination and the killing of an 'Arab holy warrior'. We regard this as a continuation of the American policy based on oppression and the shedding of Muslim and Arab blood."<ref name="latimes.com">{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fgw-bin-laden-hamas-20110501,0,1332635.story |title= Hamas Denounces Killing of bin Laden |work = [[Los Angeles Times]] | author =Parker, Ned |date=May 2, 2011}}</ref> [[Ismail Haniya]], a senior political leader of Hamas and one of two disputed Prime Ministers of the [[Palestinian National Authority]], said: "We condemn any killing of a holy warrior or of a Muslim and Arab person and we ask Allah to bestow his mercy upon him." Ismail al-Ashqar, a Hamas lawmaker, called it "state terrorism that America carries out against Muslims".<ref name="nytimes1">{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/03/world/middleeast/03gaza.html | title = Hamas Condemns the Killing of bin Laden | author = Akram, Fares| work = [[The New York Times]] | date = May 2, 2011}}</ref> :* The [[United States]] and the [[United Kingdom]] condemned Hamas for mourning bin Laden's death and referring to him as a "holy warrior". A U.S. State Department spokesman called the reference "outrageous", and British Foreign Secretary [[William Hague]] echoed that sentiment.<ref name="jpost1">[http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=219060 "US, UK Condemn Hamas for Mourning Death of Osama bin Laden"]. ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]''. May 3, 2011.</ref> * [[Lashkar-e-Taiba]] organized prayer meetings to pay tribute to bin Laden in several Pakistani cities, including [[Lahore]] and [[Karachi]]. * A [[Taliban in Pakistan]] spokesman said: "If he [bin Laden] has been martyred, we will avenge his death and launch attacks against American and Pakistani governments and their security forces... If he has become a martyr, it is a great victory for us because martyrdom is the aim of all of us."<ref name=afplive/> *On May 6, [[Al Qaeda]] confirmed the death of Osama bin Laden in a statement posted on jihadist internet forums. It said, "We also stress that the blood of the mujahid Sheikh Osama bin Laden, may Allah have mercy upon him, weighs more to us and is more precious to us and to every Muslim than to be wasted in vain." The message called upon [[Pakistan]], where bin Laden was discovered, "We call upon our Muslim people in Pakistan, on whose land Sheikh Osama was killed, to rise up and revolt to cleanse this shame that has been attached to them by a clique of traitors and thieves who sold everything to the enemies."<ref>{{cite web|author=<!--[if IE 6]> <![endif]--> |url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/05/06/148081.html |title=Taliban Say bin Laden Death Will Give 'New Impetus' To Fight Against 'Invaders' |publisher= [[Al Arabiya]] |date=May 6, 2011 |accessdate=May 12, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia/2011/05/201156125729467729.html |title=Al-Qaeda Vows Revenge for bin Laden Death |publisher= [[Al Jazeera English]] |date=May 6, 2011 |accessdate=May 12, 2011}}</ref> * On May 13, the Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility for a suicide bombing attack at a [[paramilitary]] academy in [[Charsadda|Charsadda, Pakistan]] that killed 80 people as revenge for the death of bin Laden. A spokesman for the Pakistani Taliban, Ehsanullah Ehsan, called from an undisclosed location saying, "There will be more."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/13/us-pakistan-bombing-idUSTRE74C0GU20110513|title=Bombers Take Bin Laden Revenge in Pakistan; U.S. Ties Cool|publisher= [[Reuters]]|date=May 13, 2011|accessdate=May 15, 2011}}</ref>
=== NGOs === * [[Amnesty International]] had concerns about the nature and circumstances surrounding Osama bin Laden's death. "We are seeking information from the US and Pakistani authorities about how many people were in the compound at the time of the operation, what happened to them and specifically what is the status and current whereabouts of the survivors," said [[Claudio Cordone]], Senior Director at Amnesty International. Since he was unarmed, they raised concerns that there was no attempt to capture him alive. While condemning bin Laden for [[crimes against humanity]], Amnesty International stressed the importance of doing so in compliance with international law. :* Pakistani and U.S. officials responded, saying there were 18 people in the compound. They report that five people were killed, and two women wounded, both of whom were left with at least six children, at the compound. [[Central Intelligence Agency]] Director [[Leon Panetta]] said that, although they were to capture bin Laden if he surrendered, they were authorized to kill. The White House reported that bin Laden resisted arrest.<ref>{{cite web|title=Questions Around Operation Against Osama bin Laden|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/questions-around-operation-against-osama-bin-laden-2011-05-04| publisher = [[Amnesty International]] | accessdate=May 6, 2011}}</ref> * The [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights|U.N. High Commissioner for Human Rights]], [[Navi Pillay]] said, "This was a complex operation and it would be helpful if we knew the precise facts surrounding his killing. The United Nations has consistently emphasized that all counter-terrorism acts must respect international law." Pillay did point out that the U.S. intended to arrest him if possible, and pointed out that taking bin Laden alive was likely to be difficult. Had he been taken to court, Pillay said that, "I have no doubt he would have been charged with the most serious crimes, including the mass murder of civilians that took place on 9/11, which were planned and systematic and in my view amounted to crime against humanity."<ref>{{cite news|title=U.N. Rights Boss Asks U.S. for Facts on bin Laden Killing|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/03/us-binladen-un-rights-idUSTRE7425PR20110503|accessdate=May 6, 2011 | publisher = [[Reuters]]|author =Nebehay, Stephanie|date=May 3, 2011}}</ref> * [[Human Rights Watch]] stated that bin Laden's death "is a reminder of the thousands of innocents who suffer when terrorist groups seek political change through brutal means"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/node/98530 |title=Osama bin Laden's Death |publisher= [[Human Rights Watch]] |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 12, 2011}}</ref> and called on the U.S. government to release more information regarding the operation to clarify whether "it was justified under international law".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/en/news/2011/05/04/killing-osama-bin-laden |title=Killing of Osama bin Laden |publisher= [[Human Rights Watch]] |date=May 4, 2011 |accessdate=May 12, 2011}}</ref> HRW's Asia director said that "if [bin Laden] wasn't shooting at the soldiers, the killing should be investigated",<ref name="Vancouver">{{cite news|url=https://vancouversun.com/news/human+rights+boss+questions+legality+Laden+killing/4725624/story.html|title=UN Human Rights Boss Questions U.S. on Legality of bin Laden Killing|work=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|author=Edwards, Steven|date=May 4, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110506065559/http://www.vancouversun.com/news/human+rights+boss+questions+legality+Laden+killing/4725624/story.html|archivedate=May 6, 2011|df=}}</ref> while Kenneth Roth, HRW's executive director, criticized UN Secretary General [[Ban Ki-moon]] for calling the death an "act of justice", arguing that "even if [the killing was] justified" bin Laden was not given a trial and there was no conviction.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/may/4/human-rights-group-raps-us-bin-laden-killing/ |title=Human Rights Watch Chief: Bin Laden Killing Not 'Justice' | work = [[The Washington Times]] |date=May 4, 2011 |accessdate=May 12, 2011}}</ref> * The [[Red Cross]] said that if it had any issues with the operation, it would contact the governments directly, and handle the situation confidentially. It also stated that it "does not at this stage have enough facts about the operation to assess its legal and/or humanitarian implications".<ref>{{cite web|title=Red Cross Holds Back Judgment on bin Laden Death|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory?id=13537885| publisher = [[ABC News]] | accessdate=May 6, 2011}}</ref> *[[Code Pink]] co-founder, Medea Benjamin writing about the killing of bin Laden in the [[Huffington Post]], says that the United States never had any "justification for invading Iraq", that there is no "justification for continuing the war in Afghanistan", and that in Pakistan, the US "drone attacks are only fueling the violence and creating more Osama Bin Ladens." And she adds, "Let us not sink into a false sense of triumphalism in the wake of Bin Laden's passing."<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/medea-benjamin/osama-bin-laden-is-dead-l_b_856408.html "Osama bin Laden Is Dead; Let the Peace Begin"]. ''[[The Huffington Post]]''.</ref> * [[Cageprisoners]] published an editorial written as [[news satire]] dated May 15, 2021 announcing that "American War Criminal Barack Obama has been killed by Pakistani security forces in the UK."<ref>Weiss, Michael (May 10, 2011). [http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/news/michaelweiss/100087185/barack-obama-is-dead-a-sick-joke-from-moazzam-beggs-cageprisoners-group/ "'Barack Obama is Dead': A Sick Joke from Moazzam Begg's Cageprisoners Group"]. ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''.</ref><ref>Ansari, Fahad (May 9, 2011). [http://www.cageprisoners.com/our-work/opinion-editorial/item/1534-breaking-news-barack-obama-is-dead "Breaking News: Barack Obama Is Dead"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110512042654/http://www.cageprisoners.com/our-work/opinion-editorial/item/1534-breaking-news-barack-obama-is-dead |date=2011-05-12 }}. [[Cageprisoners]].</ref> Cageprisoners followed up with an explanation two days later: "The idea of the piece was to highlight the immorality of extrajudicial killings to those who justify and celebrate the assassination of Osama Bin Laden."<ref>[http://www.cageprisoners.com/our-work/opinion-editorial/item/1544-clarification-of-cageprisoners-piece-on-the-killing-of-barack-obama "Clarification of Cageprisoners Piece on the Fictional Killing of Barack Obama"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110809165000/http://www.cageprisoners.com/our-work/opinion-editorial/item/1544-clarification-of-cageprisoners-piece-on-the-killing-of-barack-obama |date=2011-08-09 }}. [[Cageprisoners]]. May 11, 2011.</ref>
===Media=== Said [[Steve Kroft]] on the May 8, 2011, edition of ''[[60 Minutes]]'', "For more than a decade, bin Laden managed to elude the U.S. military and intelligence establishments, and he taunted three U.S. presidents. That finally ended last Sunday, and the last thing bin Laden saw was a Navy SEAL in the third floor bedroom of his compound in Pakistan."<ref>{{cite news| author = [[Steve Kroft|Kroft, Steve]] | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/05/08/60minutes/main20060876.shtml | title=President Obama on the Mission To Kill bin Laden | work = [[60 Minutes]] | date= May 8, 2011 | accessdate=May 9, 2011}}</ref> According to ''[[The Economist]]'',<ref name="economist110504"/> "The silence of the usual critics of 'illegal', 'extrajudicial', [[targeted killing]] in the wake of America's killing of Osama bin Laden might reflect hypocrisy, sure. But this can be tough to distinguish from resignation to the fact that Mr Obama didn't submit his case for executing Mr bin Laden to some global civil authority because there isn't one and he didn't have to—because America's the biggest kid on the block and, ultimately, what America says goes. And, if it comes down to it, Britain, France, Italy, Russia and other powerful governments hope America will indulge their own kill-squad adventures with similar approving silences. Of course, if some aggrieved faction in the future seeks retribution through the targeted killing of one of these countries' leaders, that will be raw vengeance, that will be terrorism, that will be an [[crime against international law|international crime]], because, like it or not, that's how it works."
[[George Will]] suggested that America could use bin Laden's death to "draw a deep breath and some pertinent conclusions", among them that "bin Laden was brought down by intelligence gathering that more resembles excellent police work than a military operation." He added, "There remains much more to al-Qaeda than bin Laden, and there are many more tentacles to the terrorism threat than al-Qaeda and its affiliates. So 'the long war' must go on. But perhaps such language is bewitching our minds, because this is not essentially war."<ref>[[George Will|Will, George]] (May 3, 2011). [http://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/opinion/fl-gwcol-osama-bin-ladendead-will-05020110503-3,0,5301244.story "George Will: Osama bin Laden's Death a Time for America To Re-evaluate Its Role in the World"]. ''[[South Florida Sun-Sentinel]]''.</ref>
== Countries and territories==
=== Africa === {| class="wikitable" ! bgcolor="#efefef" column width=125px|Nation ! bgcolor="#efefef" class=unsortable|Response |- | {{flag|Ethiopia}} | Office of Communication Affairs of the Government statement: "Ethiopia feels and shares the agony and suffering of nations who lose citizens to senseless terrorist attacks... The Ethiopian Government salutes all parties involved in this operation, particularly the US anti-terrorist operatives, for hunting and destroying this unrepentant leader of an international terrorist organization. Although the death of Osama Bin Laden does not mean the end the anti-terrorist struggle, it is, nonetheless, a big victory for the global anti-terrorist forces.... [O]n this happy occasion, we congratulate the entire people of America and the Government of the United States. In our own immediate vicinity, Bin Laden's Al-Qaeda has wreaked havoc in stateless Somalia, killed and maimed many innocent people in Kenya and [[Tanzania]], and has for years been engaged in terrorist activities aimed at destabilizing the [[Horn of Africa]]."<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.newbusinessethiopia.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=485:ethiopia-welcomes-death-of-osama-bin-laden&catid=12:internal-politics&Itemid=5 |title= Ethiopia Welcomes Death of Osama Bin Laden |publisher=New Business Ethiopia|date=|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Kenya}} | [[Kenyan Prime Minister]] [[Raila Odinga]] said, "It's a major achievement in the war against terrorism." The Kenyan President, [[Mwai Kibaki]], called his killing an, "act of justice to those Kenyans who lost their lives and the many more who suffered injuries" referencing the [[1998 United States embassy bombings|bombings in Nairobi]], believed to be the work of Al Qaeda.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-13256956|title=Osama Bin Laden's death: Reaction in quotes |publisher=[[BBC News Online]] |date=May 3, 2011|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> "We should not celebrate the killing of Osama to the point where we forget to take precautions," said [[Joseph Kamotho]], Kenyan Cabinet Minister. "The world needs to be vigilant because al-Qaida has a strong network and they may plan to retaliate." Kenyans injured in the bombings expressed relief and celebration upon hearing the news.<ref>{{cite news|title=Osama bin Laden death: Kenya celebrates but fears retaliation|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/may/02/osama-bin-laden-kenya-celebrates|accessdate=May 15, 2011 |work= [[The Guardian]]|first1=Murithi|last1=Mutiga|first2=David|last2=Smith|date=May 2, 2011|location=London}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Liberia}} | The Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued a statement expressing the Liberian government's "profound delight" over the killing, saying that "the Liberian Government views this remarkable development as a positive achievement towards the fight against terrorism as well as the attainment and promotion of global peace and stability."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mofa.gov.lr/press.php?news_id=366|title=Liberian Government expresses delights over the death of Al-Qaeda Leader, Osama Bin Laden|publisher=Liberian Ministry of Foreign Affairs|date=May 3, 2011|accessdate=June 14, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Libya}} | [[National Transitional Council]] – Colonel [[Ahmed Omar Bani]], a spokesman for the rebel military at the time fighting against forces loyal to [[Libya]]n ruler [[Muammar Gaddafi]], said that "We are very happy" to hear the news of bin Laden's death, and considered bin Laden as another enemy fighting against the rebels. Bani added that he wished Gaddafi would suffer the same fate as bin Laden, saying, "We want the Americans to do the same to Gaddafi."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2011/05/02/idINIndia-56707720110502| title=Libya rebels: Gaddafi should face Bin Laden's fate| publisher=Reuters | date=May 2, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Morocco}} | Communications Minister Khalid Naciri said that "the entire world suffered from bin Laden and the organization he created". The Moroccan government also believes that an al-Qaeda affiliated group was responsible for the April 28, [[2011 Marrakech bombing]].<ref name="voanews.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/africa/Africans-React-to-Death-of-Osama-bin-Laden-121105964.html |title=Africans React to Death of Osama bin Laden|publisher=Voice of America |date=August 20, 2009 |accessdate=May 3, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Nigeria}} | Security consultant Evawere Oyede said that there was a "mixed" reaction in Nigeria towards bin Laden after his death. Oyede elaborated by saying, "Some people see it as a relief. While some people see it as a man who was trying to fight the [[Western world]]. Many people saw Osama as a hero."<ref>{{cite web|title=Africans React to Death of Osama bin Laden|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/africa/Africans-React-to-Death-of-Osama-bin-Laden-121105964.html|accessdate=May 4, 2011}}</ref> The country's Chief of Police, Hafiz Ringim, announced that Nigeria was put on red alert following bin Laden's death.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nigeria On Red Alert After Bin Laden's Death|url=http://www.agi.it/english-version/world/elenco-notizie/201105031850-cro-ren1084-nigeria_on_red_alert_after_bin_laden_s_death|accessdate=May 4, 2011|archive-url=https://archive.is/20110916191243/http://www.agi.it/english-version/world/elenco-notizie/201105031850-cro-ren1084-nigeria_on_red_alert_after_bin_laden_s_death#|archive-date=2011-09-16|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Somalia}} | Somali Prime Minister [[Mohamed Abdullahi Mohamed]] hailed the death of bin Laden by saying, "We welcome the operation which U.S. intelligence carried and killed the leader of al-Qaeda, Bin Laden, who already confessed he was the mastermind of mass killing in different places in the world." The Prime Minister also "accused Bin Laden for providing huge support to the [[Al-Shabaab (militant group)|Al-Shabaab]] group". He also added that "Somalia is the real victim of Osama's war ideology".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.raxanreeb.com/?p=94594 |title=Somalia government hails the death of Sheikh Osama Binu Laden |publisher=[[raxanreeb]] |date=May 3, 2011 |accessdate=May 3, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725072114/http://www.raxanreeb.com/?p=94594# |archive-date=2011-07-25 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Somali president [[Sharif Sheikh Ahmed]] welcomed the death of Bin laden saying he was instrumental in the problems of Somalia and that peace will prevail in Somalia as a result of the killing of bin Laden. Hundreds of [[Mogadishu]] residents rallied in the streets to celebrate the death of bin Laden, during which some people burnt the flag of al-Qaeda.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-05/04/c_13858917.htm |title=Hundreds rally in Mogadishu to celebrate death of Osama Bin Laden|publisher= |date=May 4, 2011 |accessdate=}}</ref> |- | {{flag|South Africa}} | The [[Department of International Relations and Cooperation]] issued a statement that the government "has noted the news of the passing on of Mr. Osama bin Laden as announced" and reaffirmed the country's support for stemming the "demon of terrorism, in all its manifestations", using "the system of global governance of multilateralism".<ref name=rsatimes01>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/local/article1046921.ece/Stop-demon-of-terror--government |title=Stop 'demon of terror': government |publisher=[[The Times (South Africa)|The Times]] |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref><ref name=mg01/> The governing [[African National Congress|ANC]]'s national spokesperson, [[Jackson Mthembu]], refused to comment the news and said that the ANC will not issue a formal statement, until there is evidence of the dead body, claiming that "even President Obama hasn't seen the body".<ref name=mg01>{{cite web|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2011-05-02-muted-local-reaction-to-bin-laden-death |title=Muted SA Reaction to Bin Laden Death | work =[[Mail & Guardian]] |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> The leader of the ruling party's youth wing, [[Julius Malema]], condemned the killing.<ref name=rsatimes03>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2011/05/05/malema-condemns-bin-laden-s-killing |title=Malema condemns Bin Laden's killing |publisher=[[The Times (South Africa)|The Times]] |date=May 5, 2011 |accessdate=June 29, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140629192354/http://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2011/05/05/malema-condemns-bin-laden-s-killing |archivedate=June 29, 2014 |deadurl=no}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Uganda}} | Uganda's government described bin Laden's death as a "momentous event". Spokesman Fred Opolot pledged that "Ugandan troops in an [[African Union]] force in Somalia will continue to fight the al-Qaeda affiliated al-Shabaab militia".<ref name="voanews.com"/> "The death of Bin Laden hopefully will bring about a new era," Kintu Nyango said, on behalf of the Ugandan President. "The world will become a better place."<ref>{{cite news|title=For Many Africans, Bin Laden's Death was a Long Time Coming|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/03/world/africa/03reax.html|accessdate=May 15, 2011 | work= [[The New York Times]]| author =Gettleman, Jeffrey|date=May 2, 2011}}</ref> |- |}
=== Americas === {| class="wikitable" ! bgcolor="#efefef" column width=125px|Nation ! bgcolor="#efefef" class=unsortable|Response |- | {{flag|Argentina}} | President [[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner]] addressed a letter to President Obama in which she highlighted the ongoing threat of terrorism as a central issue in today's society, and expressed her wish that the news of Bin Laden's death not hinder hopes for peace in the Middle East; "Bin Laden's activities," she concluded, "are repudiated by all people and nations who truly believe in the dignity of the human condition, and we stand in support of all his victims."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m24digital.com/2011/05/02/argentina-repudio-el-terrorismo-en-un-comunicado-a-eeuu-por-la-muerte-de-bin-laden/ |title=Argentina repudió el terrorismo en un comunicado por la muerte de Bin Laden |publisher=M24 Digital }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> The Governor of [[Buenos Aires Province]], [[Daniel Scioli]], considered the capture of Bin Laden a step forward in the war against terror; the nation's Chief of the Ministers' Cabinet, [[Aníbal Fernández]], announced that Argentina would take the threat of counter-attacks by al-Qaeda seriously.<ref>[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1370013-anibal-sobre-eventuales-represalias-no-me-asusta-pero-debemos-ser-cuidadosos Aníbal sobre eventuales represalias: "No me asusta, pero debemos ser cuidadosos"] {{es icon}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Brazil}} | [[Ministry of External Relations (Brazil)|Brazilian Foreign Minister]] [[Antonio Patriota]] said that, "We're very worried that there will be reprisals. We hope that this event doesn't trigger an attack."<ref name="autogenerated5">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-13256956 |title= Osama Bin Laden's Death: Political Reaction in Quotes |publisher= [[BBC News Online]] |date= May 3, 2011|accessdate=May 5, 2011}}</ref> but added that it was "important and positive" with the Arab world calling for increased freedom of expression. He continued, "Insofar as Al Qaeda and Osama bin Laden were and remain behind political strategies that prioritize acts of terrorism, (the Brazilian government) can only express our solidarity with the victims and with those who seek justice." <ref>{{cite web|title=Brazil: Bin Laden's Death Is 'Important and Positive' |url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/americas/news/article_1636558.php/Brazil-Bin-Laden-s-death-is-important-and-positive |publisher=[[Monsters and Critics]] |accessdate=May 15, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110506050527/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/americas/news/article_1636558.php/Brazil-Bin-Laden-s-death-is-important-and-positive |archivedate=May 6, 2011 |df= }}</ref> |- | {{flag|Canada}} | [[Prime Minister of Canada|Canadian Prime Minister]] [[Stephen Harper]] said that the death of bin Laden "secures a sense of justice for the families of the 24 Canadians murdered (on September 11, 2001)" and said that "Canada receives the news of the death of Osama bin Laden with sober satisfaction".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/inside-politics-blog/2011/05/reaction-to-death-of-osama-bin-laden.html |title=Obama, Harper statements on death of Osama bin Laden | author = Chris Carter |publisher=CBC News |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> The Canadian government also urged caution, for those Canadians in Pakistan, citing security concerns in a volatile environment. Those whose lives were affected by the September 11 attacks expressed a feeling of closure, or muted victory.<ref>{{cite news|title=Canadians react to bin Laden's death|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/story/2011/05/02/harper-reaction.html|accessdate=May 15, 2011|newspaper=CBC News|date=May 2, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Chile}} | President [[Sebastián Piñera]] celebrated the death of bin Laden, saying he spoke with President Obama to express his satisfaction with the operation. He said he was "glad that the whole world learned that, though late, justice arrives, and that crimes committed against innocent people around the world will not go unpunished".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emol.com/noticias/nacional/detalle/detallenoticias.asp?idnoticia=479437 |title=Piñera comenta diálogo con Obama y celebra ataque que acabó con Bin Laden |publisher=Emol.com |date= |accessdate=May 5, 2011}}</ref> Foreign Minister Alfredo Moreno hailed the death of bin Laden as "a very important advancement in the war against terrorism".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.santiagotimes.cl/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=21361:chile-minister-on-bin-ladens-death-a-very-important-advance-in-the-war-on-terrorism-&catid=19:other&Itemid=142 |title=Chile Minister On Bin Laden's Death: A Very Important Advance In The War On Terrorism |publisher=Santiagotimes.cl |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Colombia}} | [[President of Colombia|Colombian President]] [[Juan Manuel Santos]] congratulated Obama, stating in a press release that the raid "proves once again that terrorists, sooner or later, always fall. In the global fight against terrorism there is only one way: to persevere, persevere and persevere."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://colombiareports.com/colombia-news/news/15970-santos-congratulates-obama-for-death-of-bin-laden.html |title=Santos congratulates Obama for Bin Laden's death|publisher=Colombia Reports |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Cuba}} | Former President of Cuba [[Fidel Castro]] stated that "whatever the actions attributed to bin Laden, the assassination of an unarmed human being surrounded by his family constitutes an abhorrent act". While criticizing bin Laden for international terrorism, he called the attack an "execution". He added that Pakistan's laws had been violated, and that its "national dignity [was] offended".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-05-05/world/cuba.castro.bin.laden_1_bin-unarmed-man-fidel-castro?_s=PM:WORLD |title=Fidel Castro Slams 'Assassination' of Unarmed Bin Laden|publisher= [[CNN]] |date=May 5, 2011 |accessdate=May 7, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Ecuador}} | Ecuador's Foreign Minister Ricardo Patiño commented on bin Laden's death by stating, "If the United States managed to kill Bin Laden, they can celebrate it. I'm not celebrating anyone's death."<ref name="autogenerated5"/> |- | {{flag|Mexico}} | [[Secretariat of Foreign Affairs (Mexico)|Foreign Secretary]] [[Patricia Espinosa Cantellano]] said, "It is of great importance in efforts to free the world from the scourge of terrorism, which threatens peace and security, particularly one who leads one of the most ruthless and bloody terrorist organizations in the world."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sre.gob.mx/csocial/contenido/comunicados/2011/abr/cp_136.html |title=Press=136 |publisher=SRE |date=May 2, 2011 |df= }}{{dead link|date=August 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Peru}} | [[President of Peru|Peruvian President]] [[Alan García]] credited the death of bin Laden to late and recently beatified [[Pope]] [[John Paul II]], saying, "His first miracle was to remove from the world the incarnation of evil, the demonic incarnation of crime and hatred..." He also said that bin Laden's death "vindicates [former U.S. President] [[George W. Bush]]'s decision to punish Bin Laden and patiently continue this work that has borne fruit".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2011/05/02/general-lt-bin-laden-peru-john-paul-ii_8445463.html |title=Peru leader credits late pope for bin Laden death |publisher=Forbes.com |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110504230241/http://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2011/05/02/general-lt-bin-laden-peru-john-paul-ii_8445463.html |archivedate=May 4, 2011 }}</ref> |- | {{flag|Venezuela}} | Vice President [[Elias Jaua]] condemned the killing and subsequent celebrations, saying: "It surprises me to no end how natural crime and murder [have] become, how [they are] celebrated". He added: "At least before imperial governments were more subtle." Jaua elaborated this, stating that now the deaths, both of people working outside the law and of families of presidents (an apparent reference to [[Saif al-Arab Gaddafi]], a target of the [[2011 Libyan civil war]] who had been killed the day prior to bin Laden's death) "are openly celebrated by the leaders of the nations that bomb them".<ref>{{cite news | url = https://blogs.wsj.com/dispatch/2011/05/02/venezuela-official-condemns-celebrations/ | title = Venezuela Official Condemns Celebrations | work = [[The Wall Street Journal]] | date = May 2, 2011 | author = Vyas, Kejal | quote = [I]t is surprising how the crime and killing has become normal and was celebrated.<br/>Now the death of any individual, that has been accused–and not just elements outside the law like Osama bin Laden, but presidents, the families of a president–are openly celebrated by the heads of governments that bomb. }}</ref><ref>[http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/may/2/venezuela-vp-slams-bin-laden-murder/ Venezuela VP slams bin Laden 'murder'], Washington Times May 2, 2011. "It surprises me to no end how natural crime and murder has become, how it is celebrated. At least before, imperial governments were more subtle. Now the death of anyone, based on what they are accused of, but not only those working outside of the law like bin Laden, but also presidents, the families of presidents, are openly celebrated by the leaders of the nations that bomb them."</ref><ref>[http://somoslanoticia.com/secciones/nacionales/vicepresidente-no-deja-de-sorprender-como-se-ha-naturalizado-el-asesinato-y-como-se-celebra/?not=4170 No deja de sorprender cómo se ha naturalizado el asesinato y cómo se celebra] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110827144307/http://somoslanoticia.com/secciones/nacionales/vicepresidente-no-deja-de-sorprender-como-se-ha-naturalizado-el-asesinato-y-como-se-celebra/?not=4170 |date=2011-08-27 }}. Somos la Noticia. May 2, 2011. "No deja de sorprender cómo se ha naturalizado el crimen y el asesinato, y cómo se celebra. Antes, por lo menos los gobiernos imperiales guardaban la forma. Ahora la muerte de cualquier individuo, aparentemente de lo que se le acuse, pero no sólo de elementos fuera de la legalidad como Osama bin Laden, sino de presidentes, de las familias de presidentes, son abiertamente celebradas por los jefes de los gobiernos que bombardean."</ref> |- |}
=== Asia === {| class="wikitable" ! bgcolor="#efefef" column width=125px|Nation ! bgcolor="#efefef" class=unsortable|Response |- | {{flag|Afghanistan}} | [[President of Afghanistan]] [[Hamid Karzai]], speaking on the death of bin Laden, said, "It's wonderful. It's great news", elaborating that bin Laden has "been one of the key enemies of humanity, civilization, and it's really been a major problem for the human race".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/world/51731550-68/afghanistan-bin-killing-laden.html.csp|title=Afghanistan reacts to bin Laden killing |publisher=The Salt Lake Tribune|date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> He emphasized that "Afghanistan was right" in saying that "the fighting against terrorism is not in the villages of Afghanistan, not among the poor people of Afghanistan", but in "safe havens",<ref>{{cite news|url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/may/02/osama-bin-laden-afghanistan-fears|title = Osama bin Laden dead: US strategy misconceived, says Hamid Karzai|author = Jon Boone| work = [[The Guardian]] |date= May 2, 2011|location=London}}</ref> and called on the Taliban to lay down their arms. |- | {{flag|Armenia}} | Armenian spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Tigran Balayan, said: "Being involved in the struggle of the international community against terrorism, we share the feelings of Americans and all other, who fight terrorism, regarding the extermination of Bin Laden".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.armradio.am/eng/news/?part=pol&id=19911 |title=Armenian MFA comments on Bin Laden extermination |publisher=Armradio.am |date=May 6, 2011 |accessdate=May 13, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Bangladesh}} | The Foreign Office of Bangladesh praised bin Laden's death as "a major development" and pledged to continue its efforts in the global fight against terrorism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mangalorean.com/news.php?newstype=local&newsid=236264 |title=Osama's Death a Major Development, Says Bangladesh |publisher=Mangalorean.com |date=May 3, 2011 |accessdate=May 13, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Indonesia}} | Ansyaad Mbai, the head of Indonesia's [[Counter-terrorism|counter-terrorist]] agency, said that bin Laden's death "would bring positive impact" and that "it would reduce movements organized by radical groups since their main figure had died".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://maxwellreyes.com/2011/05/bin-ladens-death-to-reduce-terror-acts-in-indonesia-official/ |title=Bin Laden's Death To Reduce Terror Attacks in Indonesia: Official |publisher=Maxwellreyes.com |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110506201432/http://maxwellreyes.com/2011/05/bin-ladens-death-to-reduce-terror-acts-in-indonesia-official/# |archive-date=2011-05-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> |- | {{flag|Japan}} | [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Japan)|Japanese Foreign Minister]] [[Takeaki Matsumoto]] said, "I pay respect to the US officials concerned. While his death was confirmed, it does not mean that terrorism was eliminated."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/world/usa/global-reaction-following-bin-laden-s-death-1.802070|title=Global Reaction Following Bin Laden's Death| work = [[Gulf News]]}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Kazakhstan}} | The [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Kazakhstan)|Kazakh Foreign Ministry]] issued a statement saying that the death of bin Laden was a "major blow to international terrorism."<ref>{{cite web|title=Kazakhstan calls bin Laden death 'major blow to international terrorism'|publisher=Central Asia Newswire|date=May 3, 2011|url=http://centralasianewswire.com/Kazakhstan/Kazakhstan-calls-bin-Laden-death-lsquomajor-blow-to-international-terrorismrsquo/viewstory.aspx?id=3967|accessdate=May 6, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Malaysia}} | [[Ministry of Home Affairs (Malaysia)|Malaysian Home Minister]] [[Hishammuddin Hussein]] said he hoped that the death of bin Laden would help bring universal peace and harmony.<ref name="malaysia52">{{cite news|url=http://www.bernama.com/bernama/v5/newsindex.php?id=583376|title=- Hishammuddin Hopes Osama's Death Would Bring About Universal Peace|date=May 2, 2011|work=[[Bernama]]|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Nepal}} | Ministry of Foreign Affairs said, "The war against terrorism has always remained a priority of Nepal's government and we take bin Laden's death as a victory against terrorism".<ref name="nepal01">{{cite news|url=http://nepalnews.com/archive/2011/may/may02/news20.php|title=Govt welcomes bin Laden's death|date=May 3, 2011|accessdate=May 3, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110823030924/http://nepalnews.com/archive/2011/may/may02/news20.php#|archive-date=2011-08-23|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Philippines}} | [[President of the Philippines|Philippine President]] [[Benigno Aquino III]] praised Barack Obama and said, "The death of Osama bin Laden marks a signal defeat for the forces of extremism and terrorism",<ref>{{cite web|title=Batangas Today: World leaders' reactions on Osama bin Laden's death|url=http://www.batangastoday.com/world-leaders-reactions-on-osama-bin-ladens-death/12580/|date=|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> while the [[Philippine National Police]] described bin Laden's death as "a victory for all peace loving citizens and a major blow to terrorists and terrorism". Authorities in the Philippines believe that there are people who are linked to bin Laden's al-Qaeda network and may commit a retaliation attack.<ref name="ph502">{{cite news|title=PNP: Osama's Death a Major Blow to Terrorism |url=http://www.gmanews.tv/story/219327/nation/pnp-osamas-death-a-major-blow-to-terrorism |publisher=[[GMA News and Public Affairs|GMA News]] |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011 |archivedate=May 2, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yNSx4g6C?url=http://www.gmanews.tv/story/219327/nation/pnp-osamas-death-a-major-blow-to-terrorism |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> |- | {{flag|Singapore}} | The [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Singapore)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] said, "the killing of Osama bin Laden ... is a significant milestone in the struggle against international terrorism."<ref name="CNA20110502">{{cite news|title=Singapore says Osama's death is a significant milestone against terrorism |url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/1126246/1/.html |publisher=[[Channel NewsAsia]] |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110503042245/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/1126246/1/.html |archivedate=May 3, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> |- | {{flag|South Korea}} | A spokesman for President [[Lee Myung-bak]] said, "Our government welcomes and supports the efforts shown by the U.S. government through this operation to eradicate terrorism."<ref>{{cite news|title=SK's Lee Praises U.S. Strike on Bin Laden|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/korearealtime/2011/05/02/sks-lee-praises-u-s-strike-on-bin-laden/ | author = Ramstad, Evan | work = [[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=May 2, 2011|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Turkey}} | President [[Abdullah Gul]] welcomed the news of bin Laden's death, and said, "It should teach a lesson to terrorist organisations of the world; that the leader of the world's most dangerous and sophisticated terrorist organization is captured this way."<ref name="reactions"/> |- | {{flag|Vietnam}} | Nguyen Phuong Nga, a spokeswoman for the [[Foreign relations of Vietnam|Foreign Ministry of Vietnam]] said this when asked about the death of bin Laden, "Terrorists must bear responsibility for their acts and should be severely punished". She continued, "Vietnam will continue to join the international community in the fight against terrorism, based on the UN Charter and the basic principles of international law, to eliminate terrorism".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cpv.org.vn/cpv/Modules/News_English/News_Detail_E.aspx?CN_ID=457661&CO_ID=30253 |title=Vietnam Condemns All Forms of Terrorist Acts |publisher=[[Communist Party of Vietnam]] |date=December 1, 2005 |accessdate=May 12, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929021103/http://www.cpv.org.vn/cpv/Modules/News_English/News_Detail_E.aspx?CN_ID=457661&CO_ID=30253# |archive-date=2011-09-29 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> |- |}
=== Europe ===
====Eastern Europe==== {| class="wikitable" ! bgcolor="#efefef" column width=125px|Nation ! bgcolor="#efefef" class=unsortable|Response |- | {{flag|Czech Republic}} | [[Czech Prime Minister]] [[Petr Nečas]] said that bin Laden's death "is a significant milestone in the fight against terrorism, in the effort to achieve a more secure world, though it is far from its end. It is an important symbolic message to the survivors of victims of terrorist attacks by Al-Qaeda and a clear signal to all parties without respect for law and human lives anywhere in the world: human life is irreplaceable, but its wasting won't stay unpunished."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://zpravy.ods.cz/prispevek.php?ID=16575 |title=''Petr Nečas: Prohlášení předsedy vlády ke smrti Usámy bin Ládina'' |publisher=zpravy.ods.cz |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011 |language=Czech |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727143848/http://zpravy.ods.cz/prispevek.php?ID=16575# |archive-date=2011-07-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> [[President of the Czech Republic|Czech President]] [[Václav Klaus]] said, "I accept this message about the destruction of a symbol of world terrorism, Osama bin Laden, with great relief and I believe it will significantly increase safety and create a calm atmosphere in the world."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.klaus.cz/clanky/2827 |title=Prohlášení prezidenta republiky k zneškodnění Usámy ibn Ládina |publisher=Václav Klaus |date=May 3, 2011 |accessdate=May 3, 2011|language=Czech}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Hungary}} | Hungarian Foreign Minister [[János Martonyi]] said bin Laden's death "is a major success in the war on international terrorism, but it doesn't mean the end of this war. A very important and determined enemy of our entire civilization has fallen."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://stream001.radio.hu:443/mr1/0055629f_4509942.mp3 |accessdate=May 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110829232227/http://stream001.radio.hu:443/mr1/0055629f_4509942.mp3 |archivedate=August 29, 2011|title=Untitled}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Poland}} | The [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Poland)|Polish Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] said, "Justice has been done. Congratulations to our allies. We share this moment of happiness with the American people." It further added, "Let yesterday be a reminder of what will happen to those who continue to align themselves with bin Laden and to those who continue to plan further terrorist attacks."<ref>{{cite web|title=''Oświadczenie w sprawie śmierci Osamy ben Ladena'' |trans-title=Statement on the Death of Osama bin Laden| language = Polish | url=http://www.msz.gov.pl/Oswiadczenie,w,sprawie,smierci,Osamy,ben,Ladena,42936.html|publisher=MSZ Poland|accessdate=May 2, 2011|author=Sikorski, Radosław}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Romania}} | Romanian president [[Traian Băsescu]] said bin Laden's death marked the "beginning of the end" in the struggle against terrorism and called it "an extraordinary moment for what is taking place in the Arab countries", in reference to the [[Arab Spring]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.realitatea.net/basescu-despre-uciderea-lui-bin-laden-un-succes-al-sua-este-inceputul-sfarsitului_830786.html | title=Băsescu, despre uciderea lui bin Laden: Un succes al SUA, este începutul sfârşitului | publisher=realitatea.net | date=May 3, 2011 | accessdate=April 22, 2012 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110921022307/http://www.realitatea.net/basescu-despre-uciderea-lui-bin-laden-un-succes-al-sua-este-inceputul-sfarsitului_830786.html# | archive-date=2011-09-21 | dead-url=yes | df= }}</ref> |- | {{flag|Russia}} | "Russia was among the first countries to face the dangers inherent in global terrorism, and unfortunately knows what al-Qaeda is not from hearsay," the [[Moscow Kremlin|Kremlin]] said.
