"Retribution will inevitably reach all terrorists."<ref name=autogenerated4>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/05/02/bin.laden.world.reacts/ |title=World leaders React to News of Bin Laden's Death|publisher= [[CNN]] |date=May 3, 2011|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Ukraine}} | [[President of Ukraine|Ukrainian President]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]] said that bin Laden's death was "important for all countries that wish to live in the world without terrorism".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/103482/ |title=Yanukovych Comments on Osama bin Laden's death | work = [[Kyiv Post]] |date=May 3, 2011|accessdate=May 3, 2011}}</ref> |- |}
====Northern Europe==== {| class="wikitable" ! bgcolor="#efefef" column width=125px|Nation ! bgcolor="#efefef" class=unsortable|Response |- | {{flag|Denmark}} | [[Prime Minister of Denmark|Danish Prime Minister]] [[Lars Løkke Rasmussen]] said, "I congratulate President Obama and the American people with the success in finishing the era of bin Laden's unscrupulous and inhumane violence and destruction".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dr.dk/Nyheder/Politik/2011/05/02/111645.htm |title=''Løkke lykønsker USA med bin Ladens død'' |publisher=[[DR (broadcaster)|DR]]|date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011|language= Danish}}</ref> [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Denmark)|Danish Foreign Minister]] [[Lene Espersen]] called bin Laden's demise a "great symbolic victory", but warned that the [[War on Terror]] had not yet ended.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://politiken.dk/udland/ECE1269923/lene-espersen-en-stor-symbolsk-sejr/ |title= ''Lene Espersen: En stor symbolsk sejr'' |trans-title=| work = [[Politiken]] |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011|language=Danish}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Finland}} | President of Finland [[Tarja Halonen]] said, "Hopefully this is the end of an era." She also commented on the importance of the international community to create a system which would be constructive and build on co-operation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://yle.fi/uutiset/talous_ja_politiikka/2011/05/presidentti_halonen_bin_ladenista_toivottavasti_tama_on_yhden_aikakauden_loppu_2561212.html |title=Tarja Halonen's comments on the death of Osama bin Laden |publisher=Yle.fi |date=January 1, 1970 |accessdate=May 5, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Ireland}} | [[Taoiseach]] [[Enda Kenny]] said the removal of bin Laden's ability to plot heinous acts is a major achievement in the effort to rid the world of the threat of terrorism.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2011/0502/binladen_reaction.html|title=Forces of Peace Were Successful|publisher= [[RTÉ News]]|date=May 2, 2011|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Norway}} | [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Norway)|Norwegian Foreign Minister]] [[Jonas Gahr Støre]] called the death of bin Laden "a break-through in the fight against terror", but insisted that the threat from al-Qaeda remained.<ref name="Aftenposten">{{cite news|url=http://www.aftenposten.no/nyheter/iriks/article4108982.ece|title=''Et gjennombrudd i kampen mot terror''|trans-title=|date=May 2, 2011|work=[[Aftenposten]]|publisher=[[Norsk Telegrambyrå]]|language=Norwegian|accessdate=May 2, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110505192909/http://www.aftenposten.no/nyheter/iriks/article4108982.ece#|archive-date=2011-05-05|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Sweden}} | [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Sweden)|Swedish Foreign Minister]] [[Carl Bildt]] wrote a tweet saying that "a world without Osama Bin Laden is a better world. His hatred was a threat to us all".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/carlbildt/statuses/64927845574651905|title=Carl Bildt on Twitter|date=May 2, 2011|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|United Kingdom}} | [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] [[David Cameron]] said that bin Laden's death would "bring great relief" around the world.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 |title= Osama Bin Laden Dead |publisher = [[BBC News Online]]|date=May 2, 2011|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> Former Prime Minister [[Tony Blair]] said that "the operation shows those who commit acts of terror against the innocent will be brought to justice, however long it takes. This is a huge achievement in the fight against terrorism, but we know the fight against terrorism and the ideology that Bin Laden represents continues and is as urgent as ever."<ref name="autogenerated5"/> [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] and [[Leader of the Opposition (United Kingdom)|opposition]] leader [[Ed Miliband]] stated that "the world is a safer place with the death of Osama bin Laden because he is no longer there to command and encourage terrorism".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-13259095 |title= Osama Bin Laden: Miliband Says World Now 'Safer Place' |publisher= [[BBC News Online]] |date= May 2, 2011|accessdate=May 5, 2011}}</ref> [[Ken Livingstone]], the former Mayor of London, criticized Obama for having Bin Laden assassinated rather than captured alive. He stated that the killing would increase the chance of terrorism, although many disagree with Livingstone's remark.<ref>{{cite news|last=Siddique |first=Haroon |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/blog/2011/may/04/osama-bin-laden-death-aftermath |title=Osama bin Laden's Death: Aftermath and Reaction – Live Updates| work = [[The Guardian]] |date= May 4, 2011|accessdate=May 5, 2011 |location=London}}</ref> |- |}
====Southern Europe==== {| class="wikitable" ! bgcolor="#efefef" column width=125px|Nation ! bgcolor="#efefef" class=unsortable|Response |- | {{flag|Albania}} | The President of the Republic, Prof. Dr. [[Bamir Topi]], through a message conveyed to the President of the United States of America, [[Barack Obama]], commends the elimination of [[Osama Bin Laden]], by considering it as one of the greatest victories in the war against international terrorism. ''"Please allow me to congratulate you on the completion of the mission justice restored, with the final elimination of Osama Bin Laden by American troops, thus achieving one of the most important victories in the long and difficult war against international terrorism! As President of the Republic of Albania, on behalf of the Albanian nation, I would like to express my most sincere congratulations for the achievement of this objective that gave me joy and at the same time made me proud that my country is lined up on the side of the greatest ally and friend of Albania; the United States of America, the country that believed in the war without compromise against evil, against terrorism, by defending the holy principles of freedom and democracy all over the world, as well as ensuring the security, peace and stability in all parts of the world. Allow me, Mr. President, on behalf of the Albanian people and me personally, to express to you once more the best wishes for this great victory and at the same time to ensure you that Albania will continue to complete with devotion its engagements in the framework of NATO, by giving its own contribution in the future challenges for freedom, democracy, as well as in constructing a better world for the nations and their future"! – emphasizes the message of President Topi."''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.president.al/english/pub/info.asp?id=2370 |title=Website Zyrtar |first=Presidenti i |last=Republikes |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120414191229/http://www.president.al/english/pub/info.asp?id=2370 |archivedate=2012-04-14 |df= }}</ref> Prime Minister [[Sali Berisha]] reacted today to the Al-Qaeda leader also the mastermind of terrorist acts, Osama Bin Laden, being killed by the US forces in Pakistan and appreciated it as a great victory of the USA over terrorism. Speaking to reporters, PM Berisha said that Bin Laden got what he deserved and emphasized that his death relieves the pain of thousands of September 11 victims. Berisha said ''"Today's headline of the international news is elimination of one of the blackest figures of the history of mankind. It's the death of the man who by his primitiveness and aggressive behavior took the lives of thousands of people in New York, but even in other countries worldwide; they were innocent people, on whom this cruel man, Bin Laden, wanted to realize his medieval and the most inhuman ends. But, now he got the deserved response while hidden in his den for years. This marks a great victory of the United States of America, President Barack Obama; it's the victory of peace and all those who consider terrorism the number one enemy of peace and their freedom. This is the most consoling news for families of thousands of innocent victims of the attacks that the chief terrorist Osama Bin Laden masterminded in many countries of the world."''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.keshilliministrave.al/index.php?fq=brenda&m=news&lid=14752 |title=Keshilli i Ministrave i Republikes se Shqiperise |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120405222646/http://www.keshilliministrave.al/index.php?fq=brenda&m=news&lid=14752 |archivedate=2012-04-05 |df= }}</ref> [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Albania)|The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Albania]] hails the elimination of the arch-terrorist Osama Bin Laden during a successful operation conducted by US forces. On this day, the Albanian people joins the feelings and the solidarity of the peoples of the whole world, who have suffered from the unparalleled acts perpetrated by international terrorism, including the one on 11 September. As one of the first countries to join the alliance against international terrorism, Albania expresses the confidence that the unwavering stance in encountering these terrorist acts and their masterminds is the key to the success of our common struggle to uphold peace and freedom worldwide.<ref>[http://www.keminet.net/~minfagov/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=7628:njoftim-per-shtyp&catid=112:lajme&lang=en&Itemid= PRESS RELEASE, Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Albania] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120508094239/http://www.keminet.net/~minfagov/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=7628%3Anjoftim-per-shtyp&catid=112%3Alajme&lang=en&Itemid= |date=2012-05-08 }}</ref> |- | {{flag|Bosnia and Herzegovina}} | Bosnia and Herzegovina Minister of Security, Sadik Ahmetović said that the news of bin Laden's discovery and death was "received with relief". Ahmetović added that "terrorism is the evil of modern times whose victims are mainly innocent civilians so we have to fight it with all means".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sarajevo-x.com/bih/politika/clanak/110502049 |title=S olakšanjem smo dočekali vijest o ubistvu Bin Ladena |publisher=Sarajevo-x.com |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> |- |{{CRO}} |[[President of Croatia|Croatian president]] [[Ivo Josipović|Ivo Josipovi]]ć in interview to [[Croatian Radiotelevision|Croatian Radio Television]] said that: "Death of Osama Bin Laden makes a great victory in fight against terrorism". He emphasized that despite Bin Laden's death fight still isn't over, and Croatia will remain committed to it just like entire progressive world.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.index.hr/vijesti/clanak/josipovic-bin-ladenova-smrt-je-velika-pobjeda-ali-rat-protiv-terorizma-nije-zavrsen/549885.aspx|title=Josipović: Bin Ladenova smrt je velika pobjeda, ali rat protiv terorizma nije završen|access-date=2017-01-04}}</ref> [[Prime Minister of Croatia|Croatian Prime Minister]] [[Jadranka Kosor]] stated that Croatia is member of antiterorist coalition, fight against terrorism is imperative for everyone, and that her government is "taking certain measures" in that context.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://metro-portal.rtl.hr/kosor-borba-protiv-terorizma-je-obveza-svih-poduzimamo-neke-korake/58386|title=Kosor nakon ubojstva Bin Ladena: Poduzimamo neke korake|website=metro-portal.rtl.hr|access-date=2017-01-04}}</ref> Croatian Minister of Interior [[Tomislav Karamarko]] said that upon death of Bin Laden, security in Croatia is on high-quality level. |- | {{flag|Cyprus}} | Following the news and the statements made by Obama, the [[Cyprus Police]] have increased their security measures for the protection of potential Western and US targets within their country. A spokesman for the Cyprus Police, Michalis Katounotos, stated that "the force has adopted additional security measures in the event of new terrorist activities or reaction to the death of bin Laden."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://greece.greekreporter.com/2011/05/02/cyprus-boost-security-measures-after-bin-laden-death/|title=Cyprus Boost Security Measures After Bin Laden Death - GreekReporter.com|first=A.|last=Makris|publisher=}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Greece}} | Greek Foreign Minister [[Dimitris Droutsas]] made the following statement: "International terrorism is an abhorrent phenomenon, a constant threat to international peace and security that undermines the prospects of societies throughout the world for prosperity and development. Osama Bin Laden's death dealt a strong blow to terrorism. But the fight does not end here. The international community – irrespective of religious beliefs and political considerations – needs to remain united in the international effort to end this scourge." |- | {{flag|Italy}} | [[Prime Minister of Italy|Prime Minister]] [[Silvio Berlusconi]] said of bin Laden's killing, "This is a great outcome in the fight against evil, in the fight against terrorism, a great outcome for the United States and for all democracies."<ref name=autogenerated3>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia/2011/05/20115241936984209.html|title=Reactions: Bin Laden's Death |publisher= [[Al Jazeera English]]|date=May 11, 2011|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Italy)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] [[Franco Frattini]] hailed the killing of bin Laden as "a great victory" for the U.S. and the international community as a whole in the struggle against al-Qaeda and terrorism. The Minister has praised U.S. officials for the operation.<ref name=aki01>{{cite web|url=http://www.adnkronos.com/IGN/Aki/English/Security/Italy-Bin-Laden-slaying-great-victory-for-whole-international-community-says-minister_311966959810.html |title=Italy: Bin Laden slaying 'great victory for whole international community' says minister |publisher=[[Adnkronos|Adnkronos International]] |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> [[Italian Minister of the Interior|Minister of the Interior]] [[Roberto Maroni]] said that "Bin Laden's elimination is a good news" and he shared Interpol chief's concerns about risks of immediate terrorist reactions.<ref name=aki02>{{cite web|url=http://www.adnkronos.com/IGN/Aki/English/Security/Italy-Interior-minister-eyes-security-in-wake-of-Bin-Laden-killing_311966960057.html |title=Italy: Interior minister eyes security in wake of Bin Laden killing |publisher=[[Adnkronos|Adnkronos International]] |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Macedonia}} | The Macedonian government praised the death of bin Laden as "a victory for justice and is a big success and a big step forward in the attempt to make a safer world and eliminate the terror threats against humanity".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.novamakedonija.com.mk/NewsDetal.asp?vest=5311833467&id=11&setIzdanie=22270|title=Светот се радува и стравува од нов Осама|publisher=Nova Makedonija|date=May 4, 2011|accessdate=May 4, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928045401/http://www.novamakedonija.com.mk/NewsDetal.asp?vest=5311833467&id=11&setIzdanie=22270#|archive-date=2011-09-28|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Malta}} | The Maltese government said in an official statement: "Osama bin Laden was responsible for some of the worst terrorist attacks in recent history that cost the lives of thousands of innocent people. We hope that the world will be safer place to live in and that the international community will continue to strive to combat the scourge of extremism and to build a world of peace, security and prosperity for all."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20110502/local/maltese-government-reaction-to-bin-laden-s-death.363321|title=Maltese government reaction to Bin Laden's death|first=Allied Newspapers|last=Ltd|publisher=}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Portugal}} | The [[President of Portugal]], [[Aníbal Cavaco Silva]], sent a message to the U.S. President in which he expressed his solidarity with the feelings of the American people when the outcome of the military operation of which ended with the death of bin Laden became known.<ref>{{cite web|title=Presidente Cavaco Silva enviou mensagem de solidariedade ao homólogo Barack Obama|date=May 2, 2011|url=http://www.presidencia.pt/?idc=18&idi=53304}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Spain}} | [[Prime Minister of Spain]] [[José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero]] sent a telegram to Barack Obama to expressed "in name of [his] Government and the Spanish society, the satisfaction shared with the American people for the result of the anti-terrorist operation which led to bin Laden's death. Satisfaction for the meaning it has as a decisive and determining step in fighting Al-Qaeda's terrorism. Satisfaction inseparable of the memories of the victims caused by the horrible terrorist strikes which will never leave our memory. Spain will stay fully committed with the International Community in fighting terrorism."<ref>{{cite web|title=Rodríguez Zapatero expresa a Obama su satisfacción por la operación contra el terrorismo de Bin Laden |date=May 2, 2011|url=http://www.lamoncloa.gob.es/presidente/actividades/actividadesnacionales/2011/020411declaraciongobierno.htm|quote=Quiero expresarte, en nombre de mi Gobierno y de la sociedad española, la satisfacción compartida con el pueblo americano por el resultado de la operación antiterrorista que ha conducido a la muerte de Osama Bin Laden. Satisfacción por lo que significa de paso decisivo y determinante en la lucha contra el terrorismo de Al-Qaeda. Satisfacción inseparable del recuerdo de las víctimas causadas por unos horribles atentados que nunca abandonarán nuestra memoria. España seguirá plenamente comprometida con la Comunidad internacional en la lucha contra el terrorismo.}}</ref> |- | {{flagicon|Vatican City}} [[Holy See]] | Vatican spokesman Fr. [[Federico Lombardi]] said that bin Laden "was gravely responsible for promoting division and hatred between peoples, causing the end of countless innocent lives, and of exploiting religions to this end. Faced with the death of a man, a Christian never rejoices, but reflects on the serious responsibility of each and every one of us before God and before man, and hopes and commits himself so that no event is an opportunity for further growth of hatred, but for peace".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/vatican-says-bin-laden-gravely-responsible-hopes-for-peace/ |title=Vatican says Bin Laden 'gravely responsible,' hopes for peace|publisher=Reuters|date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> |- |}
====Western Europe==== {| class="wikitable" ! bgcolor="#efefef" column width=125px|Nation ! bgcolor="#efefef" class=unsortable|Response |- | {{flag|Austria}} | Austrian Foreign Minister [[Michael Spindelegger]] welcomed the news, calling it "a relief for many people", but warned that it must not be interpreted as a "final victory over terrorism".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/europe/news/article_1636434.php/Austria-Terrorism-not-defeated-by-bin-Laden-death|title=Austria: Terrorism Not Defeated by Bin Laden Death|publisher=[[Monsters and Critics]]|date=May 1, 2011|accessdate=May 2, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120107060246/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/europe/news/article_1636434.php/Austria-Terrorism-not-defeated-by-bin-Laden-death|archivedate=January 7, 2012|df=}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Belgium}} | Belgian resigning Prime Minister [[Yves Leterme]] said, "Many people have a sense of relief, especially the victims of the attacks. One would normally expect a trial, but I think this is a good solution, given what happened in the past on the initiative of Osama bin Laden."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.standaard.be/artikel/detail.aspx?artikelid=DMF20110502_015|publisher=De Standaard Online|date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011|title=Vanackere bezorgd om troepen in Afghanistan}}</ref> |- | {{flag|France}} | French Foreign Minister [[Alain Juppé]] said that bin Laden's death is a "victory for all democracies fighting the abominable scourge of terrorism". He went on to say, "France, the United States and European states work closely together to fight terrorism, so I'm overjoyed at the news."<ref>{{Cite news | url=http://www.expatica.com/fr/news/french-news/bin-laden-death-victory-for-all-democracies--france_146072.html | title=Bin Laden Death 'Victory for All Democracies' | publisher=Expatica France | date=May 2, 2011 | accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Germany}} | [[German Foreign Minister]] [[Guido Westerwelle]] said, "That a stop could be put to this terrorist's bloody trade is good news for all peace-loving and free-thinking people in the world."<ref name="reactions">{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/05/02/bin.laden.world.reacts/ |title=World Leaders React to News of Bin Laden's Death |date=May 2, 2011 |publisher=[[CNN]] |accessdate=May 2, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yNLdnUAf?url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/05/02/bin.laden.world.reacts/ |archivedate=May 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> [[German Chancellor]] [[Angela Merkel]] expressed joy that bin Laden had been successfully killed,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bundeskanzlerin.de/Content/DE/Mitschrift/Pressekonferenzen/2011/05/2011-05-02-merkel-osama-bin-laden.html|title=Pressestatement von Bundeskanzlerin Angela Merkel zur Tötung von Osama bin Laden|date=May 2, 2011|accessdate=May 5, 2011|publisher=[[Bundeskanzleramt]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110506172009/http://www.bundeskanzlerin.de/Content/DE/Mitschrift/Pressekonferenzen/2011/05/2011-05-02-merkel-osama-bin-laden.html#|archive-date=2011-05-06|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> a statement that drew some criticism in Germany.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.handelsblatt.com/politik/deutschland/kritik-an-kanzlerin-merkels-reaktion-/4130664.html|title=Kritik an Kanzlerin Merkels Reaktion|date=May 4, 2011|publisher=[[Handelsblatt]]|accessdate=May 5, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.zeit.de/politik/deutschland/2011-05/bin-laden-merkel-koalition-streit|title=Merkel wehrt Kritik an Bin-Laden-Äußerungen ab|date=May 4, 2011|publisher=[[Die ZEIT]]|accessdate=May 5, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Netherlands}} | [[Dutch Prime Minister]] [[Mark Rutte]] praises the courage and the determination that people showed during the mission. He further says that this is a major blow to the al-Qaeda network. He has presented his compliments to President Obama but also said this is not the end of terrorism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nos.nl/artikel/237203-premier-rutte-slag-voor-alqaida.html |title=NOS Nieuws – Premier Rutte: slag voor al-Qaida |publisher=Nos.nl |date=|accessdate=May 3, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Switzerland}} | Jacques Baud, a Swiss security expert, says the killing of Osama bin Laden won't necessarily lead to a speedier withdrawal of foreign troops from Afghanistan. But said that "his death is seen as a major victory over terrorism."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/bin-laden-death--won-t-spark--afghan-retreat/30143408|date=May 3, 2011|publisher=[[Simon Bradley]]|accessdate=May 3, 2011|title=Bin Laden death "won’t spark" Afghan retreat}}</ref> |- |}
===Middle East=== {| class="wikitable" ! bgcolor="#efefef" column width=125px|Nation ! bgcolor="#efefef" class=unsortable|Response |- | {{flag|Iran}} | Foreign Ministry spokesman [[Ramin Mehmanparast]] said bin Laden's death meant that the "US and their allies have no more excuse to deploy forces in the Middle East under (the) pretext of fighting terrorism". He hoped that the killing would "establish peace and security in the region", adding that it is Iran's policy to "strongly condemn terrorism all over the world".<ref name=afplive/> [[Alaeddin Boroujerdi]], head of the Iranian Parliament's foreign policy commission, stated, "If it is true, then the killing of bin Laden 10 years after the September 11 incident is no big deal."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/middleeast/news/article_1636423.php/Iranian-lawmaker-bin-Laden-s-death-no-big-deal |title=Iranian Lawmaker: bin Laden's Death 'No Big Deal' |publisher=[[Deutsche Presse-Agentur]] (via [[Monsters and Critics]]) |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110908045538/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/middleeast/news/article_1636423.php/Iranian-lawmaker-bin-Laden-s-death-no-big-deal |archivedate=September 8, 2011 |df= }}</ref> [[Heydar Moslehi|Heyder Moslehi]], the Iranian Intelligence Minister, said that bin Laden had died before the raid: "We have exact information that indicates that bin Laden had died from an illness some time ago,", "Why didn't (the White House) show his body? Why did they throw it into the sea?"<ref>{{cite news|title=Iranian Official: Bin Laden Died Long Before US Raid|author=Cohen, Dudi|publisher = [[Ynetnews]]|date=May 9, 2011|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4066469,00.html|accessdate=May 9, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Iraq}} | Foreign Minister of Iraq [[Hoshyar Zebari]] said that "[[Baghdad]] is delighted by the news that Osama bin Laden has been killed". He mentioned that "thousands of Iraqis had died because of his ideologies".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110502-iraq-fm-delighted-see-end-bin-laden |title=Iraq FM 'Delighted' To See End of Bin Laden |publisher=[[France 24]] |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> |- | {{flag|Israel}} | [[Israeli Prime Minister]] [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] said that bin Laden's death was a "resounding triumph for democratic nations fighting terrorism".<ref name="autogenerated1"/> [[Shaul Mofaz]], chairman of the [[Knesset]]'s [[Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee]], said that the killing of Osama bin Laden bears witness to the fact that the US has adopted the Israeli strategy of targeting terrorist leaders....Mofaz said that the strategy [[Operation Wrath of God|was originally employed by Israel]] following the [[Munich massacre|murder of nine Israeli athletes]] at the [[1972 Munich Olympics]].<ref name="economist110504"/> |- | {{flag|Lebanon}} | Former [[Prime Minister of Lebanon|Lebanese Prime Minister]] [[Saad Hariri]] said, "Murderers and villains deserve such a fate and the fight against all its [terrorism] shapes and forms should not stop and is first and foremost the responsibility of Arabs and Muslims who have the duty of liberating Islam from its kidnappers",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Politics/May/02/Hariri-Bin-Laden-got-what-he-deserved.ashx |title=Hariri: Bin Laden Got What He Deserved | work = [[The Daily Star (Lebanon)|The Daily Star]] |date=May 2, 2011 }}</ref> and "the history of our nationalism and Islam will never forgive that man who was a black mark for two decades, filling the minds of youngsters with ideas about terrorism, murder and destruction".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia/2011/05/20115241936984209.html |title=Reactions: Bin Laden's Death|publisher= [[Al Jazeera English]] |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 3, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Saudi Arabia}} | The Saudi Deputy Interior Minister, Prince [[Ahmed bin Abdul-Aziz Al Saud]], was cited on TV: "Saudi Arabia hopes that the elimination of the leader of the terrorist al-Qaeda organisation will be a step towards supporting international efforts aimed at combating terrorism and dismantling its cells".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-13256956 |title= Osama Bin Laden's Death: Political Reaction in Quotes |publisher= [[BBC News Online]] |date=May 3, 2011 |accessdate=May 3, 2011}}</ref> Saudi Prince [[Alwaleed bin Talal]] praised the U.S. forces' success in killing bin Laden, stating the terrorist leader's demise was "a plus not only for the U.S. but for the whole world," and characterized Barack Obama's approach to the region in general as "very prudent".<ref>{{cite web|url= http://m.foxbusiness.com/quickPage.html?page=32811&content=52056073&pageNum=-1 |title= Saudi Prince Alwaleed: Israel Should Abide By Obama Plan|publisher= [[Fox Business Network]] |date=May 19, 2011 |accessdate=May 19, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|United Arab Emirates}} | UAE's Assistant Foreign Minister for Political Affairs, Tariq Al-Haidan, said that bin Laden's death "will strengthen efforts of international community in combating terrorism". He added that terrorism had deteriorated the image of Islam and Muslims worldwide and that the "death of the Al-qaeda leader does not mean an end to Al-qaeda or terrorism".<ref>{{cite news| author = Staff|title=Death of Osama Bin Laden To Strengthen Anti Terrorism Efforts: UAE|url=http://www.kalam.tv/ur/video/73382/index.html|accessdate=May 3, 2011| publisher = [[Kalam TV]]}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Yemen}} | A government official described bin Laden's death as "a truly historic moment". "We welcome the news ... millions of people will sleep in peace tonight. Osama bin Laden was more of a symbolic figure, a spiritual leader for al-Qaeda. But this is definitely a strong blow to the organization," said the official, who did not want to be named because he is not authorized to talk to the media.<ref name=autogenerated4 /> |- |}
=== Oceania === {| class="wikitable" ! bgcolor="#efefef" column width=125px|Nation ! bgcolor="#efefef" class=unsortable|Response |- | {{flag|Australia}} | [[Prime Minister of Australia|Australian Prime Minister]] [[Julia Gillard]] welcomed the news of bin Laden's death, by saying: "Osama bin Laden declared war on innocent people and today he has paid the price for that declaration. Osama bin Laden was directly responsible for despicable acts of violence against innocent people and he inspired acts of violence by others. Today of all days we remember the lives lost, particularly the lives of Australians."<ref>{{cite web|author =Farr, Malcolm |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/breaking-news/julia-gillard-says-australian-troops-in-afghanistan-wont-withdraw-after-osama-bin-laden-death/story-e6frf7jx-1226048547594 |title=Julia Gillard Says Australian Troops in Afghanistan Won't Withdraw after Osama bin Laden Death |work = [[Herald Sun]] |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> She also said it was "a small measure of justice",<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/breaking-news/julia-gillard-says-australian-troops-in-afghanistan-wont-withdraw-after-osama-bin-laden-death/story-e6frfku0-1226048547594 |title=Julia Gillard Says Australian Troops in Afghanistan Won't Withdraw after Osama bin Laden Death |publisher= [[news.com.au]] |author=Farr, Malcolm |accessdate=May 2, 2011 |date=May 2, 2011}} </ref> but stated that the "[[War on Terror]] is not over", and "must be continued".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/more-news/julia-gillard-welcomes-bin-laden-death/story-fn7x8me2-1226048551599 |title=Julia Gillard 'Welcomes' Osama Bin Laden Death |work =[[Herald Sun]] |author=Johnston, Matt |accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> |- | {{flag|New Zealand}} | [[Prime Minister of New Zealand|New Zealand Prime Minister]] [[John Key]] stated that "the world is a safer place without Osama bin Laden", but "bin Laden's death may not mean an end to terrorism".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/key-world-safer-place-without-bin-laden-4150925 |title=Key: World a Safer Place Without Bin Laden | publisher= [[Television New Zealand]] |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> |- |}
=== Other state entities === {| class="wikitable" ! bgcolor="#efefef" column width=125px|Entity ! bgcolor="#efefef" class=unsortable|Response |- | {{flag|Kosovo}} | The [[President of Kosovo]], [[Atifete Jahjaga]], said, "Terrorist Osama Bin Laden took the deserved punishment after all the killings, suffering, pain and damage he inflicted on the world. Justice was put into place. The good won against evil. People will live in peace, progress, fearless and safe. The war against international terrorism is in function of peace, prosperity, security for all, in defense of life and human dignity."<ref>{{cite web|title= Statement of the President of the Republic of Kosovo, Mrs. Atifete Jahjaga, on the death of Osama Bin Laden|url=http://www.president-ksgov.net/?page=2,6,1753}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Gaza Strip}} | [[Hamas]], the government of the Gaza Strip, denounced the killing of bin Laden: "We condemn the assassination and the killing of an 'Arab holy warrior'. We regard this as a continuation of the American policy based on oppression and the shedding of Muslim and Arab blood."<ref name="latimes.com" /> [[Ismail Haniya]], a senior political leader of Hamas and one of two disputed Prime Ministers of the [[Palestinian National Authority]], said: "We condemn any killing of a holy warrior or of a Muslim and Arab person and we ask Allah to bestow his mercy upon him." Ismail al-Ashqar, a Hamas lawmaker, called it "state terrorism that America carries out against Muslims".<ref name="nytimes1"/> The [[United States]] and the [[United Kingdom]] condemned Hamas for mourning bin Laden's death and referring to him as a "holy warrior". A U.S. State Department spokesman called the reference "outrageous", and British Foreign Secretary [[William Hague]] echoed the sentiment.<ref name="jpost1"/> |- | {{flag|Palestinian Authority}} | The official leader of the Palestinian Authority is in dispute. One of two disputed Prime Ministers of the Palestinian National Authority, [[Ismail Haniya]], said: "We condemn any killing of a holy warrior or of a Muslim and Arab person and we ask Allah to bestow his mercy upon him." The spokesman for the rival party, [[Palestinian People's Party]], [[Ghassan Khatib]] said: "Getting rid of Bin Laden is good for the cause of peace worldwide, but what counts is to overcome the discourse and the methods – the violent methods – that were created and encouraged by Bin Laden and others in the world".<ref name="latimes.com"/> |- | {{flag|Republic of China (Taiwan)}}<!--There is no government called "TAIWAN" - It is the "Republic of China" government--> | The ROC government raised the terror alert levels across the ROC (Taiwanese) territories, including the island of Taiwan, after learning about bin Laden's death.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.taiwanembassy.org/US/ct.asp?xItem=197001&ctNode=2300&mp=12# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2011-05-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111003053537/http://www.taiwanembassy.org/US/ct.asp?xItem=197001&ctNode=2300&mp=12# |archive-date=2011-10-03 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Also, [[President of the Republic of China|President]] [[Ma Ying-jeou]] said that "this is a huge progress for the international counter-terrorism movement." Vice Premier Sean Chen, along with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, echoed that statement. |- |}
==Individuals== * The scope of international interest in this incident can be illustrated with over three million [[Twitter|tweet]]s about bin Laden's death released by various individuals as of May 7, 2011. [[Twitter]] has protested when researchers attempted to analyze that data.<ref>Shulman, Stuart (May 7, 2011). [http://blog.texifter.com/index.php/2011/05/07/twitter-and-history-march-on/ "Twitter and History March On"].</ref> * The [[14th Dalai Lama]] said, "Forgiveness doesn't mean forget what happened. … If something is serious and it is necessary to take counter-measures, you have to take counter-measures."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-0504-dalai-lama-20110504,0,7229481.story |title=Dalai Lama: Speaking at USC, Dalai Lama Suggests He Condones Osama Bin Laden's Killing |work= [[Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=May 4, 2011 | author = Landsberg, Mitchell |date=May 4, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = https://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2011/05/05/dalai-lama-in-bin-laden-quandary/ | title = Dalai Lama in Bin Laden Quandary | date = May 5, 2011 |work = [[The Wall Street Journal]] | author = Stancati, Margherita }}</ref> * [[Rowan Williams]], the [[Archbishop of Canterbury]], said "it doesn't look as if justice ... is done," concerning the killing of an unarmed man. He elaborated, "I don't know full details any more than anyone else does. But I do believe that in such circumstances when we are faced with someone who was manifestly a [[war criminal]], in terms of the atrocities inflicted, it is important that justice is seen to be observed."<ref>{{cite news|title=Osama bin Laden dead: Archbishop of Canterbury criticises White House|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/al-qaeda/8494852/Osama-bin-Laden-dead-Archbishop-of-Canterbury-criticises-White-House.html|accessdate=May 6, 2011 |work= [[The Daily Telegraph]] | author =Ross, Tim|date=May 5, 2011|location=London}}</ref> * [[Salman Rushdie]] – novelist and essayist, said: "It is time to declare Pakistan a terrorist state and expel it from the community of nations." Rushdie asked whether the world is to believe Pakistan when it professes its ignorance about Osama's presence on its soil in the very town housing its elite military academy. He stated: "In the aftermath of the raid on Abbottabad, all the big questions need to be answered by Pakistan."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arcamax.com/currentnews/newsheadlines/s-878982 |title=Acramax UK/AHN News, Rushdie Says Pak' Should Be Declared a Teror State |publisher=[[ArcaMax Publishing]]|date=May 3, 2011 |accessdate=May 12, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2011-05-03/news/29499637_1_terrorist-state-safe-havens-salman-rushdie |title=Economic Times- Indiatimes, May 3, 2011 |publisher=Articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com |date= |accessdate=May 12, 2011 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> * [[Noam Chomsky]] – scholar in the field of linguistics as well as an anarchist and libertarian socialist, said: "We might ask ourselves how we would be reacting if Iraqi commandos landed at George W. Bush's compound, assassinated him, and dumped his body in the Atlantic. Uncontroversially, his crimes vastly exceed bin Laden's, and he is not a 'suspect' but uncontroversially the 'decider' who gave the orders to commit the "supreme international crime differing only from other war crimes in that it contains within itself the accumulated evil of the whole" (quoting the Nuremberg Tribunal) for which Nazi criminals were hanged: the hundreds of thousands of deaths, millions of refugees, destruction of much of the country, the bitter sectarian conflict that has now spread to the rest of the region."<ref>[http://www.guernicamag.com/blog/2652/noam_chomsky_my_reaction_to_os/ "My Reaction to Osama bin Laden's Death"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110513033734/http://www.guernicamag.com/blog/2652/noam_chomsky_my_reaction_to_os/ |date=2011-05-13 }}.</ref> * [[Henry Kissinger]], former advisor to Presidents [[Richard Nixon|Nixon]] and [[Gerald Ford|Ford]], commended President Obama on the matter. He pointed out that, "Operationally, the general view seems to be that bin Laden was not in active operational control anymore. But symbolically, as the head of the movement, his death has a blighting effect." He indicated that relations with Pakistan will be difficult, but that there should be an increase in Pakistan's role in America's foreign policy. He urged Obama to think critically about how this affects the war in Afghanistan, but said, "[o]n the whole, I think that it has been an extremely positive development."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/articles/266599/kissinger-obama-osama-and-af-pak-robert-costa |title=Kissinger on Obama, Osama, and Af-Pak| work = [[National Review]] | date= |accessdate=May 15, 2011}}</ref>
==Pro-bin Laden rallies== {{flag|Pakistan}} *On May 2, around 1200 supporters of the [[Taliban]] attended a rally in the Pakistani city of [[Quetta]] to pay homage to Osama bin Laden, chanting "[[death to America]]" and setting fire to a U.S. flag, witnesses and organisers said. One of the demonstrators, Asmatullah said: "Bin Laden was the hero of the Muslim world and after his martyrdom he has won the title of great mujahed (Muslim fighter)."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dawn.com/2011/05/02/hundreds-join-first-pakistan-rally-to-honour-bin-laden.html|title=Hundreds Join First Pakistan Rally To Honour bin Laden| work = [[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]}}</ref> * On May 4, hundreds of people in the city of [[Multan]], marched through the streets in a pro-bin Laden rally, protesting the killing of bin Laden by U.S. Special Forces. The crowd held placards and burned U.S. flags.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1383011/Osama-Bin-Laden-dead-Pakistanis-burn-US-flags-backlash-grows.html |title=DailyMail(UK), May 4, 2011 | work = [[Daily Mail]] |date= May 4, 2011|accessdate=May 12, 2011 |location=London}}</ref> * On May 5, Pakistan's biggest and most influential political Islamist party [[Jamaat-e-Islami Pakistan|Jamaat-i-Islami]], held a pro-Bin Laden rally in [[Islamabad]] chanting anti-American, anti-Israeli and anti-Indian slogans.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/05/us-binladen-pakistan-protest-idUSTRE74414N20110505|title=Pakistan Islamists To Protest Against U.S. bin Laden Raid|author=Azhar, Saeed|publisher= [[Reuters]] |date=May 5, 2011}}</ref> * On May 5, 150 Pakistani lawyers in [[Peshawar]], describing themselves as "followers" of bin Laden, prayed for him outside the Peshawar High Court. Organizer Gul Nabi said that "bin Laden was as a martyr and this prayer was not offered anywhere. It was an ''Faraz-e-Kafaya'' (Islamic obligation) so we performed this and we did this just to complete this ''Namaz-e-janaza'' (funeral) for all those ''Shaheeds'' (martyrs) who were killed in Abbottabad." After the prayers, the lawyers chanted anti-American slogans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://samaa.tv/newsdetail.aspx?ID=31602|title=Peshawar High Court Lawyers Offer Prayers for Osama Bin Laden|publisher=[[SAMAA TV]]|access-date=2011-05-05|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110826154953/http://samaa.tv/newsdetail.aspx?ID=31602#|archive-date=2011-08-26|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> * On May 6, mass crowds gathered in [[Kuchlak]], held a pro- bin Laden rally, headed by the political party [[Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam]]. The demonstrators carried picture of bin Laden and burned a U.S. flag.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.timesleader.com/news/Bleak_image_is_painted__of_bin_Laden_rsquo_s_last_days_05-06-2011.html |title=The Times Leader, Wilkes-Barre Scranton News, May 7, 2011 |publisher=Timesleader.com |date= |accessdate=May 12, 2011 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://iguardusa.com/al-qaida-vows-revenge-for-osama-bin-ladens-death/ |title=IGuardUSA – Al Qaeda vows revenge |publisher=Iguardusa.com |date= |accessdate=May 12, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/topic/photo/0asvfkAcrtaQW?q=killing+of+al-Qaida+chief+Osama+bin+Laden |title=Times of India, May 6, 2011 |work = [[The Times of India]] |date=May 6, 2011 |accessdate=May 12, 2011 }} {{Dead link|date=June 2011|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> * On May 7, religious and religio-political parties held demonstrations and rallies outside mosques after Friday prayers across [[Pakistan]] including [[Lahore]] to protest against the growing U.S. interference, drone attacks, Abbotabad operation and the resultant killing of bin Laden. During Friday prayers, imams termed the war on terror as war against Islam and Muslims, they also stressed that Islamic countries should unite to fight against a common enemy.<ref name=autogenerated7>{{cite web|url=http://nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online/Regional/Lahore/07-May-2011/Mammoth-rallies-across-Punjab|title=Mammoth Rallies Across Punjab|author=Gilani, Iqtidar|work=[[The Nation]]|access-date=2011-05-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511180028/http://nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online/Regional/Lahore/07-May-2011/Mammoth-rallies-across-Punjab#|archive-date=2011-05-11|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> A mammoth rally was also held in Mansoora, Lahore, the headquarters of [[Jamaat-e-Islami Pakistan|Jamat-e-Islami]] against the U.S. operation, where the [[Syed Munawar Hasan|ameer of Jamaat-e-Islami Syed Munawar Hasan]] was also present and warned "Washington and her allies" that terrorism would not come to an end through a war against Islam and the Muslims.<ref name=autogenerated7 /> {{flag|Palestinian Authority}} * On May 2, dozens of [[Palestinian people|Palestinian]] [[Arab]] residents of [[Silwan]] in [[East Jerusalem]] held a rally in support of Osama bin Laden. Some demonstrators threw stones at [[Israel Police]] officers. ''[[Ynet]]'' noted that bin Laden had made various statements in support of the Palestinians and against Israel, had declared that [[Muslim]]s were engaged in a war against [[Jews]], and had criticized the United States for "its support of Israel and the ongoing occupation in Palestine".<ref>{{cite news|title=Jerusalem Arabs Honor bin Laden|author=Altman, Yair; Reuters|publisher = [[Ynetnews]]|date=May 3, 2011|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4063672,00.html}}</ref> * On the day after bin Laden's death, 25 people, including [[al-Qaeda]] sympathizers and students, gathered for a rally outside a [[Gaza City]] university. Some said they opposed bin Laden's ideology, but nonetheless considered him a martyr and were angry at the U.S. for killing him.<ref>{{cite news|title=J'lem imam: Obama will soon hang|author=Elior Levy |newspaper=Ynetnews|date=May 3, 2011|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4064183,00.html}}</ref> * On May 7, dozens of [[Salafists]] Islamists gathered in the main square of [[Gaza City]] to protest against bin Laden's killing. The demonstrators, chanting "We warn you America, we warn you Europe", held posters of bin Laden along with banners reading "We are all your soldiers Osama" and "Osama is alive inside us." The protest was broken up by [[Hamas]] police. [[Reuters]] noted that while Hamas itself had denounced the killing of bin Laden as well, it had recently engaged in gun battles with Gazan Salafist groups.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/07/us-palestinians-binladen-idUSTRE7461WT20110507 "Hamas Breaks Up Salafist bin Laden Rally in Gaza"]. Reuters. May 7, 2011.</ref> {{flag|Sudan}} * On May 3, around 1,000 people rallied in [[Khartoum]], [[Sudan]], to praise bin Laden, chanting "Death to America". The gathering was attended by junior members of the ruling northern [[National Congress (Sudan)|National Congress Party]]. The rally consisted of a prayer and several speeches by radical Sunni Muslim clerics who praised bin Laden and called on Arab leaders to fight the USA. Sheikh Abu Zaid Mohammed Hamza declared: "Islam is calling to fight against the USA because it supports [[Israel]] and the [[Jews]]... We hope that all Arab presidents will become like Osama bin Laden." Sheikh Abdul Hai Youssuf said that "Osama bin Laden is our brother".<ref>[https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE7420R020110503 "In Sudan, 1,000 Denounce Killing of Bin Laden"]. [[Reuters]]. May 3, 2011.</ref> {{flag|Turkey}} * On May 6, about 200 people rallied at the [[Fatih Mosque, Istanbul|Fatih Mosque]] in [[Istanbul]], by protesting the killing of bin Laden by U.S. commandos. After Friday prayers, the demonstrators gathered at the call of Islamist newspaper ''[[Millî Gazete]]'', and with the support of the Islamist organization Özgür-Der.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/9/11533/World/International/Scores-protest-at-bin-Ladens-death-in-Istanbul.aspx |title=AFP/AhramOnline, May 6, 2011 | work = [[Al-Ahram]] |date=May 6, 2011 |accessdate=May 12, 2011}}</ref> {{flag|United Kingdom}} * On May 6, hundreds of British Muslims and [[Muslims Against Crusades]] members held a pro-Bin Laden rally outside the [[U.S. Embassy, London]] and staged [[salat al-Janazah]] (funeral prayers) for Osama bin Laden. Protesters clashed with police when they tried to storm the embassy. [[Anjem Choudary]] – a British national of [[British Pakistanis|Pakistani descent]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Raymond, Catherine Zara|url=http://www.icsr.info/publications/papers/1276697989CatherineZaraRaymondICSRPaper.pdf|title=Pg.19, Al Muhajiroun and Islam4UK, The Group Behind the Ban|format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]|date=|accessdate=May 12, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111008182235/http://www.icsr.info/publications/papers/1276697989CatherineZaraRaymondICSRPaper.pdf|archivedate=October 8, 2011|df=}}</ref> who organised the protest, predicted an attack similar to the [[7 July 2005 London bombings]] in response to bin Laden's death. The rally was met by a counter protest from the anti-Islamist [[English Defence League]].<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1384344/Osama-Bin-Laden-death-UK-Muslims-stage-mock-funeral-outside-US-Embassy.html "This Just in from London-istan: Violent Clashes Outside U.S. Embassy after Hundreds of UK Muslims Stage Mock Funeral for 'Murdered' Bin Laden"]. ''[[Daily Mail]]''. May 7, 2011.</ref> {{flag|India}} *{{flag|Jammu and Kashmir}}: May 6, Separatist [[Hurriyat Conference]] leader [[Syed Ali Shah Geelani]] led a gathering for funeral prayers at [[Batmaloo]], [[Srinagar]] for al-Qaeda chief Osama bin Laden. Special prayers were given at [[Pulwama]], [[Bijbehara]] and [[Baramulla]] in [[Kashmir]]. These prayers were attended by about a hundred [[Kashmiri people|Kashmiri Muslims]] who called Osama a martyr. Protesters also shouted anti-U.S. slogans. Although a relatively minor incident, it led to a small riot between police and protesters.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/2011/05/07/stories/2011050751050100.htm |title=Geelani Leads Prayers for Osama May 7, 2011 | work = [[The Hindu]] |date=May 7, 2011 |accessdate=May 12, 2011 |location=Chennai, India}}</ref> {{flag|Egypt}} * Hundreds of Islamist Salafists held special prayers Friday for Osama bin Laden at the Salafist-run al-Nour Mosque in the Abbasiyah quarter of Cairo after regular Friday noon prayers, though police tried to stop the special prayers. Some Islamists regard bin Laden as a martyr.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.reuters.com/faithworld/2011/05/06/egyptian-salafists-honor-bin-laden-with-death-prayer/ |title=Geelani Leads Prayers for Osama May 7, 2011 |publisher= [[Reuters]] | date=May 6, 2011}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Death of Osama bin Laden conspiracy theories]] *[[Operation Geronimo name controversy]] *[[Reactions to the September 11 attacks]] *[[The Situation Room (photograph)]]
==References== {{reflist|30em|refs= <ref name="economist110504">{{cite news |url= https://www.economist.com/blogs/democracyinamerica/2011/05/targeted_killing|title= Targeted Killing: The Ethics and ''Realpolitik'' of Assassination |date= May 4, 2011 |series= Democracy in America |work = [[The Economist]] |accessdate=May 9, 2011}}</ref> }}
==External links== {{Commons category|Death of Osama bin Laden}} * [http://www.life.com/gallery/59961/bin-laden-is-dead-the-reaction#index/0 Bin Laden Is Dead: The Reaction] – slideshow by ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' * [https://www.npr.org/2011/05/03/135932108/on-social-media-americans-react-to-bin-laden-death On Social Media, Americans React To Bin Laden Death] – report by [[NPR]]
{{Osama bin Laden}} {{Portal bar|Death|Pakistan|Terrorism|United States}}

revision.text:
[[File:Teatro alla Canobbiana Scene From Comte Ory.jpg|thumb|250px|right|The stage setting for Rossini's ''Le Comte Ory'' as performed at the Teatro alla Canobbiana in 1830]] The '''Teatro Lirico''' (known until 1894 as the '''Teatro alla Canobbiana''') is a theatre in [[Milan]], [[Italy]]. In the 19th and early 20th centuries it was particularly notable for [[opera]] performances, including the world premieres of [[Donizetti]]'s ''[[L'elisir d'amore]]'' and [[Umberto Giordano|Giordano]]'s ''[[Fedora (Giordano)|Fedora]]''. The theatre, located on Via Rastrelli, closed in 1998. However, a restoration project was begun in April 2007, and it was due to re-open in 2009 as the Teatro Lirico [[Giorgio Gaber]].
==History== [[File:Milano, Teatro Lirico, interno 01.jpg|thumb|Interior of the Teatro Lirico in 1938, after the restoration of [[Antonio Cassi Ramelli]]]] The Court Theatre of the Ducal Palace in Milan was destroyed by fire on February 26, 1776. With the city deprived of its only theatre, [[Giuseppe Piermarini]] was commissioned to design and build two new theatres on land surrounding the Palace. The church of Santa Maria della Scala was demolished to build the [[La Scala|Teatro alla Scala]]. A second theatre was built nearby, on the site of the Scuole Cannobiane and was called the Teatro alla Canobbiana. The Teatro alla Scala was intended for the more aristocratic audiences, while the Cannobiana was considered the theater for the public at large.<ref>[http://ilmirino.it/2014/11/18/vecchio-teatro-cannobiana/ Il Mirino] article on the Teatro Cannobiana, 18 novembre 2014 – by Carlo Radollovich.</ref>
It was inaugurated on August 21, 1779 (a little more than year after the opening of La Scala) with an [[opera buffa]] and [[ballet]] by [[Antonio Salieri|Salieri]]. Like La Scala and many Italian opera houses of the time, it was built in a horseshoe shape, surmounted by a [[cupola]], with four tiers of boxes and a gallery (or ''loggione''). For nearly a century it was Milan's second opera house.
By the 1880s, with the increasing lack of public funds and fewer and fewer private subscriptions, the Teatro alla Canobbiana had fallen on hard times. In 1894, it was taken over by [[Edoardo Sonzogno]] and renamed the Teatro Lirico Internazionale, although it is normally referred to in Milan simply as the Teatro Lirico. The theatre continued to be used for opera, ballet, and plays into the 20th century, but was taken over by the city of Milan in 1926, after which it was increasingly used for public assemblies. It was in the Teatro Lirico that [[Benito Mussolini]] made one of his first public speeches in 1921 and his last public speech and radio broadcast in 1944. The building was badly damaged by a fire in 1938, but was repaired in time to host the 1943 season for [[La Scala]] after its own theatre had been largely destroyed by the American aerial bombardment of Milan during [[World War II]].
Theatrical performances, and public meetings resumed after the War, and for a period in the 1960s, the Teatro Lirico was the home of [[Giorgio Strehler]]'s [[Piccolo Teatro di Milano]]. In 1998, facing financial difficulties, Milan could no longer afford to run the theatre, and in the absence of outside funding, it was closed.
In April 2007, after several false starts, work was begun to renovate and modernise the theatre while keeping the Piermarini facade and the basic design of the original interior. When it re-opens, it will be called the Teatro Lirico [[Giorgio Gaber]] in honour of the Milanese singer, songwriter, actor and playwright who had frequently performed at the Teatro Lirico from the early 1960s until its closure in 1998. The renovated theatre will also house the archives of the Fondazione Giorgio Gaber.
==World premieres== '''Opera''' {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} *[[Antonio Salieri|Salieri]]'s ''[[Il Talismino|Il talismano]]'' – 21 August 1779 *Vaccai's ''Romeo e Giulietta'' – 31 October 1825 *[[Cesare Pugni|Pugni]]'s ''Il Disertore Svizzero'' – 1831 *[[Donizetti]]'s ''[[L'elisir d'amore]]'' – 12 May 1832 *[[Francesco Cilea|Cilea]]'s ''[[L'arlesiana|L'Arlesiana]]'' – 27 November 1897 *[[Umberto Giordano|Giordano]]'s ''[[Fedora (Giordano)|Fedora]]'' – 17 November 1898 *[[Leoncavallo]]'s ''[[Zazà]]'' – 10 November 1900 {{col-break}} *Cilea's ''[[Adriana Lecouvreur]]'' – 6 November 1902 *Giordano's ''Marcella'' – 9 November 1907 *[[Franz Lehár|Lehár]]'s ''Gigolette'' – 30 December 1926
'''Ballet''' *[[Ponchielli]]'s ''Il genio della montagna'' February, 1874 {{col-end}}
==References== {{Reflist}} *{{cite web |url=http://www.teatroliricomilano.it |title=Teatro Lirico Giorgio Gaber |accessdate=28 October 2010}} *Cevolani, A., 1999, ''Le Scuole Allievi Ufficiali della Guardia Nazionale Repubblicana durante la RSI: l'esperienza di Fontanellato'', Università degli Studi di Milano, [http://www.tesionline.it Doctoral Thesis]. (accessed 24 May 2007) *Colussi, P., 2002, 'Palazzo Reale dagli Spagnoli ai Savoia', [http://www.storiadimilano.it/citta/Piazza_Duomo/palazzo_reale_-_dagli_spagnoli_ai_savoia.htm Storia di Milano]. (accessed 24 May 2007) *Fondazione Giorgio Gaber, [http://www.fondazioneitalianelmondo.com/2004/NOTIZIARIO/Sezione_NOTIZIE/Nasce_il_teatro_lirico_Gaber.htm Press Release:] 'Nasce a Milano il Teatro Lirico Giorgio Gaber', April 19, 2007. (accessed 24 May 2007) *Piano, R., 1995, ''Torino: la stampa racconta l'operetta'', Università degli Studi di Torino, [http://www.tesionline.it Doctoral Thesis]. (accessed 24 May 2007) *Zonca, P. 'Il Lirico sarà la casa di Gaber', ''La Repubblica'', 31 December 2005.
'''Further Reading'''
*Cambiaghi, M. 1996, ''La Scena Drammatica Del Teatro Alla Canobbiana in Milano (1779–1892)'', Bulzoni. {{ISBN|978-88-7119-987-0}}
